headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to The J. M. Smucker Company's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the conference over to Aaron B
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to The J. M. Smucker Company's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. At this time, I would like to inform you that this conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now turn the conference over to Aaron Broholm, Director, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our third quarter earnings conference call. With me today and presenting our prepared comments are Richard Smucker, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Belgya, Chief Financial Officer. Also
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our third quarter earnings conference call. 
With me today and presenting our prepared comments are Richard Smucker, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Belgya, Chief Financial Officer. 
Also joining us for the Q&A portion of the call is Vince Byrd, Vice Chairman; Steve Oakland, President, Coffee and Foodservice; Mark Smucker, President, Consumer Foods; Dave West, President, Pet Foods; and Barry Dunaway, President, International. 
As a reminder, on March 1, Barry will be assuming leadership of the Pet Food segment. At that time, the International business will begin reporting to Mark Smucker.  For the purpose of today's call, questions in these areas will be fielded by the current business President. 
During this conference call, we will make forward-looking statements that reflect the company's current expectations about future plans and performance. These statements rely on a number of assumptions and estimates, and actual results may differ materially due to risks and uncertainties. I encourage you to read the full disclosure statement in this morning's press release concerning forward-looking statements. 
Additionally, please note the company uses non-GAAP results for the purpose of evaluating performance internally as detailed in the press release, which is located in our corporate website at jmsmucker.com. A replay of this call will also be available on our website. If you have any questions after today's call, please contact me. 
I will now turn the call over to Richard.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Aaron. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. It was a great pressure to see many of you last week at CAGNY. We appreciate the opportunity to provide an update on a number of key initiatives that are going on across our businesse
componenttext:
Thank you, Aaron. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. It was a great pressure to see many of you last week at CAGNY. We appreciate the opportunity to provide an update on a number of key initiatives that are going on across our businesses. 
One of our takeaways from CAGNY was how aligned the CPG companies were on the trends that we're all seeing in the changing consumer perceptions and shopping habits. The real key to success is how each company responds to these changes and perceptions. We're trying to capitalize early on trends and not the fads, with bigger, longer lasting bests. 
We also believe that our company and especially our brands are well in line with the consumers' desires, and we are in a better position than most to capture more of the growth from these trends. 
Today, our comments will primarily focus on the third quarter financial results that we announced earlier this morning and our updated outlook for the rest of the year. 
I'll begin with an overview of consolidated results. First, net sales increased 37% to nearly $2 billion, driven by the addition of the Big Heart Pet Brands. Excluding acquisitions, divestitures and foreign exchange, sales declined -- the sales decline of 1% was reflected in volume decline in Consumer Foods and the price declined in Coffee. 
Second, non-GAAP operating income grew $108 million or 44% for the third quarter. 
The addition of the Big Heart business, strong Coffee segment profit growth and onetime gain on the divestiture of the U.S. Canned Milk business were all key drivers. 
Third, reflecting increased interest expense and a higher share count, non-GAAP earnings per share increased 14% to $1.76. 
Excluding amortization, adjusted earnings per share were $2.05, an increase of 21% from the comparable measure in the prior year. Both of these EPS metrics include a $0.14 per share gain on the divestiture of the Milk business. 
Lastly, we generated record free cash flow nearly $500 million in the quarter, bringing the full year total to $962 million. 
Turning to our U.S. Retail segments. I'll start with Coffee, which had another strong quarter as our growth initiatives, along with favorable manufacturing overhead and commodity cost benefited results. 
Looking at the key drivers, Folgers roast and ground coffee volume based on tonnage was up slightly compared to the prior year, while unit shipments increased even more, reflecting the transition to a reduced canister size for the Folgers offerings. 
With our price reduction related to small canisters and an additional list price decrease implemented in July to pass through lower green coffee cost, consumers are seeing lower price points on shelf and our market share continues to grow. 
During the latest 12-week period, our brands gained 3 points dollar share within the mainstream Coffee segment. 
For our overall K-Cup portfolio, the Dunkin' Donuts brand continues to drive growth with a 12-week ACB of over 90% and a 6% dollar share of the K-Cup category.  Consumer trial and repeat rates also remained strong. 
We're pleased with the momentum for this business, which has helped offset declines for Folgers K-Cups. 
As with other mainstream brands, Folgers K-Cups continue to be impacted by the proliferation of offerings in the K-Cup space and the resulting competitive pricing. Our team is focused on improving this trend, including price improvements. 
The performance of Dunkin' Donuts bagged coffee was soft in the quarter, reflecting aggressive pricing -- competitive pricing. However, the recent target pricing investments, which are supported by favorable green coffee costs, our price gaps have improved and we're well-positioned as we move ahead. 
Lastly, Café Bustelo brand established a new record for the quarterly sales under our ownership with double-digit gains for both roast and ground and K-Cup offerings in the quarter. 
Promotional activities such as our Café Bustelo pop-up cafés have successfully broadened the brand awareness and the brand continues to gain traction especially with millennials. 
Turning to Consumer Foods. Overall results were mixed. Specifically, the Smucker's brand performed well in the quarter. Smucker's Uncrustables frozen sandwiches achieved a 16th consecutive quarter of double-digit volume growth. 
In addition, net sales for Smucker's Fruit Spreads were in line with last year's third quarter and the brand continues to gain volume in dollar share within the breads category. 
Within Natural Foods, our branded business also had a strong third quarter, led by double-digit sales gains for our R.W. Knudsen family and Santa Cruz Organic brands. 
Volume for the Jif brand was down from the prior year, primarily attributable to a reduction in inventory levels at several key customers. We believe this is mostly the result of timing as ScanData trends remained positive for our peanut butter business. 
Lastly, in the baking aisle, the overall category remains down, which we believe is partially attributable to continued growth in retailers and store bakeries. Our results have been further impacted by aggressive competitive pricing as was expected.  Our focus remains on providing value-added innovation in these categories and competing responsibly. 
Results for our Pet Food business also fell short of expectations in the quarter. Mainstream pet food sales continue to reflect heightened competitive activity and drive ARPU, which has impacted the performance of our Kibbles 'n Bits brand. 
As we discussed last week, we are looking at all levers, including pricing, and are committed to improving the competitive position of our Dry Dog Food business. 
Cat food sales were also down in the quarter, however, similar to peanut butter, we view this as a timing issue with certain key customers as market share trends remained positive. 
Offsetting much of these declines were the continued strong performance of our premium pet food and pet snacks brands, which both achieved high single digit sales growth in the quarter. 
We have been pleased with the rollout of the Natural Balance brand into PetSmart. 
Also, innovation for Milk-Bone and Meow Mix brand has continued to be a key contributor to the pet snack results. 
Overall, while mainstream dog food has been challenged, we are pleased by solid results in Pet Specialty and Pet Snacks, which are the growing segments of the business. 
With respect to both pet foods and the broader organization, we continue to make good progress on our integration activities and synergy targets. Our March 1 integration is now just a week away, and through the hard work and dedication of many individuals throughout our company, we are well prepared for this exciting milestone. 
Lastly, as Mark will discuss in a moment, we continue to expect our full year earnings per share before factoring in the gain of the sale of the milk business to be in line with the guidance provided at the end of the second quarter. 
In addition, we remain confident about our brands and the initiatives we have in place to support future growth across our key platforms of Coffee, Consumer Foods and Pet Foods. 
Finally, I'd like to close by thanking all our employees. This continues to be an exciting and dynamic time, and we appreciate their ongoing efforts. 
With that, I will now turn the call over to Mark.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Richard, and good morning, everyone. I will start by providing additional color on our third quarter results and then conclude by updating our outlook for the year. Net sales increased by $534 million in the quarter, reflecting the addition o
componenttext:
Thank you, Richard, and good morning, everyone. I will start by providing additional color on our third quarter results and then conclude by updating our outlook for the year. 
Net sales increased by $534 million in the quarter, reflecting the addition of Big Heart. Including pet, sales were down as lower net pricing primarily for Coffee detracted 2 percentage points from net sales. 
Foreign exchange was also unfavorable in the quarter, reducing net sales by about 1 percentage point. 
Conversely, volume and mix combined to add 1 point of growth as strong contributions from Dunkin' Donuts K-Cups were mostly offset by declines in several key categories. 
GAAP earnings per share were $1.55 this quarter, 2% below the prior year. Included in GAAP earnings were $45 million of special project costs related to merger integration activities compared to $6 million of such cost in the prior year. 
Also included were $7 million of unallocated derivative gains compared to $30 million last year. 
Excluding these items, non-GAAP EPS was $1.76 or an increase of 14%, which included a $0.14 per share gain on the divestiture of our U.S. Canned Milk business. 
Excluding amortization expense of $52 million, adjusted EPS was $2.05, up 21% for the quarter. Non-GAAP gross profit grew 49%, reflecting the addition of Pet Food and favorable volume/mix for the Coffee segment. And commodity cost were also favorable in the third quarter, most notably for green coffee and were only partially offset by lower net pricing. 
Combined, this resulted in a 310 basis point increase in gross margin to 38.5%, well ahead of our previous expectations for the quarter. 
SD&A increased at a greater rate than sales primarily attributable to incremental marketing spend across all 3 U.S. Retail segments. 
For the third quarter, synergy recognition totaled approximately $12 million, bringing the year-to-date total to $20 million, mostly benefiting G&A expenses. 
As we indicated last week, we are now on track to achieve $35 million in synergies for the full year. 
Amortization expense increased $27 million in the third quarter as a result of the Pet Food acquisition. Factoring all of these in, including a $25 million gain on the sale of the Milk business, non-GAAP operating income increased $108 million or 44%, while operating margin increased 80 basis points to 18%. 
The gain in operating income was partially offset below the line by higher interest expense and an increase in the number of shares outstanding related to the Big Heart acquisition. 
Let me now provide a brief overview of the results for our segments starting with Coffee. Net sales grew 1% as favorable volume mix of 5% was mostly offset by lower net pricing. 
For the Folgers brand, net sales declined 9%, mostly attributable to a 6% reduction in net price realization. 
Unfavorable mix, driven by declines in Folgers K-Cups, also was a factor. 
Sales for the Dunkin' Donuts brand increased 55% for the quarter, driven by Dunkin' Donuts K-Cups. 
And lastly, Café Bustelo sales were up 16% as the momentum for this brand continues. 
Segment profit increased 17% for the quarter, higher volume/mix and lower manufacturing overhead more than offset a double-digit increase in marketing and significantly higher selling expense due to the Dunkin' Donuts royalties. 
And in addition, we continue to recognize lower green coffee cost in the quarter, which is only partially offset by the lower net pricing. 
As we move ahead, we anticipate fourth quarter segment profit growth to be comparable to the year-to-date rate, reflecting the momentum in the business, additional contributions for Dunkin K-Cups and favorable coffee costs. 
Factored into this outlook is ongoing marketing spend related to new products, along with plans to continue supporting key price points as well as other targeted pricing investments to address competitive activity related to Dunkin' Donuts bagged coffee and Folgers K-Cups. 
Overall, we are very pleased with this level of profit recovery following the decline in the prior year. 
Turning to Consumer Foods. Net sales were down 5% as lower volume, the impact of the canned milk divestiture and lower net price realization all contributed. 
Looking at our key brands. Volume for Jif Peanut Butter was down 7% compared to a strong prior year quarter where volume was up 7%. 
As Richard indicated, we believe that current year decline is mostly the result of timing as consumer takeaway was up slightly in the quarter based on volume trends reported in IRI placed 4- and 12-week scan periods. 
Volume for Smucker's Uncrustables was up an impressive 33% for quarter while Smucker fruit spreads were down 2%. However, in the peanut butter, we're encouraged the consumer takeaway trends were much better as scan volume was up nearly 4% in the latest 4- and 12-week periods for Smucker's Fruit Spreads. 
And lastly in the bake aisle, volume for the Crisco and Pillsbury brand declined 3% and 9%, respectively. 
Segment profit increased 6% compared to the prior year, including the $25 million gain on the milk divestiture, a 42% increase in marketing expense, the unfavorable impact of volume and plan increases in manufacturing overhead cost offset much of this gain. 
The higher overhead costs were primarily attributable to the new peanut butter facility in Memphis as well as temporarily under absorbed overhead costs related to our working capital initiatives. 
On a full year basis, we continue to expect Consumer Foods segment profits to be down as the gain from the milk sale will be more than offset by higher overhead, the unfavorable impact of lower pricing net of cost and higher marketing expenses. 
Net sales for our U.S. Retail Pet Foods segments were $571 million in the third quarter. Sales for pet snacks and premium pet brands of growth increased high single digits, driven by distribution gains and new item launches. 
Conversely, mainstream pet food sales declined at low double digits resulting in a modest overall decline for the segment. 
Pet Food segment profit was $97 million for the quarter. As anticipated, we realized a sequential increase in segment profit margin from 15.6% in the second quarter to 17% this quarter, and we continue to expect another sequential step up in the fourth quarter. 
Despite the softer than anticipated top line and a slight reduction in profitability expectations for 2016, we remain on track to deliver on our targeted growing full year pet food gross margin by 100 basis points compared to the prior year. 
Lastly, net sales for International and Foodservice declined 4% in the quarter as the addition of pet food in Canada was more than offset by a $17 million impact of FX. 
Combined segment profit for our International and Foodservice businesses was up 4% over the prior year, primarily in our Canadian business. 
Favorable mix, along with lower selling expenses, contributed to the profit gains. 
The impact of foreign exchange partially offset these items. We continue to expect FX to remain a significant headwind in the fourth quarter and into fiscal 2017. 
Turning to cash flow. Cash provided by operations was $542 million for the quarter compared to $428 million in the prior year. The increase primarily reflect a lower working capital needs as the impact of higher noncash depreciation and amortization in the current year was offset by the benefit of terminating an interest rate swap in the prior year. 
Factoring in capital expenditures of $43 million, free cash flow was $499 million for the quarter, bringing the year-to-date total to $962 million. 
We're increasing our full year outlook for free cash flow from $925 million to $975 million. The increase primarily reflects the strong cash flow performance through the first 9 months of the year, which includes nearly $100 million of our working capital improvement target, up from our previous estimate of $60 million. 
Partially offsetting this as we now project CapEx of $240 million for the year, an increase from our most recent guidance of $220 million as we pull forward spending on certain projects into 2016. 
As a result, CapEx in the fourth quarter is projected to approximately $80 million. 
This step up in CapEx, along with planned inventory build and incremental tax payment are the primary cost of free cash flow increasing only modestly for the fourth quarter. 
In addition to this strong free cash flow, we used after-tax proceeds from the divestiture of the milk business of approximately $165 million to further paid down debt during the third quarter. As a result, we ended the quarter with total debt of just under $5.3 billion and leverage currently stand at approximately 3.5x. 
Let me conclude with an update on our full year sales and earnings outlook for 2016. We now expect net sales of approximately $7.8 billion with the reduction from our previous guidance of $7.9 million, primarily attributable to Consumer Foods and Pet Food segments. 
For Consumer Foods, this reflects the softer-than-anticipated third quarter results, which we expect to continue into the fourth quarter, particularly for our oil and baking businesses. For Pets, this reflects the continuing challenges in our dry dog food. 
With stronger-than-expected Coffee segment profits and increase in synergies, we expect to offset the net sale shortfall at bottom line. 
As a result, we continue to expect non-GAAP earnings per share to be consistent with our previous guidance range of $5.70 to $5.80. 
Adding the $0.14 gain on sale of Milk business to this range, our updated guidance is now $5.84 to $5.94 for the year. 
Excluding amortization expense of approximately $1.15 per share, this would result in adjusted earnings per share between $6.99 and $7.09. 
As discussed last week, we expect to recognize a noncash deferred tax benefit related to the integration of Big Heart into the Smucker company during the fourth quarter. While not factored into our revised guidance range, we're estimating this benefit to be approximately $50 million. 
In summary, we continue to be pleased with the earnings performance of the company and, in particular, the ongoing strong results for coffee. Our overall results reflect the success of our key growth initiatives for the current year, including the launch of Dunkin K-Cups, achieving lower price points for Folgers roast and ground coffee, introduction of Natural Balance and PetSmart. 
At the same time, while delivering on our cost-savings and our working capital initiatives. 
And as we move ahead, we're encouraged by the plans in place to deliver continued growth. 
With that, we'll now open the call up to your questions. Operator, can you please queue up the first question?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Eric Katzman with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Eric Katzman with Deutsche Bank.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I wanted to, Richard, I guess, you talked about some of the similarities across the companies at CAGNY last week. But I guess, one of the differences we found out today was that your advertising spending is up significantly across the bulk of the
componenttext: I guess, I wanted to, Richard, I guess, you talked about some of the similarities across the companies at CAGNY last week. But I guess, one of the differences we found out today was that your advertising spending is up significantly across the bulk of the business, whereas a lot of folks are cutting back on that. But I guess, the question is you didn't really see the benefit in terms of shipments. And so how should we think about the fact that you're spending to support the business, which is good, but not really seeing the follow through in terms of unit tell?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll give a general answer and then I'll ask the team to respond specifically. But advertising, our advertising, primarily longer-term and the benefits of the advertising don't just hit quarter-by-quarter. A lot of that this brand building, and we tr
componenttext: Yes, I'll give a general answer and then I'll ask the team to respond specifically. But advertising, our advertising, primarily longer-term and the benefits of the advertising don't just hit quarter-by-quarter. A lot of that this brand building, and we try to do it over time, we try to be consistent. And so, we wouldn't expect to see it necessarily in the quarter, but the team has specific efforts that we made this past quarter.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Richard, this is Mark Smucker. I would just add, Eric, that we did pull back significantly on advertising last year, so we are returning our advertising more to historical levels. And as Richard said, it is around some building of equity. We have a new Sm
componenttext: Richard, this is Mark Smucker. I would just add, Eric, that we did pull back significantly on advertising last year, so we are returning our advertising more to historical levels. And as Richard said, it is around some building of equity. We have a new Smucker's TV commercial on air and then just supporting some of our new things in Milk-Bone. But Richard is also right that the support on advertising generally does as a residual impact. So we think it's important.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, and -- it's Steve Oakland. I would say there's a number of factors in the Coffee business right now that are all going right, but it would be hard not to say some of the marketing materials, especially on the Dunkin K-Cups launch. We've got awarenes
componenttext: Sure, and -- it's Steve Oakland. I would say there's a number of factors in the Coffee business right now that are all going right, but it would be hard not to say some of the marketing materials, especially on the Dunkin K-Cups launch. We've got awareness out there very, very quickly on that. Side, so I would hope that the Dunkin media has been very helpful.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as my second question follow up more on the cash flow side of things. Free cash flow very, very strong and your debt has come down pretty quickly. I guess, Richard, as you kind of think about that cash and returning it to shareholders,
componenttext: Okay. And then just as my second question follow up more on the cash flow side of things. Free cash flow very, very strong and your debt has come down pretty quickly. I guess, Richard, as you kind of think about that cash and returning it to shareholders, is there any, I guess, adjustment in terms of the debt pay down versus buy back in kind of balancing those 2 opportunities?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure I'll start on that, and I'll let Mark finish up. But we look at using cash in a variety of ways. Our first choice is to look at new acquisitions because we think that builds the business for the full long term. But share buyback is still part of our
componenttext: Sure I'll start on that, and I'll let Mark finish up. But we look at using cash in a variety of ways. Our first choice is to look at new acquisitions because we think that builds the business for the full long term. But share buyback is still part of our plan over time. We still think our company is a great investment and with a better cash flow that we have, this is a little bit of both, better ability to do that sooner rather than later. But no announcements at this point.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, it's Mark. I think, basically agree with Richard. We've been pretty adamant to last year so as we our last half year, I guess, as we came out the transaction that with the speeding up of the pay down. And the fact that we get around 3x, I think we'r
componenttext: Eric, it's Mark. I think, basically agree with Richard. We've been pretty adamant to last year so as we our last half year, I guess, as we came out the transaction that with the speeding up of the pay down. And the fact that we get around 3x, I think we're at the level that we're comfortable with 3x leverage so we'll hit that end of next year. So that's just we'll speed up anything in terms of, whether it's acquisition, buyback or other uses of this cash.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, will be Ken Goldman of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next, will be Ken Goldman of JPMorgan.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions on Pet. And, Barry, not to throw you into the fire, and I realize it's early, but are you expecting to make any meaningful changes to the strategy for the business overall? Because I think it's safe to say, at least from an outsiders pe
componenttext: I have 2 questions on Pet. And, Barry, not to throw you into the fire, and I realize it's early, but are you expecting to make any meaningful changes to the strategy for the business overall? Because I think it's safe to say, at least from an outsiders perspective, growth has been disappointing where management has talked recently about reducing prices in Kibbles 'n Bits, but mainstream dog or dry dog is I guess what 20% of the portfolio? So I'm just not sure how discounting one brand is enough. It just feels, I guess, again, from one outsider's perspective like bigger changes across-the-board need to be made to hit your numbers.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well from a strategic perspective,  I would say no fundamental changes in strategy. We think that Snacks business really is the key driver of the Pet Food business, both in terms of sales and profit therefore we'll continue to invest and innovate. From a
componenttext: Well from a strategic perspective,  I would say no fundamental changes in strategy. We think that Snacks business really is the key driver of the Pet Food business, both in terms of sales and profit therefore we'll continue to invest and innovate. From a dry dog perspective, clearly, we're looking at what the trends are in mass premium, and we're going to step back and understand what we need to do to compete there. Similar to all other categories that we participate in, we feel we should have a presence in every segment, but we're watching them as premium, and we'll figure out what our strategy should be there long term. But I would say no fundamental shifts in the strategy. This will drive the business long term, and it is about snacks. Dave, would you add anything to that?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so I guess, my second question is...
componenttext: Okay, so I guess, my second question is...

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Rick. Let me just add to that because we're still very excited about the Pet business. I mean this is it's a great business. In any acquisition we've ever made historically, there's always a hiccup. I've never had an acquisition where one of the -
componenttext: This is Rick. Let me just add to that because we're still very excited about the Pet business. I mean this is it's a great business. In any acquisition we've ever made historically, there's always a hiccup. I've never had an acquisition where one of the -- all of the cylinders fire 100%. But we are 3/4 of this business is doing very well. And so we'll figure out the mainstream pet soon enough. But the other business are right in line where we like them to be. And so we're still very confident and very excited about the pet business.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean, I guess, it's different when Godzilla hiccups versus when Gecko hiccups and this is Godzilla for you guys. It's a very big business. But I'll move on to my next question. You highlighted the challenges faced by Kibbles 'n Bits, right? As we
componenttext: Okay. I mean, I guess, it's different when Godzilla hiccups versus when Gecko hiccups and this is Godzilla for you guys. It's a very big business. But I'll move on to my next question. You highlighted the challenges faced by Kibbles 'n Bits, right? As we look at Nielsen data, sales for the brand is really been a steady decline for years and I realize the rate of erosion has accelerated versus a year ago, but it's similar to what it's been each of the last 8, 9 months at least in the Nielsen again. So I guess, I'm not sure why the weakness this quarter was such a surprise to you.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let the this is Dave. Let me take that question. We did see heightening competitive activity in the marketplace in the quarter in the form of price side and wage changes in bonus ags. We have corn and soybean milk continue to be trading at relative l
componenttext: Yes, let the this is Dave. Let me take that question. We did see heightening competitive activity in the marketplace in the quarter in the form of price side and wage changes in bonus ags. We have corn and soybean milk continue to be trading at relative lows and what we have seen is some of that favorability commodities was reinvested in the marketplace and I think what on a year-to-date basis, we would -- our margins, our gross margins in the mainstream pet food business are actually up. So not all of the commodity favorability has been passed through from our perspective, and we're using part of our goal and the way we set our plans for this of fiscal would have been prior to the acquisition of Big Heart by JMS. So we executed those plans. You will see it become a bit more aggressive now as we come into the latter part of the year and the early part of next year to respond to some of the bonus pay activity. Now the relative price and size. But I think overall, it was a little bit more -- it was more down than we would expect it to be, but the margin structure of the business is still pretty good and there's a fundamentally there's a consumer food there's is going to continue to look at value in the marketplace but there other consumers who are looking for other benefits, and we will go meet those other benefits in a different way, it won't be a price lever. So I think Barry's point was, we see other segments emerging, we're very pleased with our premium dog food business in this pet -- specialty channel and in the independent channel, but we're not happy with where we are in mass.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next will be Chris Growe with Stifel.
componenttext: Next will be Chris Growe with Stifel.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions for me, if I could. First, on Coffee. If we look at the Coffee business, I'm looking again at some IRI and Nielsen data. Just showing coffee, excluding the Dunkin' K-Cups, overall coffee has been a bit weak. And I think you did cite some wea
componenttext: Two questions for me, if I could. First, on Coffee. If we look at the Coffee business, I'm looking again at some IRI and Nielsen data. Just showing coffee, excluding the Dunkin' K-Cups, overall coffee has been a bit weak. And I think you did cite some weakness on the Folgers K-Cup side. I think that's part of the issue. I just want to get a sense. You've increased marketing spending I think behind the business. Does require just being more promotional, or is there one piece of the business that you need to attack if you will kind of firm up the non-Dunkin' K-Cup Coffee business?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, Steve Oakland. The Coffee business does have a couple of big segments and if you bore into that Nielsen data, you'll see that our mainstream roast and ground business, although threw a lot of changes this year remember there's an 11% smaller canist
componenttext: Chris, Steve Oakland. The Coffee business does have a couple of big segments and if you bore into that Nielsen data, you'll see that our mainstream roast and ground business, although threw a lot of changes this year remember there's an 11% smaller canister, the promotional size, and we took a 6% price decline. So your roll those two things and then you actually see volume up. So mainstream volume will be up when you take 11% out of the canister. We think it's a nice rebound to that business, and we're hitting price points that excite and I talked about this both the retailer and the consumer, right? You need to the price point to get to retailer excited about merchandising. So that piece of business is much healthier than it's been in a while. So then you take our Dunkin' K-Cup business, and it's fair to say that, that business has just come out of the gate on fire. We should continue to see good momentum there. So the Dunkin' K-Cup business is very strong and although small, Bustelo is starting to move our share a little bit, right? It's starting to get big enough that that business is material. Now the Dunkin' bag business has been a struggle early on the year. I would say that we've seen price compression in premium that we've never seen before. And part of that was driven by a green and part of that is driven by the strategy of the competitive side. And so the good news is the pricing we have in the market we've seen today turned that around somewhat turned that around be expected business as green helps us to get even better. And frankly the legacy K-Cup business or the Folgers K-Cup business is performing, I would argue, held up K-Cup category. If you take 2 premium brand out, you take out some of the other major premium brand in the K-Cup business, it's not a healthy category. And so the opportunity for us is to continue the momentum on the Dunkin' business and to fix our K-Cup business. And we are committed, I think it's an important statement to grow in our whole K-Cup portfolio over time. Dunkin' is giving us a little bit of tailwind there, a lot of tailwind right there, but the challenge process to get our legacy K-Cup business back on track.

componenttext: Yes, there's no question. You will see K-Cup mainstream K-Cups would be much more price competitive across -- it's hard to say what our competitors will do, but we'll be following that trend and some of that pricing is actually in the market as we speak.

componenttext: Steve, I would also maybe add to that the retail is right is kind of resetting the categories because I think they've all agreed there's been too many SKUs there. And we have some very, very good SKUs that I think as they do resets, we'll end up with a better position overtime.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it will be classic category management right with all of that growth everybody just threw SKUs at and threw space at. And now you'll see Class A category management. How many hazelnuts do you need. I mean you go in some sections and there's 13 hazeln
componenttext: Yes, it will be classic category management right with all of that growth everybody just threw SKUs at and threw space at. And now you'll see Class A category management. How many hazelnuts do you need. I mean you go in some sections and there's 13 hazelnuts. So I think those things will work their way out. But we have some more work to do on that on the K-Cup business. The consumers told us they want them, and so we have to win there.

componenttext: Chris, it's Mark. Obviously, if you take where we ended this quarter and probably somewhat similar in Q4 and take that off, I think you're going to get down more in that $2.2 billion range.

componenttext: Yes. Go back to your first point I would like to clarify why we include, so that everyone understand on the call. We have, historically, put the expectations on our businesses, both on the positive and the negative. The response for the brands, and that's why overtime, we've included amortization and impairment. At the same time, the brand benefits is generate a gain on the sale of brands that no longer fits the portfolio. We felt is just as appropriate around that through. So, while you guys may exclude that, clearly, that's the reason we leave it in.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, fine. And then final question for me just on Natural Balance. I think you guys said that the growth in the third quarter on your specialty business, which I'm going to assume is mostly Natural Balance. I know there's another brand here, but I know it
componenttext: Yes, fine. And then final question for me just on Natural Balance. I think you guys said that the growth in the third quarter on your specialty business, which I'm going to assume is mostly Natural Balance. I know there's another brand here, but I know it's mostly it's Natural Balance was high single digits. I think in the last call you said the growth in the Natural Balance was up to elect mid-teens or high teens so if those statements are true, is there a bit of a deceleration in growth rate there? Number one, is that true? And then number two, kind of how do you see the growth for that business over the longer course of time because it seems there's some fair amount of volatility here. I mean, it's good news, but it's a question of what landscape are we in, high single digits or mid-teens?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Natural Balance -- this is Dave. Natural Balance was up double digits in the quarter. We have the Nature's Recipe brand, which is a gateway brand in pet specialty as people cross over from mass. That brand was not up as much so that goes into that premium
componenttext: Natural Balance -- this is Dave. Natural Balance was up double digits in the quarter. We have the Nature's Recipe brand, which is a gateway brand in pet specialty as people cross over from mass. That brand was not up as much so that goes into that premium measurement that we gave you. So I think overall, we are very happy with where we are in the Natural Balance expansion where the PetSmart, we continue to be pleased across the channel, across the 2 majors pet specialty retails, but also with distribution gains that we're getting and other independent and other parts of the channel. So pleased with where we are. As we go forward, we haven't given a projection with respect to growth on a forward basis and I would not want to do that since my competitors out there probably aren't going to give me the growth projections either, so I think I'll pass.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016

componenttext: Next is Jason English with Goldman Sachs.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to pick up where David left off. So I, too, was struck by premium only growing high single digits in the context of all the PetSmart distribution growth. So are we overestimating how much PetSmart distribution on the balance product is contribute
componenttext: I wanted to pick up where David left off. So I, too, was struck by premium only growing high single digits in the context of all the PetSmart distribution growth. So are we overestimating how much PetSmart distribution on the balance product is contributed? Or is the business sort of kind of flattish, maybe even down, excluding distribution?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, one of the things that you have to understand is the measurement of how incremental truly is that distribution. Is that incremental to the retailer as we expand, is it incremental to the category, what are the cannibalization rates. So we ha
componenttext: Yes, I think, one of the things that you have to understand is the measurement of how incremental truly is that distribution. Is that incremental to the retailer as we expand, is it incremental to the category, what are the cannibalization rates. So we have an assumption on the way in of what that business with the. Again, Natural Balance is not the only brand in that measurement when we talk about premium. So we have other businesses that are sold in the premium and in channels, and they are not growing as rapidly. So I'm pleased with where we are with Natural Balance. I think we've done a very good job of expanding the footprint this year. We have our first national ad campaign on the business that we've launched into a higher protein offering in the period, and we've gotten good shelf space in the major retail PetSmart and kept our relationships with Petco and independents at the same time. So I think we're in good shape. We've got double-digit growth in the brand I'm not going to apologize for double-digit growth. I think that's pretty good and it's kind of in the range of acceptable for us right now.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know, I hear you. Double-digit growth is always good. But I'm still not sure I'm tracking. If we excluded the PetSmart distribution gain, on Natural Balance, is your premium portfolio growing?
componenttext: I know, I hear you. Double-digit growth is always good. But I'm still not sure I'm tracking. If we excluded the PetSmart distribution gain, on Natural Balance, is your premium portfolio growing?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, I'm not going to try to be difficult, but I'm not going to answer the question because yes, you can't assume that these higher set of distribution is 100% incremental. The hope would be that anytime you add distribution is 100% incremental, but tha
componenttext: Again, I'm not going to try to be difficult, but I'm not going to answer the question because yes, you can't assume that these higher set of distribution is 100% incremental. The hope would be that anytime you add distribution is 100% incremental, but that's just not the reality of it. There's always cannibalization and consumers are going to find their way as they see distribution in new places. So I'm not going to try to get into disclosing the incrementality or the switching behavior of consumers. It's just -- that's something that we're measuring, where we have new distribution it's also something that we are tracking very closely and the rest of the channel where we have this distribution for a long period of time. Those are conversations that we'll have with all of the retailers in the channel, make sure we're brining the brand the right way. As I said, we're happy with where we are, and you build distribution, you build awareness, and you see how consumers are trying and are they new to the category, are they new to the retailer. Those are the things that we're measuring on a weekly basis but like I said, I'm happy with where we are, but I don't think I'd give out any more information than that.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. One more question I'll pass it on. On Coffee, congratulations for a phenomenal rebound this year, guys. Obviously, a contributor to call out has been the positive price-to-cost surplus. Do you think that can sustain, or are we reaching a
componenttext: Okay, understood. One more question I'll pass it on. On Coffee, congratulations for a phenomenal rebound this year, guys. Obviously, a contributor to call out has been the positive price-to-cost surplus. Do you think that can sustain, or are we reaching a point where he equilibrium in terms of price pass-through in the cost relief will approach or given competitive dynamics in the category, can you actually sustain surplus for longer than historically at?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, well, there's a couple of things we need to really look at in the numbers. We look at the price-to-cost relationship on an annual basis, right? And I think we took price down early, and so you might see some of that. You saw some of that hit us in t
componenttext: Okay, well, there's a couple of things we need to really look at in the numbers. We look at the price-to-cost relationship on an annual basis, right? And I think we took price down early, and so you might see some of that. You saw some of that hit us in the early periods, you see now the benefit of that later periods. The volume is also helping our operational efficiency. And so just the nature of how some of things fall, a lot of that fell this quarter is an annual number, but it falls in periods when you take that absorption. So I think we can see very good margins. We continue to see solid margin growth in this business. We think the green market as we look out the next quarter or so or 2 looks like it will continue to help us hit on those price points to invest in the things I talked about in the earlier question and maintain similar margins. So we think we can keep all of those things, it's really 3 dimensional, it's exciting to consumer, exciting to retailer than having those things right, we think we're going to be in good shape the next couple of quarters.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, I'm going to add one thing to that -- to this comment is that, last year, when we sat here we knew our challenge in coffee. A lot of the activities that have taken place this year in coffee were put into strategy last year, almost the fact, for exa
componenttext: Jason, I'm going to add one thing to that -- to this comment is that, last year, when we sat here we knew our challenge in coffee. A lot of the activities that have taken place this year in coffee were put into strategy last year, almost the fact, for example, the change in the excitement of our coffee canister was a 2-year project. So we saw last year the challenges that we had in coffee and even before that occurred, we were putting a lot of initiatives in place to make sure this year and is turned out the latest. Now obviously we have the tailwind a little bit of green mountain the green cost coffee cost. And -- but the work on getting the Dunkin' K-Cup was also a 2- or 3-year project. So a lot of those initiatives, really, are 2 to 3 years old and now they're all coming to fruition this year. So I just want to put in perspective that when we see a tough quarter, we can't respond and the very next quarter, things turn around. So it's just I think it's important to remember that, but it's also important to remember that we look at those things and take that long-term perspective. And so the same thing applies on mainstream pet food business, and we put a number of initiatives in place, so we think that overtime, that will turn around also. But we're not sitting in our laurels. We recognize those are challenges that we have and have a number of initiatives in place, but you may not see the results of those for 6 to 9 months or a year later.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Alexia Howard with Bernstein.
componenttext: The next question is from Alexia Howard with Bernstein.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 quick questions. Firstly, on promotional activity, we had a number of other companies talking about how that pruning in effect of promotions the sense that I'm good thing is that in some of your more competitive areas, you might actually be stepp
componenttext: I have 2 quick questions. Firstly, on promotional activity, we had a number of other companies talking about how that pruning in effect of promotions the sense that I'm good thing is that in some of your more competitive areas, you might actually be stepping that out. So I just like to hear your view on directionally, are you likely to see more less promotion over the next year or so? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Alexia, this is Mark Smucker. I'll guess, I'll start. The way you're seeing promotional activity like baking, there is no question that, that has taken place. We've seen in that particular category that the adjusted promotion has not yielded gross a
componenttext: Well, Alexia, this is Mark Smucker. I'll guess, I'll start. The way you're seeing promotional activity like baking, there is no question that, that has taken place. We've seen in that particular category that the adjusted promotion has not yielded gross and actually, we've seen that across multiple customers. But in their other areas where we are more focused on being more efficient in our trade spend, and so overtime, our goal is, as I think we've said a couple of times, not to prune for the sake of pruning but to get better at spending those dollars and putting them where they really do expect the business.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as a follow-up, in the U.S. Retail Consumer business, you've got pockets that seem to be working quite well like Uncrustables and and other like areas like baking that happen weaker. How are you thinking about resourcing those weaker parts
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up, in the U.S. Retail Consumer business, you've got pockets that seem to be working quite well like Uncrustables and and other like areas like baking that happen weaker. How are you thinking about resourcing those weaker parts going forward? Are they areas that are targeted for the more investment, more innovation, more marketing to fix it? Or might we see a pullback on some of that investments or maybe even further divestments along the lines of the Canned Milk business?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, again, baking, I think we've heard broadly from our customer base that they weren't as happy, of course, with the Fall Bake period given the level of activity and the fact that the category itself continue to decline. What's interesting is and where w
componenttext: So, again, baking, I think we've heard broadly from our customer base that they weren't as happy, of course, with the Fall Bake period given the level of activity and the fact that the category itself continue to decline. What's interesting is and where we have seen good growth is on the on-trend items, like gluten-free and the more simple ingredients, those businesses seem to be doing very well, albeit not enough to offset the decline in sort of the mainstream business. So cake frosting, unfortunately, frosting has been down as well. Brownies are actually doing well for some reason, but it's really need more on-trend authentic simple ingredients items that we're seeing some good growth. That would also be true in our Fruit Spreads business as well or even though we had a down quarter in peanut butter, our Jif Natural, our National Product is actually up significantly as well. So from a peanut butter perspective, I think we're less concerns because the consumer takeaway has not followed our decline in shipments. And so we would expect to see some improvement over the coming months in peanut butter.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016

componenttext: Farha, it's Mark, again. In peanut butter, we do think it's probably limited to the third quarter. Again, the consumer take away on the ScanData has not reflected that, so I think we feel cautiously optimistic about the next several months.

componenttext: On cat food, we've seen there are some shipment timing with respect to promotion new item activated that was in year ago. And so I think you're going to have noise up-and-down with respect to shipment timing, but I think feel free to go about the mix, the business particularly where we're headed next year with respect to innovation.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Farha, this is Barry. I think you also have to remember that you a couple of major retailers the fiscal year and the same as our third quarter and this is not unprecedented in terms of what occurred historically that there might be some destocking at the
componenttext: Farha, this is Barry. I think you also have to remember that you a couple of major retailers the fiscal year and the same as our third quarter and this is not unprecedented in terms of what occurred historically that there might be some destocking at the end of their fiscal year. So it goes in cycles, but we would anticipate that not to be a long-term situation.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful. And then just as a follow-up, the 3 drivers of your topline this year seem to be Dunkin' K-Cups, Uncrustables and Natural Balance. Each of them have benefited from channel sale and capacity expansion this year. When you look longer
componenttext: That's really helpful. And then just as a follow-up, the 3 drivers of your topline this year seem to be Dunkin' K-Cups, Uncrustables and Natural Balance. Each of them have benefited from channel sale and capacity expansion this year. When you look longer term into next year, would you expect these businesses to continue to be able to post growth going into next year? Or is there something else that will take their place in terms of growth drivers?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Farha, this is Mark Belgya. I think the expectation those are 3 big areas that we would continue to invest and expect to grow. Now will this be as additive as they were this year? That will be determined. We're also, as normal course is, we're going to co
componenttext: Farha, this is Mark Belgya. I think the expectation those are 3 big areas that we would continue to invest and expect to grow. Now will this be as additive as they were this year? That will be determined. We're also, as normal course is, we're going to continue to introduce new products. And I think the other one I would add to that is Milk-Bone just through the innovation and Barry's comments around the strength of snack and how important that is to us.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Bustelo, Bustelo has double-digit growth, small but double-digit growth.
componenttext: And Bustelo, Bustelo has double-digit growth, small but double-digit growth.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's the advantage of having a broad portfolio and the size and scale that the company had and adding another growth leg is that the innovation funnel is balanced over time and there'll be a lot of work going forward to make sure that we always
componenttext: I think that's the advantage of having a broad portfolio and the size and scale that the company had and adding another growth leg is that the innovation funnel is balanced over time and there'll be a lot of work going forward to make sure that we always have something coming down the funnel and that we've talked with customers and have good plans in place so that we constantly refresh that. But there will, obviously, continue to be certain brands, Folgers, Dunkin', Milk-Bone, Jif, et cetera that we're going to focus that innovation against because they are the brands that have the shoulders to take that kind of innovation. But I think, there'll always be something in the funnel on a forward basis, and that's just part of having the resources that the company have.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Robert Moskow with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question is from Robert Moskow with Crédit Suisse.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Farha, kind of asked my question I had, but if you think about the mathematics for next year to get t the 10% EPS growth, if I strip out the benefit of the synergies and the dilution, I think I'm getting to kind of a flattish EPS growth for the b
componenttext: I think, Farha, kind of asked my question I had, but if you think about the mathematics for next year to get t the 10% EPS growth, if I strip out the benefit of the synergies and the dilution, I think I'm getting to kind of a flattish EPS growth for the base business and you can check my math on that, if you like. And I think that in a normal year, I would call that conservative. But there are tougher comparisons in fiscal '17. And I appreciate the comments to grow Natural Balance and Duncans K-Cups and Uncrustables. But I think we've all been in that situation where you have -- what had been a great launch in the first year ends up being a tougher comp in the second year. So I guess, is there something you could tell me little bit more about what's going to drive the growth in those businesses while maintaining kind of the core, kind of flattish basis? Is a distribution, is it advertising? What is it that keeps those growing?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Richard. Just -- and Dave mentioned it also, just the fact that we have a much broader portfolio we've never had before. We've got more initiatives in place and a more new product initiatives in place we've never had before. We also have, we still
componenttext: This is Richard. Just -- and Dave mentioned it also, just the fact that we have a much broader portfolio we've never had before. We've got more initiatives in place and a more new product initiatives in place we've never had before. We also have, we still want to drive our shared market reach for our existing brands. And the fact our go-to-market strategy and the sales and marketing teams that we put together are much more robust than we've ever had before. So we would expect basically to call each one of those levers and no one is going to drive the growth, but if you combine them all together, we can each get a little bit out of each one, which is our plan, we're going to see reasonable growth. Now we're in categories that we think are -- resonate well with the consumer today. And so we think that we're going to have some reasonable baseline growth in addition, with new product growth. But it's a challenged market out there, but we think we're well positioned and probably better position than most CPG companies to see that growth.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016

componenttext: If I can comment. This is Steve Oakland in the Coffee business. If you look at the results that we're posting this year, we got strong momentum on our base business. I went through some of these earlier. We think that what we can see should maintain we think there's some opportunity. Remember, our first quarter wasn't as strong as the back 9 months has been. We think that the green premium green we don't  usually get into this, but different streams of green come in at different times of the year, so we think there's going to be some tailwind for our Dunkin' business for next year, and we have to make that grow. Our Dunkin' business has the opportunity to get its momentum back underneath it and what we're talking about is Folgers K-Cups. So we don't think the powers all the spent on the Coffee business. We think there's some opportunities to repeat what we've done. The largest retailer in the country did not take down Dunkin' K-Cups out of the gate, they're there now. So that will be a little bit of tailwind. So we feel good about the Coffee segment even following the kind of numbers that we've shown you this year.

componenttext: Can I ask a follow-up to Mark Belgya? Is my math just about right, Mark, that if I drop all those synergies to bottom line and then take out the dilution from canned milk, it kind of implies a core EPS, maybe up 1% or something like that?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that would be about right. I think you're probably using roughly $100 million for the synergy number, which is about $0.55, $0.60 probably, and that sounds about right. Rob, the only other thing I would add is right now where we add in our planning p
componenttext: Yes, that would be about right. I think you're probably using roughly $100 million for the synergy number, which is about $0.55, $0.60 probably, and that sounds about right. Rob, the only other thing I would add is right now where we add in our planning process and our synergy recognition, we feel comfortable with $100 million incremental for '17. But I think just on the base business from a cost and budgeting spend, again, while we've done some of the aggressive things that some of our peers have done. We still put changes pressure on budget management just the normal course. So whether you call the synergies or not, think that recognizing what you just suggesting in terms of these growth, we just got to continue to try to push cost from a budget perspective. So we're drove the the door now and hope that will contribute as well for '17.

componenttext: This is Vince Byrd. The short answer is not driven by the under performance of the business. It's 2 areas that we have been realize a little quicker than we had anticipated in the administrative and operational areas and then also some direct materials. We made some choices about ingredients and other things that increased our synergy target from $25 million to $35 million.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we made a statement earlier that we are committed to grow the K-Cup business and I think we've done this this year. I think it's a testament to that relationship so far. We are having the kind of dialogue to candidly discuss what we've got to do w
componenttext: I think we made a statement earlier that we are committed to grow the K-Cup business and I think we've done this this year. I think it's a testament to that relationship so far. We are having the kind of dialogue to candidly discuss what we've got to do with the leadership of Keurig. We can't look into what happened in the future. I mean, we need that. Once the transaction closes, there's nothing that they said or done to date that would suggest that we won't together on those opportunities. We have to be position to grow the business. I mean the consumer has spoken the 1 K-Cups, and so we're committed to be there and to date, I think we've been with the right partner.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next is Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next is Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to try with 2 follow ups with pet business. First, you mentioned that you're considering all levers to improve performance in the mainstream dry dog business and I know it's hard to talk perspective me about promotion. But from innovation or
componenttext: I just wanted to try with 2 follow ups with pet business. First, you mentioned that you're considering all levers to improve performance in the mainstream dry dog business and I know it's hard to talk perspective me about promotion. But from innovation or brand building standpoint, how the brand is marketed or positioned, are there any specific steps you're taking or thoughts you can share on how you might look to revitalize that? And in general terms, are you thinking about the urgency of potential timing of taking some of those actions?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as Richard mentioned and I think it's good thing to always pause and think about how quickly to turn the business where you plan to lead long customers to 9 to 12 months out, particularly in a business that tends to be everyday low price and not a
componenttext: I think as Richard mentioned and I think it's good thing to always pause and think about how quickly to turn the business where you plan to lead long customers to 9 to 12 months out, particularly in a business that tends to be everyday low price and not a high low business, so it's much more base than it is promotion. It's much more difficult to move those types of businesses. So in the dry dog food business, in the mass channel is a business that is much more ESLP and plan with big one customers. So we are looking at all levers, so we're looking at pricing, we're looking at product packaging, we're looking at other opportunities to innovate in the business, not just in the Kibbles 'n Bits brands but across our entire mass dog food business. So we're looking at all the levers. I think what in the short-term, the "easiest"  lever to pull is always pricing promotion. It's not generally the smartest one to pull because when you talk about poor trade spending, poor IRI, the trade spend is deployed on a short-term basis generally doesn't have great ROI because you don't get the kind of merchandising, your lift force that you would expect. So I think we've looked at all of those things as I mentioned from a profitability standpoint when we had our Investor Day, the areas of focus for growth for the pet business were around pet snacks, dog snacks and cat snacks, around the premium business and particularly, Natural Balance and the expansion of Natural Balance and then also focus in our cat business, our Meow Mix business, which is our largest brand in the pet portfolio and innovation that we have coming on that brand next year. So the role of the dry dog food business and mass has not been one of growth that has been one of profit maintenance, and that's the role we've taken our margins are up for the year. Our gross margins are up, that's the role of portfolio. As Barry said, we've looked at what we're doing. I don't want to get into specifics. I don't  think I want to be forecasting or projecting into the marketplace longer to do, but we are looking at all levers, and you will see some changes in terms of how we're going to market across the portfolio. But as I said, we're disappointed with those kind of results. But overall, when I look strategically across the 3 growth levers that we talked about when we had our Investor Day back in October, we're hitting on those 3 levers and this was not going to be a huge area of focus for growth for us. Unfortunately, right now, it's down significantly, and we'll take steps that we need to fix it.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, we'll wait to hear more there. And then just on Natural Balance and Pet Specialty, obviously, business is growing high single digit overall, double digits. Can you give us any sense of what that implies from a market share standpoint in the channel
componenttext: Okay, we'll wait to hear more there. And then just on Natural Balance and Pet Specialty, obviously, business is growing high single digit overall, double digits. Can you give us any sense of what that implies from a market share standpoint in the channel of the Natural category? Are there any metrics you can give us in terms of repeat purchase behavior at PetSmart or any of those sort of metrics that you be tracking at this stage and expansion?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're tracking our velocity on a weekly basis. We are also doing consumer research to track trial and repeat and repeat repeaters. So we're tracking what we would expect in any normal launch. We're looking answers and volume, we're looking at incrementali
componenttext: We're tracking our velocity on a weekly basis. We are also doing consumer research to track trial and repeat and repeat repeaters. So we're tracking what we would expect in any normal launch. We're looking answers and volume, we're looking at incrementality and incrementality to the category, incrementality to the brand. So we're looking at all those things. We evaluated weekly, and I'm not going to get into specific numbers with you. We're pleased with where we are, Petco, PetSmart and the Pet Specialty channel, in general, has been a little bit slower this year overall. And that, obviously, affected not only probably our business, but the category growth rates in general. But like I said, I'm pleased with where we are in the business. We've got the kind of launch support that we needed and will also been able to continue to get support from the retailers who we had a distribution would for a long time. So pleased with it overall. I don't know that -- when you see market share, it's not all inclusive, so there's -- we have better visibility, into better data that I'm not prepared to share.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Luby filling in for Akshay. I wanted to ask a question on your advertising spending. So you guys have increased advertising spending across a number of your businesses this year. And I think some of that will carry into next year. So can you just
componenttext: This is Luby filling in for Akshay. I wanted to ask a question on your advertising spending. So you guys have increased advertising spending across a number of your businesses this year. And I think some of that will carry into next year. So can you just talk a little bit about what your internal analytics are telling about effectiveness or returns on those programs? So are you generally encouraged by what you're seeing? And then maybe if you could just touch a little bit on these advertising mix so digital versus traditional media, et cetera. That will be helpful.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me kick that one, I'll start on Pets because we are up significantly year-on-year, particularly in the third quarter when you look at our segment profit in the third quarter. We're supporting Milk-Bone, the Milk-Bone brand, we're supporting Meow Mix I
componenttext: Let me kick that one, I'll start on Pets because we are up significantly year-on-year, particularly in the third quarter when you look at our segment profit in the third quarter. We're supporting Milk-Bone, the Milk-Bone brand, we're supporting Meow Mix Irresistible Cat Snacks, and we're also supporting the Natural Balance brand as we expanded our distribution footprint. I think those 3 initiatives are really against trial and awareness and building, so the ROI on them initially is a tough to measure because you're trying to get to trial and repeat. So I'm not sure that the economic effectiveness of it measuring it in the first quarter, at the end of 6 months that it's the same true on Dunkin' K-Cups and Jif Peanut Butter bars and the number of other things where we're going to advertise new items. It's part of launching a new item with the quality way you try to stock your marketing so that you'll get merchandising as well as an attractive price point plus consumer awareness. So a lot of the marketing that you're seeing from us is a geared towards that, across the portfolio. And then the other area where I think it's more difficult for the industry in general to measure is an investment in digital. And we're trying to make sure that we invest in first party data and first party relationships with consumers. We want to reach them wherever they are and want to make sure that we are on their path to purchase. So whether it's free shop or in-store as they're making decisions, we are focused on building a digital network and a digital ecosystem that reaches them there. So there's some infrastructure building there as well. Overall, I think we continue to look at the ROI and I think will fine-tune them as we go along. But I think is the right thing to do with the brands that we have to support them the way we're supporting them.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mark Smucker. I'll just add to that. As Dave said, there's a lot of advertising being spent, particularly we had on, what we would call initiatives. So if you think about the 2 buckets of advertising, it's equity support and initiative. And s
componenttext: Yes, this is Mark Smucker. I'll just add to that. As Dave said, there's a lot of advertising being spent, particularly we had on, what we would call initiatives. So if you think about the 2 buckets of advertising, it's equity support and initiative. And so while a lot of it you're seeing on pet is more on new products initiatives versus Smucker's we're on there with a new ad that is strictly focused on equity. And so again -- but in either case, they're relatively difficult to manage or measure, I should say, and so just trying to get the ROI on those isn't the quarterly exercise, it's more like a 12-month exercise. But we do feel that obviously supporting our brand is very important, and we're going to continue to do that, but I think that's it.

componenttext: The only thing I've mentioned at CAGNY is we now have about 25% of our media spend is in digital. Switches up if you read a couple of years ago, it's less than 10%> So we're moving in that area, but as Dave said, it's not easy to measure, so we're trying to do it judiciously, and that's why we measure where we can.

componenttext: That's very helpful. And then up I apologize if you touched on this already. headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mark Belgya. I think it's pretty consistent with what we said last week at CAGNY, I don't see any specific change. So if you just think of it in terms of round numbers of about $1 billion in free cash flow, about 1/4 of that is going to go to
componenttext: Yes, this is Mark Belgya. I think it's pretty consistent with what we said last week at CAGNY, I don't see any specific change. So if you just think of it in terms of round numbers of about $1 billion in free cash flow, about 1/4 of that is going to go to dividends. We're going to target about $400 million to $500 million in debt repayment and embedded in that $1 billion of free cash flow is about, call it, $0.25 billion of CapEx. So I think we'll see that. The only other thing I would bring out to that is, we mentioned earlier is just share repurchases would fall into that. That may cause us to be borrow a bit to do such, but I think generally speaking, I would just hold to our cash deployment model. We talked about really acquisition was announced a year ago.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
