componenttext: I just wanted to ask in your slides, you would outline a couple of factors that would be some headwinds heading into 2017. One of those was FX and other one is the milk divestiture. So I was wondering if you could give us some sense of what the incremental drag from the divestiture of milk is and the current rates FX is an additional, I don't  know, $0.05, $0.06, $0.07 of EPS headwind?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So Bryan, we'll get into this a little bit more in our fourth quarter earnings call, but in terms of the milk, that's probably, I'd say a $0.10 to $0.15 impact of contribution. Again, just everyone is clear, that's the milk contribution we're allud
componenttext: Right. So Bryan, we'll get into this a little bit more in our fourth quarter earnings call, but in terms of the milk, that's probably, I'd say a $0.10 to $0.15 impact of contribution. Again, just everyone is clear, that's the milk contribution we're alluding at, nothing to do with the gain of $0.14 we recognized, but roughly that. FX is we're still kind of working to do that, but that's going to still be a pretty significant impact. I mean, we're thinking that's well over $20 million next year. If you look at what the exchange rate have done even to sort of average in this year, it's falling well below $0.70 for a while. So I would get at least $20 million, probably north of that.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016

componenttext: So just a couple quick questions. I guess, first more broadly this has been touched on a little bit I just want to a bit more clarification. So the marketing spend was up in consumer. Volume still pressure, touch coming in below plan in year 1. So again if we think about fiscal '17 and have into cost synergies, how should we be also thinking about potential for incremental needs of reinvestment to support the brand? That's one. And then two, how should we be thinking about the 3- to 4-year growth targets you set out on a segment basis top line back in October?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: To the latter point, I don't think there's any significant changes in the growth rate assumptions that we laid out by the business unit that ultimately got us to 4% to 5% overall company rate. I think we spent probably enough time talking about how we thi
componenttext: To the latter point, I don't think there's any significant changes in the growth rate assumptions that we laid out by the business unit that ultimately got us to 4% to 5% overall company rate. I think we spent probably enough time talking about how we think we're going to deliver those, so our expectations by that time period will figure the dry dog out, and we'll be where we are. In terms of the dollar investment and guys, jump in here. We would continue to invest as we were. I think we said earlier on our call, our marketing spend while it's up significantly, it quite came returning to more historical levels. So we don't see that at least year-over-year as another significant incremental jump in marketing as we would a pretty good run rate. So I don't think you got to be too concerned about that being a big headwind going into it. And then, again, we're kind of moving to our planning process for '17, but the expectations is for all things you've heard today where we're trying to build the business, we would expect to see some benefits out of that and trying to hit sort of our normal growth rate for those business units.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up in terms of underperforming brands and potential for divestment that we saw in the canned milk business. How is your perspective on further divestment changed? Is it the same are you actively looking at your ba
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up in terms of underperforming brands and potential for divestment that we saw in the canned milk business. How is your perspective on further divestment changed? Is it the same are you actively looking at your baking business or oils, what have you? And I just asked because obviously it's been longer -- there's been longer term pressure in some of these brands and obviously, they generate some cash flow. But for thinking margin benefits relative or sorry price mix benefit and growth potential going forward and potential benefit of accelerated deleverage, if you do divest those, like why not divest them?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, you just listed all the criteria that we look at in terms of evaluating our portfolio so those are the things that we do look. We look at our portfolio on a regular basis. We actually think, for the most part, we have a good portfolio right now. And
componenttext: Rob, you just listed all the criteria that we look at in terms of evaluating our portfolio so those are the things that we do look. We look at our portfolio on a regular basis. We actually think, for the most part, we have a good portfolio right now. And it would be -- it doesn't mean we're not going to look at something to divest the small plan here and there, but it would be -- I don't see anything in the future in the next year or so.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, this is Mark Belgya. I guess maybe one thing that I would point  that and actually tied to a question to Kevin asked earlier and a little bit of question which was asked in terms of growth rates business unit. But one thing I would say it we have do
componenttext: Mark, this is Mark Belgya. I guess maybe one thing that I would point  that and actually tied to a question to Kevin asked earlier and a little bit of question which was asked in terms of growth rates business unit. But one thing I would say it we have done is our portfolio, just number brands have expanded. We continue to think about what role our brands play. So where in the pet, I don't want to say this is a not a categorical statement, everything, we do expect to grow evenly, but I do think we are setting different expectations on the brand is somewhat indicated by the growth rates that we put for the 4 business units. So I think that will just continue maturation of how we look at the businesses. And if it makes sense overtime, is there of brand or brands that fall out of favor I think in the process it will surface. But I agree with Richard, I think we feel pretty good about what we have, we have [indiscernible] to work on. But for now, they're fairly positive cash-generating businesses. It will be a little tough to -- to be quite honest, to fill the dilution if we sold them.

componenttextpreview: Yes. John, this is, obviously, Mark. Right now and it goes a little bit back to this conversation we had, right now, we're investment mode. So some of the products that Mark mentioned under the Pillsbury, the Smucker's brands, were clearly, whether it's s
componenttext: Yes. John, this is, obviously, Mark. Right now and it goes a little bit back to this conversation we had, right now, we're investment mode. So some of the products that Mark mentioned under the Pillsbury, the Smucker's brands, were clearly, whether it's spending with the trade or intro in terms of advertising, those are negatively affected, both topline and profitability. But if you think of commentary we've said in the past, we expect over time for our innovation to be mixed positive. We're looking for bigger range and bigger margin item. So once we get through that first couple years of intro period, we would expect that the comparable products would be adding margin greater than the more traditional ones. For example, cake. We expect our [indiscernible] simple ingredient product to be more profitable overtime.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is Mark Smucker. I would just add that Smucker's Natural Fruit Spreads, Smucker's Fruit and Honey as Mark just pointed out clearly simple, all of those products, which have possibly slightly higher ingredients costs, we're able to command a premi
componenttext: And this is Mark Smucker. I would just add that Smucker's Natural Fruit Spreads, Smucker's Fruit and Honey as Mark just pointed out clearly simple, all of those products, which have possibly slightly higher ingredients costs, we're able to command a premium for those in the consumer by offering variety that consumer that wants those products, will choose those products. But actually because we've seen growth there, it does validate the fact that the consumer is willing to choose with their pocketbook.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. componenttextpreview: Yes, actually, I think if you look at it in the Big Heart business that number we presented to you actually will be higher. We've done some innovation around the Milk-Bone brand, Milk-Bone Brushing Chews, the Milo’s Kitchen brand and some innovation we
componenttext: Yes, actually, I think if you look at it in the Big Heart business that number we presented to you actually will be higher. We've done some innovation around the Milk-Bone brand, Milk-Bone Brushing Chews, the Milo’s Kitchen brand and some innovation we did in the Natural Meat Snacks segment. We've done some inter dynamic brands. Pet has had more innovation historically and then in Pet Specialty, there's a natural amount of innovation that just occurs every year. And I think it's almost an expectation or anti to compete in the category. So pets probably a little bit higher than that on average.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I'll just add to that in the sense that each one of our businesses does have a target in terms of innovation. And what we expect the growth rate to be from innovation, and it really does depend upon each of those categories and where we think inno
componenttext: I think I'll just add to that in the sense that each one of our businesses does have a target in terms of innovation. And what we expect the growth rate to be from innovation, and it really does depend upon each of those categories and where we think innovation really drives the category. So although, Dave, I'm not prepared to share those numbers, each one of them has a target to go for and each manager has an obligation to hit those targets. It's still into their bonuses and the performance. So we look at that all the time. So thanks for the question.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
