headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: JAB. I think we made a statement earlier that we're committed to grow the K-Cup business, and I think we've done that this year. I think it's a testament to that relationship so far. We are having the kind of dialogue to candidly discuss what we've got to
componenttext: JAB. I think we made a statement earlier that we're committed to grow the K-Cup business, and I think we've done that this year. I think it's a testament to that relationship so far. We are having the kind of dialogue to candidly discuss what we've got to do with the leadership of Keurig. We can't look into what will happen in the future. I mean, we need that -- once that transaction closes, there's nothing they've said or done to date that would suggest that we won't work together on those opportunities. But we have to be positioned to grow that business. I mean, the consumer has spoken. They want K-Cups, and so we're committed to be there. And to date, I think we've been with the right partner.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next is Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next is Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to try with 2 follow ups on the Pet business. First, you mentioned that you're considering all levers to improve performance in the mainstream dry dog business, and I know it's hard to talk perspectively about promotion. But from an innovati
componenttext: I just wanted to try with 2 follow ups on the Pet business. First, you mentioned that you're considering all levers to improve performance in the mainstream dry dog business, and I know it's hard to talk perspectively about promotion. But from an innovation or brand building standpoint, how the brand is marketed or positioned, are there any specific steps you're taking or thoughts you can share on how you might look to revitalize that? And in general terms, how are you thinking about the urgency or potential timing of taking some of those actions?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Richard mentioned and I think it's a good thing to always pause and think about how quickly can you turn a business where you've planned the long-lead customers for 9 to 12 months out and particularly, in a business that tends to be every day low
componenttext: I think Richard mentioned and I think it's a good thing to always pause and think about how quickly can you turn a business where you've planned the long-lead customers for 9 to 12 months out and particularly, in a business that tends to be every day low price and not high -- and not a Hi-Lo business, so it's much more base than it is promotion. It's much more difficult to move those types of businesses. So and the dry dog food business in the mass channel is a business that is much more EDLP and planned with some big long-lead customers. So we are looking at all levers, so we're looking at pricing, we're looking at product packaging, we're looking at other opportunities to innovate in the business, not just in the Kibbles 'n Bits brand but across our entire mass dog food business. So we're looking at all the levers. I think what -- in the short-term, the "easiest" lever to pull is always pricing promotion. It's not generally the smartest one to pull because when you talk about poor trade spending, poor ROI, the trade spend that's deployed on a short-term basis generally doesn't have great ROI because you don't get the kind of merchandising [indiscernible] that you would expect. So I think we've looked at all of those things, as I mentioned, from a profitability standpoint. When we had our Investor Day, the areas of focus for growth for the pet business were around pet snacks, dog snacks and cat snacks, around the premium business and particularly, Natural Balance and the expansion of Natural Balance and then also focused on our cat business, our Meow Mix business, which is our largest brand in the pet portfolio and innovation that we have coming on that brand next year. So the role of the dry dog food business en masse has not been one of growth. It has been one of profit maintenance, and now that's the role we've taken with -- our margins are up for the year. Our gross margins are up, that's the role of portfolio. As Barry said, we've looked at what we're doing. I don't want to get into specifics. I don't think I want to be forecasting or projecting into the marketplace. What I'm going to do -- but we are looking at all levers, and you will see some changes in terms of how we're going to market across the portfolio. But as I said, yes, we're disappointed with those kind of results. But overall, when I look strategically across the 3 growth levers that we talked about when we had our Investor Day back in October, we're hitting on those 3 levers and this is -- was not going to be a huge area of focus for growth for us. Unfortunately, right now, it's down significantly, and we'll take the steps that we need to fix it.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, we'll wait to hear more there. And then just on Natural Balance and Pet specialty, obviously, business is growing high single digit overall, double digits. Can you give us any sense of what that implies from a market share standpoint in the channel
componenttext: Okay, we'll wait to hear more there. And then just on Natural Balance and Pet specialty, obviously, business is growing high single digit overall, double digits. Can you give us any sense of what that implies from a market share standpoint in the channel of the Natural category? And are there any metrics you can give us in terms of repeat purchase behavior at PetSmart or any of those sort of metrics that you'd be tracking at this stage in the expansion?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're tracking our velocity on a weekly basis. We are also doing consumer research to track trial and repeat and repeat repeaters. So we're tracking what you would expect in any normal launch. We're looking at source of volume, we're looking at incrementa
componenttext: We're tracking our velocity on a weekly basis. We are also doing consumer research to track trial and repeat and repeat repeaters. So we're tracking what you would expect in any normal launch. We're looking at source of volume, we're looking at incremental-ity and incremental-ity to the category, incremental-ity to the brand. So we're looking at all of those things that -- and we evaluate it weekly, and I'm not going to get into the specific numbers with you. We're pleased with where we are, Petco, PetSmart and the Pet Specialty channel, in general, has been a little bit slower this year overall. And that's, obviously, affected not only probably our business, but the category growth rates in general. But like I said, I'm pleased with where we are in the business. We've gotten the kind of launch support that we needed, and we've also been able to continue to get support from the retailers who we've had distribution with for a long time. So pleased with it overall. I don't know that -- when you see market share, it's not all inclusive, so there's -- we have a better visibility into -- but it's data that I'm not prepared to share.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Lubi filling in for Akshay. I wanted to ask a question on your advertising spending. So you guys have increased advertising spending across a number of your businesses this year. And I think some of that will carry into next year. So can you just
componenttext: This is Lubi filling in for Akshay. I wanted to ask a question on your advertising spending. So you guys have increased advertising spending across a number of your businesses this year. And I think some of that will carry into next year. So can you just talk a little bit about what your internal analytics are telling you about the effectiveness or returns on those programs? So are you generally encouraged by what you're seeing? And then maybe if you could just touch a little bit on these advertising mix so digital versus traditional media, et cetera. That will be helpful.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take a kick at that one. This is Dave West. I'll start on Pets because we are up significantly year-on-year, particularly in the third quarter when you look at our segment profit in the third quarter. We're supporting Milk-Bone, the Milk-Bone brand
componenttext: Let me take a kick at that one. This is Dave West. I'll start on Pets because we are up significantly year-on-year, particularly in the third quarter when you look at our segment profit in the third quarter. We're supporting Milk-Bone, the Milk-Bone brand, we're supporting Meow Mix Irresistibles Cat Snacks, and we're also supporting the Natural Balance brand as we expanded our distribution footprint. I think those 3 initiatives are really against trial and awareness and building, so the ROI on them is initially is tough to measure because you're trying to get to trial and repeat. So I'm not sure that the economic effectiveness of it measuring it in the first quarter at the end of the first 6 months that it's staying the same, it's going to be true on Dunkin' K-Cups and Jif Peanut Butter bars and the number of the other things where we're going to advertise new items. It's part of launching a new item with a quality way is that you try to stack your marketing so that you get merchandising as well as an attractive price point plus consumer awareness. So a lot of the marketing that you're seeing from us is geared towards that across the portfolio. And then the other area where I think it's more difficult for the industry in general to measure is an investment in digital. And we're trying to make sure that we invest in first party data and first party relationships with consumers. We want to reach them wherever they are, and we want to make sure that we're in -- on their path to purchase. So whether it's free shop or in-store as they're making decisions, we are focused on building a digital network and a digital ecosystem that reaches them there. So there's some infrastructure building there as well. Overall, I think we continue to look at our ROIs, and I think we'll fine-tune them as we go along. But I think it's the right thing to do with the brands that we have to support them the way we're supporting them.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mark Smucker. I'll just add to that. As Dave said, there's a lot of advertising being spent, particularly we had on, what we would call initiatives So if you think about the 2 buckets of advertising, it's me -- it's equity support and initiat
componenttext: Yes, this is Mark Smucker. I'll just add to that. As Dave said, there's a lot of advertising being spent, particularly we had on, what we would call initiatives So if you think about the 2 buckets of advertising, it's me -- it's equity support and initiative. And so while a lot of it you're seeing in the Pet is more on new product initiatives versus Smucker's we're on air with the new ad that is strictly focused on equity. And so again -- but in either case, they're relatively difficult to manage or measure, I should say, and so just trying to get the ROI on those isn't a quarterly exercise. It's more like a 12-month exercise. So -- but we do feel that obviously supporting our brand is very important, and we're going to continue to do that, but I think that's it.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. I don't think we mentioned the CAGNY as we now have bought 25% of our media now spend is in digital. Switch is up if you read it a couple of years ago, it's less than 10%. So we're moving in that area, but as Dave said, it's not easy to measure
componenttext: Thank you. I don't think we mentioned the CAGNY as we now have bought 25% of our media now spend is in digital. Switch is up if you read it a couple of years ago, it's less than 10%. So we're moving in that area, but as Dave said, it's not easy to measure, so we're trying to do it judiciously, and then try to measure it where we can.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then apologies if you touched on this already. But -- and I know you're not providing specific guidance for 2017 just yet, but could you just talk maybe high-level about how you're thinking about cash allocation for fiscal '17 bec
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then apologies if you touched on this already. But -- and I know you're not providing specific guidance for 2017 just yet, but could you just talk maybe high-level about how you're thinking about cash allocation for fiscal '17 because obviously, cash flow generation remains strong? So just some thoughts on that would be helpful.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mark Belgya. I think it's pretty consistent with what we said last week at CAGNY, I don't see any specific change. So if you just think of it in terms of round numbers of about $1 billion in free cash flow, about 1/4 of that is going to go to
componenttext: Yes, this is Mark Belgya. I think it's pretty consistent with what we said last week at CAGNY, I don't see any specific change. So if you just think of it in terms of round numbers of about $1 billion in free cash flow, about 1/4 of that is going to go to dividends. We're going to target about $400 million to $500 million in debt repayment and then embed it in $1 billion of free cash flow is about, call it, $0.25 billion of CapEx. So I think we'll see that. The only other thing I -- we would bring in to that is, we mentioned earlier, is just where share repurchases would fall into that. That may cause us to be -- to borrow a bit to do such, but I think generally speaking, I would just hold to our cash deployment model. We talked about really since the acquisition was announced a year ago.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Bryan Carlson with Tudor Investment Corp.
componenttext: And the next question is from Bryan Carlson with Tudor Investment Corp.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask in your slides, you would outline a couple of factors that would be sort of headwinds heading into 2017. One of those was FX and the other was the milk divestiture. I just wondered if you can give us some sense of what the incremental
componenttext: I just wanted to ask in your slides, you would outline a couple of factors that would be sort of headwinds heading into 2017. One of those was FX and the other was the milk divestiture. I just wondered if you can give us some sense of what the incremental drag from the divestiture of the milk is and the current rates FX is an additional, I don't know, $0.05, $0.06, $0.07 of EPS headwind?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So right, we'll get into this a little bit more in our fourth quarter earnings call, but in terms of the milk, that's probably, I'd say a $0.10 to $0.15 impact of contribution. Again, just so everyone's clear, that's the milk contribution we're allud
componenttext: Yes. So right, we'll get into this a little bit more in our fourth quarter earnings call, but in terms of the milk, that's probably, I'd say a $0.10 to $0.15 impact of contribution. Again, just so everyone's clear, that's the milk contribution we're alluding at, nothing to do with the gain of $0.14 we recognized, but roughly that. FX is -- we're still kind of working to that, but that's going to still be a pretty significant impact. I mean, we're thinking that's well over $20 million next year. If you look at what the exchange rate has done even if you sort of averaged in this year, it's falling well below $0.70 for a while. So I would get to at least $20 million, probably north of that.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Rob Dickerson with Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: The next question is from Rob Dickerson with Consumer Edge Research.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a couple of quick questions. I guess, first more broadly, this has been touched on a little bit. I just want a bit more clarification. So the marketing spend, obviously, was up in consumer. Volume's still pressured, touch [ph] coming in below plan
componenttext: So just a couple of quick questions. I guess, first more broadly, this has been touched on a little bit. I just want a bit more clarification. So the marketing spend, obviously, was up in consumer. Volume's still pressured, touch [ph] coming in below plan in year 1. So again if we think about fiscal '17 and have incremental cost synergies, how should we also be thinking about a potential for incremental needs of reinvestment to support the brands? That's one. And then two, how should we be thinking about the 3- to 4-year growth targets you set out on a segment basis top line back in October?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: To the latter point, I don't think there's any significant changes in the growth rate assumptions that we laid out by the business units that ultimately got us the 4% to 5% overall company rate. I think we spent probably enough time talking about how we t
componenttext: To the latter point, I don't think there's any significant changes in the growth rate assumptions that we laid out by the business units that ultimately got us the 4% to 5% overall company rate. I think we spent probably enough time talking about how we think we're going to deliver those, so our expectations by that time period will figure the dry dog out, and we'll be where we are. In terms of the dollar investment and guys, jump in here. We would continue to invest as we were. I think it was said earlier on our call, our marketing spend while it's up significantly, it quite keenly is returning to more historical levels. So we don't see that at least year-over-year as another significant incremental jump in marketing as we would consider this a pretty good run rate. So I don't think you got to be too concerned about that being a big headwind going into it. And then, again, we're kind of moving through our planning process for '17, but the expectations is for all the things you've heard today where we're trying to build the business, we would expect to see some benefits out of that and trying to hit sort of our normal growth rate for those business units.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up in terms of underperforming brands and potential for divestment that we saw in the canned milk business. How has your perspective on further divestment changed? Is it the same are you actively looking at your b
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up in terms of underperforming brands and potential for divestment that we saw in the canned milk business. How has your perspective on further divestment changed? Is it the same are you actively looking at your baking business or oils, what have you? And I just asked because, obviously, it's been longer. There's been some longer term pressure in some of these brands and obviously, they generate some cash flow. But for thinking margin mix benefit relative or -- sorry, price mix benefit and growth potential going forward and potential benefit of these accelerated deleverage, do you divest those? How like why not divest them?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, you just listed all the criteria that we look at continually in terms of evaluating our portfolio so those are the things that we do look at. We look at our portfolio on a regular basis. We actually think, for the most part, we have a good portfolio
componenttext: Rob, you just listed all the criteria that we look at continually in terms of evaluating our portfolio so those are the things that we do look at. We look at our portfolio on a regular basis. We actually think, for the most part, we have a good portfolio right now. And it would be -- it doesn't mean we're not going to look at something to divest the small brand here or there, but it would be -- I don't see anything in the future in the next year or so.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, this is Mark Belgya. I guess, maybe one thing that I would point to that and actually I think tied into a question, [indiscernible] who asked it earlier. But -- and a little bit to the question was just asked in terms of growth rates about business u
componenttext: Rob, this is Mark Belgya. I guess, maybe one thing that I would point to that and actually I think tied into a question, [indiscernible] who asked it earlier. But -- and a little bit to the question was just asked in terms of growth rates about business units. But one thing I would say that we have done is our portfolio, just number of brands have expanded and we continue to think about what role our brands play. So where in the past, I don't want to say this is a not a categorical statement, but everything we'd expect to grow evenly, but I do think we are setting different expectations on the brand is somewhat indicated by the growth rates that we've put for the 4 business units. So I think that will just continue -- the maturation of how we look at businesses than if it makes sense overtime, if there are brand or brands that fall out of favor, I think in that process it will surface. But I agree with Richard, I think we feel pretty good about what we have, we have some areas to work on. But for now, they're fairly positive cash-generating businesses that would be a little tough to -- quite honestly, would fill the dilution if we sold them.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next will be John Baumgartner with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Next will be John Baumgartner with Wells Fargo.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick question for Mark Belgya. I know -- I'd like to ask in terms of this renovation you're doing with the natural ingredients across your portfolio. Is there any notable drag on your margins that may be worth quantifying from the reinvestment into foo
componenttext: A quick question for Mark Belgya. I know -- I'd like to ask in terms of this renovation you're doing with the natural ingredients across your portfolio. Is there any notable drag on your margins that may be worth quantifying from the reinvestment into food quality?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. John, this is obviously Mark. Right now and again, it goes a little bit back to the -- some of the conversations we had. Right now, we're investment mode. So with some of the products that Mark mentioned under the Pillsbury and the Smucker's brands,
componenttext: Yes. John, this is obviously Mark. Right now and again, it goes a little bit back to the -- some of the conversations we had. Right now, we're investment mode. So with some of the products that Mark mentioned under the Pillsbury and the Smucker's brands, we're clearly, whether it's spending with the trade or the intro in terms of the advertising, those are negatively affecting, both topline and profitability. But if you think of commentary we've said in the past, we expect over time for our innovation to be mixed positive. We're looking for bigger range and bigger margin item. So once we get through that first couple years of intro period, we would expect that the comparable products would be adding margin greater than the more traditional ones. For example, cake. We expect our simple-ingredient product to be more profitable over time.

componenttext: On -- and this is Mark Smucker. I would just add that Smucker's Natural Fruit Spreads, Smucker's Fruit and Honey as Mark just pointed out, clearly simple, all of those products which have possibly slightly higher ingredient costs, we're able to command a premium for those in the consumer by offering variety. The consumer that wants those products will choose those products when we've actually because we've seen growth there, that does validate the fact that the consumer is willing to choose with their pocketbook.

Is there a way to isolate that contribution just for the Big Heart business and maybe where you see that going over time for Big Heart?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's actually, I think, you were guided in the Big Heart business that number we presented to you would actually be higher. We've done some innovation around the Milk-Bone brand, Milk-Bone Brushing Chews, the Milo’s Kitchen brand and some innovatio
componenttext: Yes, it's actually, I think, you were guided in the Big Heart business that number we presented to you would actually be higher. We've done some innovation around the Milk-Bone brand, Milk-Bone Brushing Chews, the Milo’s Kitchen brand and some innovation that we did in the natural meat snacks segment. We've done some things with the Meow Mix brand. So Pet has had more innovation historically, and then in Pet Specialty, there's a natural amount of innovation that just occurs every year. And I think it's almost an expectation or anti to compete in the category. So Pet's probably a little bit higher than that on average.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016

componenttext: I think I'll just add to that in the sense that each one of our businesses does have a target and in terms of innovation. And what we expect their growth rate to [indiscernible] be from innovation, and it really does depend upon each of those categories and where we think innovation really drives the category. So although -- like Dave, I'm not prepared to share those numbers, each one of them has a target to go for and each general manager has an obligation to hit those targets. It's built into their bonuses and the performance. So we look at that all the time. So thanks for the question.
