headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: JAB. I think we made a statement earlier that we're committed to grow the K-Cup business, and I think we've done that this year. I think it's a testament to that relationship so far. We are having the kind of dialogue to candidly discuss what we've got to
componenttext: JAB. I think we made a statement earlier that we're committed to grow the K-Cup business, and I think we've done that this year. I think it's a testament to that relationship so far. We are having the kind of dialogue to candidly discuss what we've got to do with the leadership of Keurig. We can't look into what will happen in the future. I mean, we need that -- once that transaction closes, there's nothing they've said or done to date that would suggest that we won't work together on those opportunities. But we have to be positioned to grow that business. I mean, the consumer has spoken. They want K-Cups, and so we're committed to be there. And to date, I think we've been with the right partner.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next is Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next is Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to try with 2 follow ups on the Pet business. First, you mentioned that you're considering all levers to improve performance in the mainstream dry dog business, and I know it's hard to talk prospectively about promotion. But from an innovati
componenttext: I just wanted to try with 2 follow ups on the Pet business. First, you mentioned that you're considering all levers to improve performance in the mainstream dry dog business, and I know it's hard to talk prospectively about promotion. But from an innovation or brand building standpoint, how the brand is marketed or positioned, are there any specific steps you're taking or thoughts you can share on how you might look to revitalize that? And in general terms, how are you thinking about the urgency or potential timing of taking some of those actions?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think Richard mentioned and I think it's a good thing to always pause and think about how quickly can you turn a business where you've planned the long-lead customers for 9 to 12 months out and particularly, in a business that tends to be everyday low p
componenttext: I think Richard mentioned and I think it's a good thing to always pause and think about how quickly can you turn a business where you've planned the long-lead customers for 9 to 12 months out and particularly, in a business that tends to be everyday low price and not high -- and not a Hi-Lo business, so it's much more base than it is promotion. It's much more difficult to move those types of businesses. So and the dry dog food business in the mass channel is a business that is much more EDLP and planned with some big long-lead customers. So we are looking at all levers, so we're looking at pricing, we're looking at product packaging, we're looking at other opportunities to innovate in the business, not just in the Kibbles 'n Bits brand but across our entire mass dog food business. So we're looking at all the levers. I think what -- in the short-term, the "easiest" lever to pull is always pricing promotion. It's not generally the smartest one to pull because when you talk about poor trade spend, poor ROI, the trade spend that's deployed on a short-term basis generally doesn't have great ROI because you don't get the kind of merchandising or lift for it that you would expect. So I think we've looked at all of those things, as I mentioned, from a profitability standpoint. When we had our Investor Day, the areas of focus for growth for the pet business were around pet snacks, dog snacks and cat snacks, around the premium business and particularly, Natural Balance and the expansion of Natural Balance and then also focused on our cat business, our Meow Mix business, which is our largest brand in the pet portfolio and innovation that we have coming on that brand next year. So the role of the dry dog food business en masse has not been one of growth. It has been one of profit maintenance, and now that's the role we've taken with -- our margins are up for the year. Our gross margins are up, that's the role of portfolio. As Barry said, we've looked at what we're doing. I don't want to get into specifics. I don't think I want to be forecasting or projecting into the marketplace what I'm going to do. But we are looking at all levers, and you will see some changes in terms of how we're going to market across the portfolio. But as I said, yes, we're disappointed with those kind of results. But overall, when I look strategically across the 3 growth levers that we talked about when we had our Investor Day back in October, we're hitting on those 3 levers and this is -- was not going to be a huge area of focus for growth for us. Unfortunately, right now, it's down significantly, and we'll take the steps that we need to fix it.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, we'll wait to hear more there. And then just on Natural Balance and Pet specialty, obviously, business is growing high single digit overall, double digits. Can you give us any sense of what that implies from a market share standpoint in the channel
componenttext: Okay, we'll wait to hear more there. And then just on Natural Balance and Pet specialty, obviously, business is growing high single digit overall, double digits. Can you give us any sense of what that implies from a market share standpoint in the channel of the Natural category? And are there any metrics you can give us in terms of repeat purchase behavior at PetSmart or any of those sort of metrics that you'd be tracking at this stage in the expansion?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're tracking our velocity on a weekly basis. We are also doing consumer research to track trial and repeat and repeat repeaters. So we're tracking what you would expect in any normal launch. We're looking at source of volume, we're looking at incrementa
componenttext: We're tracking our velocity on a weekly basis. We are also doing consumer research to track trial and repeat and repeat repeaters. So we're tracking what you would expect in any normal launch. We're looking at source of volume, we're looking at incremental-ity and incremental-ity to the category, incremental-ity to the brand. So we're looking at all of those things that -- and we evaluate it weekly, and I'm not going to get into the specific numbers with you. We're pleased with where we are, Petco, PetSmart and the Pet Specialty channel, in general, has been a little bit slower this year overall. And that's, obviously, affected not only probably our business, but the category growth rates in general. But as I said, I'm pleased with where we are in the business. We've gotten the kind of launch support that we needed, and we've also been able to continue to get support from the retailers who we've had distribution with for a long time. So pleased with it overall. I don't know that -- when you see market share, it's not all inclusive, so there's -- we have a better visibility into it, but it's data that I'm not prepared to share.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.
componenttext: The next question is from Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Lubi filling in for Akshay. I wanted to ask a question on your advertising spending. So you guys have increased advertising spending across a number of your businesses this year. And I think some of that will carry into next year. So can you just
componenttext: This is Lubi filling in for Akshay. I wanted to ask a question on your advertising spending. So you guys have increased advertising spending across a number of your businesses this year. And I think some of that will carry into next year. So can you just talk a little bit about what your internal analytics are telling you about the effectiveness or returns on those programs? So are you generally encouraged by what you're seeing? And then maybe if you could just touch a little bit on these advertising mix so digital versus traditional media, et cetera. That will be helpful.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take a kick at that one. This is Dave West. I'll start on Pets because we are up significantly year-on-year, particularly in the third quarter when you look at our segment profit in the third quarter. We're supporting Milk-Bone, the Milk-Bone brand
componenttext: Let me take a kick at that one. This is Dave West. I'll start on Pets because we are up significantly year-on-year, particularly in the third quarter when you look at our segment profit in the third quarter. We're supporting Milk-Bone, the Milk-Bone brand, we're supporting Meow Mix Irresistibles Cat Snacks, and we're also supporting the Natural Balance brand as we expanded our distribution footprint. I think those 3 initiatives are really against trial and awareness and building, so the ROI on them is initially is tough to measure because you're trying to get to trial and repeat. So I'm not sure that the economic effectiveness of it measuring it in the first quarter it’s in or the first 6 months that it's in. The same is going to be true on Dunkin' K-Cups and Jif Peanut Butter bars and the number of the other things where we're going to advertise new items. It's part of launching a new item with a quality way is that you try to stack your marketing so that you get merchandising as well as an attractive price point plus consumer awareness. So a lot of the marketing that you're seeing from us is geared towards that across the portfolio. And then the other area where I think it's more difficult for the industry in general to measure is an investment in digital. And we're trying to make sure that we invest in first-party data and first-party relationships with consumers. We want to reach them wherever they are, and we want to make sure that we're in -- on their path to purchase. So whether it's pre-shop or in-store as they're making decisions, we are focused on building a digital network and a digital ecosystem that reaches them there. So there's some infrastructure building there as well. Overall, I think we continue to look at our ROIs, and I think we'll fine-tune them as we go along. But I think it's the right thing to do with the brands that we have to support them the way we're supporting them.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mark Smucker. I'll just add to that. As Dave said, there's a lot of advertising being spent, particularly we had on, what we would call initiatives. So if you think about the 2 buckets of advertising, it's me -- it's equity support and initia
componenttext: Yes, this is Mark Smucker. I'll just add to that. As Dave said, there's a lot of advertising being spent, particularly we had on, what we would call initiatives. So if you think about the 2 buckets of advertising, it's me -- it's equity support and initiative. And so while a lot of it you're seeing in the Pet is more on new product initiatives versus Smucker's we're on air with the new ad that is strictly focused on equity. And so again -- but in either case, they're relatively difficult to manage or measure, I should say, and so just trying to get the ROI on those isn't a quarterly exercise. It's more like a 12-month exercise. So -- but we do feel that obviously supporting our brands is very important, and we're going to continue to do that, but I think that's it.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the other thing we mentioned at CAGNY is we now have about 25% of our media now spent is in digital. Which is up, if you read it a couple of years ago, it's less than 10%. So we're moving in that area, but as Dave said, it's not easy to measure, s
componenttext: I think the other thing we mentioned at CAGNY is we now have about 25% of our media now spent is in digital. Which is up, if you read it a couple of years ago, it's less than 10%. So we're moving in that area, but as Dave said, it's not easy to measure, so we're trying to do it judiciously, and then try to measure it where we can.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then apologies if you touched on this already. But -- and I know you're not providing specific guidance for 2017 just yet, but could you just talk maybe high level about how you're thinking about cash allocation for fiscal '17 bec
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then apologies if you touched on this already. But -- and I know you're not providing specific guidance for 2017 just yet, but could you just talk maybe high level about how you're thinking about cash allocation for fiscal '17 because obviously, cash flow generation remains strong? So just some thoughts on that would be helpful.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mark Belgya. I think it's pretty consistent with what we said last week at CAGNY, I don't see any specific change. So if you just think of it in terms of round numbers of about $1 billion in free cash flow, about 1/4 of that is going to go to
componenttext: Yes, this is Mark Belgya. I think it's pretty consistent with what we said last week at CAGNY, I don't see any specific change. So if you just think of it in terms of round numbers of about $1 billion in free cash flow, about 1/4 of that is going to go to dividends. We're going to target about $400 million to $500 million in debt repayment and then embedded in $1 billion of free cash flow is about, call it, $0.25 billion of CapEx. So I think we'll see that. The only other thing I -- we would bring in to that is, we mentioned earlier, is just where share repurchases would fall into that. That may cause us to be -- to borrow a bit to do such, but I think generally speaking, I would just hold to our cash deployment model we talked about really since the acquisition was announced a year ago.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Bryan Carlson with Tudor Investment Corp.
componenttext: And the next question is from Bryan Carlson with Tudor Investment Corp.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask in your slides, you had outlined a couple of factors that would be sort of headwinds heading into 2017. One of those was FX and the other was the milk divestiture. I just wondered if you can give us some sense of what the incremental
componenttext: I just wanted to ask in your slides, you had outlined a couple of factors that would be sort of headwinds heading into 2017. One of those was FX and the other was the milk divestiture. I just wondered if you can give us some sense of what the incremental drag from the divestiture of the milk is and the current rates FX is an additional, I don't know, $0.05, $0.06, $0.07 of EPS headwind?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So right, we'll get into this a little bit more in our fourth quarter earnings call, but in terms of the milk, that's probably, I'd say a $0.10 to $0.15 impact of contribution. Again, just so everyone's clear, that's the milk contribution we're allud
componenttext: Yes. So right, we'll get into this a little bit more in our fourth quarter earnings call, but in terms of the milk, that's probably, I'd say a $0.10 to $0.15 impact of contribution. Again, just so everyone's clear, that's the milk contribution we're alluding at, nothing to do with the gain of $0.14 we recognized, but roughly that. FX is -- we're still kind of working through that, but that's going to still be a pretty significant impact. I mean, we're thinking that's well over $20 million next year. If you look at what the exchange rate has done even if you sort of averaged in this year, it's fallen well below $0.70 for a while. So I would guess it’s at least $20 million, probably north of that.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Rob Dickerson with Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: The next question is from Rob Dickerson with Consumer Edge Research.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just a couple of quick questions. I guess, first more broadly, this has been touched on a little bit. I just want a bit more clarification. So the marketing spend, obviously, was up in consumer. Volume's still pressured, Pets coming in below plan in ye
componenttext: So just a couple of quick questions. I guess, first more broadly, this has been touched on a little bit. I just want a bit more clarification. So the marketing spend, obviously, was up in consumer. Volume's still pressured, Pets coming in below plan in year 1. So again if we think about fiscal '17 and have incremental cost synergies, how should we also be thinking about a potential for incremental needs of reinvestment to support the brands? That's one. And then two, how should we be thinking about the 3- to 4-year growth targets you set out on a segment basis top line back in October?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: To the latter point, I don't think there's any significant changes in the growth rate assumptions that we laid out by the business units that ultimately got us the 4% to 5% overall company rate. I think we spent probably enough time talking about how we t
componenttext: To the latter point, I don't think there's any significant changes in the growth rate assumptions that we laid out by the business units that ultimately got us the 4% to 5% overall company rate. I think we spent probably enough time talking about how we think we're going to deliver those, so our expectation is by that time period we’ll figure the dry dog out, and we'll be where we are. In terms of the dollar investment and guys, jump in here. We would continue to invest as we were. I think it was said earlier on our call, our marketing spend while it's up significantly, it quite candidly is returning to more historical levels. So we don't see that at least year-over-year as another significant incremental jump in marketing as we would consider this a pretty good run rate. So I don't think you got to be too concerned about that being a big headwind going into it. And then, again, we're kind of moving through our planning process for '17, but the expectations is for all the things you've heard today where we're trying to build the business, we would expect to see some benefits out of that and trying to hit sort of our normal growth rate for those business units.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up in terms of underperforming brands and potential for divestment that we saw in the canned milk business. How has your perspective on further divestment changed? Is it the same are you actively looking at your b
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up in terms of underperforming brands and potential for divestment that we saw in the canned milk business. How has your perspective on further divestment changed? Is it the same are you actively looking at your baking business or oils, what have you? And I just asked because, obviously, it's been longer. There's been some longer-term pressure in some of these brands and obviously, they generate some cash flow. But for thinking margin mix benefit relative or -- sorry, price mix benefit and growth potential going forward and potential benefit off these accelerated deleverage if do you divest those, how -- like why not divest them?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, you just listed all the criteria that we look at continually in terms of evaluating our portfolio so those are the things that we do look at. We look at our portfolio on a regular basis. We actually think, for the most part, we have a good portfolio
componenttext: Rob, you just listed all the criteria that we look at continually in terms of evaluating our portfolio so those are the things that we do look at. We look at our portfolio on a regular basis. We actually think, for the most part, we have a good portfolio right now. And it would be -- it doesn't mean we're not going to look at something to divest a small brand here or there, but it would be -- I don't see anything in the future in the next year or so.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, this is Mark Belgya. I guess, maybe one thing that I would point to that and actually I think ties into a question, I can’t recall who asked it earlier. But -- and a little bit to the question was just asked in terms of growth rates by business uni
componenttext: Rob, this is Mark Belgya. I guess, maybe one thing that I would point to that and actually I think ties into a question, I can’t recall who asked it earlier. But -- and a little bit to the question was just asked in terms of growth rates by business unit. But one thing I would say that we have done as our portfolio, just number of brands have expanded is we continue to think about what role our brands play. So where in the past, I don't want to say -- this is a not a categorical statement that everything would expect to grow evenly, but I do think we are setting different expectations on the brand as somewhat indicated by the growth rates that we've put for the 4 business units. So I think that will just continue -- the maturation of how we look at businesses. And if it makes sense over time, if there are brand or brands that fall out of favor, I think in that process it will surface. But I agree with Richard, I think we feel pretty good about what we have, we have some areas to work on. But for now, they're fairly positive cash-generating businesses that would be a little tough to -- quite honestly, would fill the dilution if we sold them.

componenttext: Yes. John, this is obviously Mark. Right now and again, it goes a little bit back to the -- some of the conversations we had. Right now, we're investment mode. So with some of the products that Mark mentioned under the Pillsbury and the Smucker's brands, we're clearly, whether it's spending with the trade or the intro in terms of the advertising, those are negatively affecting both top line and profitability. But if you think of commentary we've said in the past, we expect over time for our innovation to be mix positive. We're looking for bigger range and bigger margin item. So once we get through that first couple years of intro period, we would expect that the comparable products would be adding margin greater than the more traditional ones. For example, cake. We expect our simple-ingredient product to be more profitable over time.

I would just add that Smucker's Natural Fruit Spreads, Smucker's Fruit and Honey as Mark just pointed out, Purely Simple, all of those products which have possibly slightly higher ingredient costs, we're able to command a premium for those in the consumer by offering variety. The consumer that wants those products will choose those products when we've actually because we've seen growth there, that does validate the fact that the consumer is willing to choose with their pocketbook.

componenttext: Yes, it's actually, I think, you look at it in the Big Heart business that number we presented to you would actually be higher. We've done some things with the Meow Mix brand. So Pet has had more innovation historically, and then in Pet Specialty, there's a natural amount of innovation that just occurs every year. And I think it's almost an expectation or anti to compete in the category. So Pet's probably a little bit higher than that on average.

componenttext: I think I'll just add to that in the sense that each one of our businesses does have a target and in terms of innovation. It's built into their bonuses and their performance. So we look at that all the time. So thanks for the question.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to The J. M. Smucker Company's Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now turn the conference call over to Aaron Broholm, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our fourth quarter earnings conference call. With me today and presenting our prepared remarks are Richard Smucker, Executive Chairman; Mark Smucker, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Bel
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our fourth quarter earnings conference call. 
With me today and presenting our prepared remarks are Richard Smucker, Executive Chairman; Mark Smucker, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Belgya, Chief Financial Officer. 
Also joining us for the Q&A portion of the call are Steve Oakland, President, U.S. Food and Beverage; and Barry Dunaway, President, Pet Food and Pet Snacks. Vince Byrd, Vice Chairman, is also on the line from another location. 
During this conference call, we will make forward-looking statements that reflect the company's current expectations about future plans and performance. These statements rely on a number of assumptions and estimates, and actual results may differ materially due to risks and uncertainties. I encourage you to read the full disclosure statement in this morning's press release concerning forward-looking statements. 
Additionally, please note the company uses non-GAAP results for the purpose of evaluating performance internally as detailed in the press release, which is located on our corporate website at jmsmucker.com. 
As we indicated earlier in the calendar year, we are transitioning to one non-GAAP earnings per share metric in 2017, which excludes noncash intangible amortization. We will refer to this as adjusted EPS.  Amortization expense will also be removed from our definition of segment profits as well as non-GAAP operating income and net income. We will follow Form 8-K later this quarter to recast prior year's segment results to reflect the new definition. We have posted to our website a couple of supplementary slides, including a bridge from our fiscal 2016 results to our fiscal 2017 adjusted EPS guidance. These slides can be accessed through the link to the website of this call. This document and a replay of this call will be archived on our website. If you have any questions after today's call, please contact me. 
I will now turn the call over to Richard.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Aaron. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. Fiscal 2016 was a dynamic and exciting year for the Smucker company as our teams delivered on a number of key strategic initiatives. These included: Significantly improving the perf
componenttext:
Thank you, Aaron. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. 
Fiscal 2016 was a dynamic and exciting year for the Smucker company as our teams delivered on a number of key strategic initiatives. These included: Significantly improving the performance of our Coffee business; reflecting the launch of the Dunkin' Donuts K-Cups; and returning momentum to our mainstream Coffee business; expanding distribution for our Natural Balance pet brand; executing a seamless integration of the Pet Food business; exceeding our synergy and working capital targets for the year; divesting our U.S. Canned Milk business, all resulting in record financial performance and earnings and cash flow that exceeded our expectation. 
Let me expand on the results for the year. Net sales increased 37% to $7.8 billion, reflecting the full year contribution by the Big Heart pet brand. 
Excluding acquisitions, divestitures and foreign exchange, sales increased 3% for the full year. 
Non-GAAP operating income was up 49% to $1.28 million with the contributions from Pet and strong Coffee segment profit growth being the key drivers.  Non-GAAP earnings per share were $6.57, including a onetime $0.46 per share -- $0.42 per share noncash benefit. 
This compares to our most recent guidance of $5.84 to $5.94, which excluded the tax benefit. 
Lastly, the company generated free cash flow of $1.26 billion, which is well above our [indiscernible]. 
Reflecting the strong cash flow, we exceeded our deleveraging objective for the year, reducing total debt by nearly $750 million. 
We also returned over $750 million of cash to shareholders in the form of share repurchases and dividends. There are numerous accomplishments during the past fiscal year and this performance is a testament to the dedication of our employees, and we thank them for their continued effort. 
We are well positioned to continue this momentum into fiscal 2017. Since the last time we spoke to many of you, we announced several executive appointments that are consistent with the company's history of long-term succession planning and the development of leadership to meet the current and future needs of our business and the constituents that we serve. 
Effectively first, Mark Smucker assumed the role of President and Chief Executive Officer. Mark and his experienced leadership team embody the values that have attributed to the company's success and long-term growth. I am confident that under their direction, the company will continue to innovate the ball and grow in the years to come. 
It's been an honor to serve as CEO of the Smucker company, and I'm grateful to have worked alongside the most talented team in the industry. I will continue to serve the company as Executive Chairman. Among other areas, my efforts will be focused on board related matters, counsel and advice on strategic decisions, enhancing customer relationships and advancing our industry leadership efforts. 
My brother, Tim, has been appointed to the role of Chairman emeritus, and we also look forward to his continued contribution. 
Lastly, I would like to recognize Vince Byrd, who has participating in his final earnings call as his retirement after 39 years with the company is effective tomorrow. Vince's contributions have helped shape the company that we are today and will continue to be reflective in the numerous employees that he has mentored throughout his career. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Mark.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Richard. Good morning, everyone. As you know, our company is unique in being led by only 6 CEOs in its 119-year history. I am honored to succeed Richard as CEO and serve as CEO . Richard has led our company through a period of significant expan
componenttext:
Thank you, Richard. Good morning, everyone. As you know, our company is unique in being led by only 6 CEOs in its 119-year history. I am honored to succeed Richard as CEO and serve as CEO . Richard has led our company through a period of significant expansion and strategic transformation. As a result, our company is stronger than ever. I am excited to lead our talented team, leveraging the continued counsel of Richard, dad and our outstanding board to drive continued growth and shareholder value. 
I also would like to echo Richard's comment about Vince and thank him for his contribution and mentorship. 
The focus of my comment today will be to provide an update on our business segment, including additional color on full year 2016 performance and initial thoughts on fiscal 2017. 
I'll start with our Coffee business, which far exceeded expectations for the year. Net sales were up 8% and segment profit increased 18% to $646 million, representing a full recovery of the segment profit declined in the prior year. This outperformance was driven by several factors, including the successful launch of Dunkin' Donuts K-Cups, the implementation of the planned Folgers canister downsize, a moderation in competitive activities and the net benefit of lower commodity cost and pricing. 
Providing lower pricing on Folgers roast and ground coffee resulted in improved performance for our mainstream Coffee business in 2016. Tonnage for our mainstream brands was up 3%, while unit shift was up even more given the canister downsize early in the fiscal year. 
In addition, our dollar share within the mainstream segment of that Coffee category increased nearly 2 share points to 55% for the latest 52-week period. 
We anticipate momentum in the Coffee business to continue in 2017. Key initiatives include Folgers sponsorship of the U.S. Olympic team for the upcoming Rio games with marketing activities already underway. 
In addition, last month, we implemented a 6% list price decline across much of our coffee portfolio, reflecting sustained lower grain coffee cost. These lower cost have been reflected in promotional pricing for the past several quarters, and we do not anticipate promoted prices changing significantly. 
With regards to Folgers K-Cups, in 2016, the brand was impacted by the ongoing proliferation and entrance in the K-Cups space, including our introduction of Dunkin' K-Cups. 
This year, we will invest in the product line to improve trends, including lower pricing and new packaging that will leverage the iconic Folgers Red Can brand equity. 
Turning to the Dunkin' Donuts brand. Dunkin' K-Cups achieved nearly $220 million in retail sales for the latest 52-week scan period and gained a 6% dollar share of the K-Cup markets, giving us an overall share of nearly 15% in the K-Cup segment. 
In its first year on the market, the Dunkin' Donuts original SKU has become the #1 K-Cup item in the channels in which we participate. 
As consumer repeat rates remained strong and with opportunities to introduce additional varieties, we anticipate further growth in 2017. 
While challenge through much of 2016, performance improved for Dunkin' Donuts Ag coffee during the fourth quarter. Supported by favorable input cost, we have sharpened pricing to improve gaps to key competitors and we look for positive volume trends to continue. 
Lastly, within Coffee, the Café Bustelo brand experienced a second consecutive year of double-digit sales growth behind strong performance for both roast and ground and K-Cup offerings. This exciting on-trend brand remains well received by millennials, and its growth is expected to continue also in 2017. 
Turning to Consumer Foods. Net sales declined 3% for the year, mostly due to lapping sales from the divested canned and milk business. Segment profit was flat the prior year, supported by the gain on the milk business sales, which offset planned increases in manufacturing overhead costs. 
Looking briefly at the key brands. We are pleased with the overall performance of our spreads business as both Jif Peanut Butter and Smucker's Food Spreads grew volume share over the latest 52-week period. 
In addition, Smucker Uncrustables Frozen Sandwiches had another strong year with volume up 26%, including a 17 consecutive quarter of double-digit volume growth in this most recent fourth quarter. 
On-trend innovation continues to be a focus area for the iconic Jif and Smucker's brand. In fiscal 2017, we look to build on recent successful launches such as Smucker's Fruit and Honey Fruit Spreads and Jif Snack Bars. This includes the upcoming introduction of new snack bar varieties and plans to expand into other snacking platforms. 
In addition, Jif, Smucker's and Uncrustables are all participating in the 2016 Olympics partnership, which will be an integral part of this year's marketing efforts for the brand. 
In the bake aisle, the overall category remains challenged throughout much of this past year, reflecting changing consumer preferences and aggressive competitive pricing. Our focus remains on providing value-added innovation such as our recent gluten-free and simple ingredients offerings. 
We are also excited to announce a licensing arrangement with the Girl Scouts of America. Under this agreement, we are launching new Pillsbury items featuring iconic Girl Scouts cookie flavors. 
Within Natural Foods, our leading R.W. Knudsen family and Santa Cruz Organic brands both achieved solid sales growth in 2016. The key Natural Foods categories in which our brands participate are growing, which gives us confidence in maintaining our momentum in this business. 
We are also excited about our recent investment in the newbie brand and the opportunities this provides in the organic tea category. 
Under our first year of ownership, Pet Foods segment profit of $392 million was generally in line with expectations. Net sales of $2.25 billion fell 1% short of the projections provided at our October Investor Day due to competitive challenges in mainstream dry dog food. 
For the year, mainstream pet food sales decreased mid-single digits, reflecting double-digit declines in dog food and a low single digit decline for the larger cat food business. Offsetting the lower mainstream sales was the strong performance of our Pet Snacks business, which was up mid-single digits over the prior year and our premium pet food brands, which grew double digits behind expanded distribution of the Natural Balance brand. 
As we enter 2017, we anticipate continued growth for Natural Balance as we launch the brand's first national marketing campaign, along with additional in-store support. 
Within pet snacks, innovation for the Milk-Bone and Meow Mix brand for key contributors to 2016 results and we expect to see -- to build on these trends with new product introduction this fiscal year. 
We also continue to focus on opportunities in mainstream pet food, driven by consumer preference for additional protein and natural ingredients. 
Lastly, within the segment, we are excited about our partnership and planned in-store activities related to the animated film, The Secret life of Pets, which will be in theaters next month. 
Turning to International and Foodservice. We are pleased with the full year results despite a significant top and bottom line impacts of foreign currency. Reported net sales were in line with the prior year as the addition of the Pet Food business and the benefit of higher net pricing in Canada offset a $60 million top line impact related to foreign exchange. Segment profit was up 12%, mostly attributable to Foodservice. The introduction of Smucker's Uncrustables into school lunch program contributed to this growth.  The strong underlying performance of our Canadian business was mostly offset by the impact of foreign exchange. 
Let me conclude with an update on our integration and cost-savings activities. We successfully achieved our March 1 integration milestone for the Pet Food business and recognize just over $35 million of synergies for 2016. 
In addition, we have clear visibility and confidence in realizing an incremental $100 million in synergies this fiscal year. 
In total, this would provide approximately $135 million in synergies for 2017. 
Looking ahead, we remain confident in achieving our original goal of $200 million in annual synergies by the end of fiscal 2018. 
In addition to the $200 million of synergies, we are targeting $50 million of incremental annual cost savings to be fully realized over the next few years. Related projects include further optimizing our manufacturing footprint as over the next 18 months, we will close a coffee facility in Harahan, Louisiana and two leased Natural Foods facilities located in Livermore, California, with production being consolidated into existing operation. 
In addition, we are nearly complete with an organizational redesign aimed at further optimizing corporate resources contributing to this cost saving target. 
We expect to initially invest much of these incremental savings in several identified areas. We will continue to prioritize investments that generate top and bottom line growth for key on-trend platform. 
In fiscal 2017, these include opportunities related to Smucker's Uncrustables, Coffee and Snack. 
We are also establishing a new growth and innovation organization, which is being led by a member of my leadership team. The group is being tasked with further building capabilities related to consumer and market insight, digital, innovation, targeted market development strategies for our customers, including pricing and trade spend optimization. 
Lastly, we plan to invest in new growth opportunities to expand our presence in China. 
In closing, 2016 was a historic year for our company and I would like to thank our employees for their efforts. As we enter 2017, key priorities include achieving our synergy goals, building on our product innovation activities and investing in new capabilities to enhance future growth. 
Overall, we remain confident in our long-term strategy, the strength of our brands and our ability to deliver shareholder value in 2017 and beyond. 
I will now turn the call over to Mark Belgya.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone. I will begin by providing commentary on our fourth quarter results, followed by 2016 cash flow performance and ending with our 2017 outlook. We concluded the fiscal year with strong fourth quarter earnings. Non-G
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark. Good morning, everyone. I will begin by providing commentary on our fourth quarter results, followed by 2016 cash flow performance and ending with our 2017 outlook. 
We concluded the fiscal year with strong fourth quarter earnings. Non-GAAP earnings per share were $1.86 for the quarter, including a onetime $0.42 per share noncash deferred tax benefit related to the integration of Big Heart into the Smucker company as was previewed during our third quarter call. This strong finish to the year was mostly attributable to coffee, including higher anticipated volume across our mainstream and premium coffee brand and a favorable price cost relationship. 
The comparison of fourth quarter earnings between years is significantly impacted by onetime items reported in each of the respective period. These included deferred tax benefit in the current year as well as the Big Heart acquisition financing-related activities in the prior year. 
As a result, the remainder of my fourth quarter commentary will be focused on the business segment. 
Beginning with Coffee. Fourth quarter net sales grew 9% as favorable volume/mix of 13% was only partially offset by lower net pricing. Sales for the Dunkin' Donuts brand doubled over the prior year with K-Cups driving much of this growth. Double-digit gains for bag Dunkin' Donuts coffee also contributed. 
For the Folgers brand, net sales declined 5% attributable to lower net price realization. And lastly, Café Bustelo sales were up 28% as the momentum for this brand continues. 
Segment profit increased $43 million or 39%. We recognized lower grain coffee cost in the quarter, which were partially offset by lower net pricing. 
In addition, higher volume/mix more than offset increased marketing. 
Turning to Consumer Foods. Net sales were up 5%, excluding the impact of the canned milk divestiture with gains across the majority of our key brands. Sales for Jif were 14% behind higher volume in net pricing, while the Smucker's brand was up 3% and Uncrustables had another strong quarter. 
In the bake aisle, sales for Crisco increased by 6%, driven by higher volume. And lastly, sales for the Pillsbury brand were up modestly as higher price realization offset volume decline. 
Segment profit declined 6% mostly attributable to lapping the prior year earnings of the divested milk business. Planned increases in manufacturing overhead costs also contributed, reflecting the new peanut butter facility in Memphis as well as underreport overhead cost related to our working capital initiatives.  These factors offset lower marketing expense. 
Net sales for U.S. Retail Pet Food segments was $563 million. We estimate this represents an approximate 3% increase compared to the prior year fourth quarter of which 6 weeks were reported under our ownership. 
Sales for our premium Pet Brands will improve low double-digit driven by Natural Balance, while Pet Snacks sales increased in line with the overall segment. Mainstream pet food sales were flat compared to the prior year as growth in our cat food brand offset declines in dog food. 
Pet Food segment profit was $170 million for the quarter. As expected, we realized a sequential increase in segment profit margin from 17% in the third quarter to 20.7% this quarter, primarily reflecting lower marketing expense. Incremental synergy recognition also contributed. 
Net sales for International and Foodservice increased 1% in the quarter, reflecting higher volume/mix in Foodservice. 
In Canada, the addition of Pet Food was potentially offset by the impact of FX. 
Segment profit was up 8% over the prior year, driven by our Foodservice business, partially offset by the impact of foreign exchange in Canada. 
Free cash flow was $295 million for the quarter, bringing the 2016 total to $1.26 billion. The outperformance compared to our most recent free cash flow guidance of $975 million was attributable to exceeding our 2016 working capital improvement target, lower than projected CapEx spending, a fourth quarter tax refund of $53 million, which is separate from the deferred tax adjustment impacting earnings and higher net income. 
Expanding on our working capital initiatives. In 2016, we realized the majority of our finished good inventory reduction goal of $200 million nearly a year ahead of schedule. In 2017, we expect to achieve the remainder of the inventory reduction target, along with modest working capital improvements related to accounts payable and receivables, all of which are factored into our 2017 free cash flow outlook i will discuss in a moment. 
We ended the year with debt of $5.4 billion. Based on 2016 EBITDA of $1.58 billion, our leverage stood at 3.4x at April 30, a reduction from 4.1x at the beginning of the year. 
In addition to exceeding our debt pay down target for the year, we were able to restart share repurchase activities, aided by the strong free cash flow and proceeds from the divestiture of the milk business. 
During the fourth quarter, we repurchased nearly 3% shares outstanding for approximately $430 million. 
In 2017, the lower shares count will offset the EPS impact of the 8 months in loss profit related to the divestment of milk business. 
Turning to our 2017 outlook. We anticipate reported net sales to decrease by 1% compared to the prior year as we will lap approximately $150 million in sales related to the milk divestiture.  Excluding this impact, net sales are projected to be up 1%. Favorable volume/mix across each of the segments, including the benefit of new products is expected to be mostly offset by lower pricing in U.S. Retail Coffee and FX in Canada. 
Approximately $25 million of the incremental $100 million of synergies for 2017 are expected to benefit gross profit. Overall commodity cost are anticipated to be lower. However, our Canadian business is estimating a cogs headwind of $20 million related to FX of which, of course, is expected to be offset.  As a result, we expect gross margins to approximate 39% in 2017. 
Further, SD&A expenses are projected to be comparable with prior year. This reflects a benefit of incremental synergy is related to headcount reductions and other administrative cost savings, offset by increased marketing in support of recently launched product, our Olympic sponsorship, innovation and regulatory expenses. 
We're projecting non-GAAP operating income growth of 4% in 2017 compared to $1.465 billion in the prior year, which excludes amortization and the prior year gain on sales of $25 million. 
Further, excluding the $32 million of profit in last year's operating related to the divestment in milk business, the growth would be 6%. 
Below net operating income, we expect net interest expense of approximately $165 million and a tax rate of 34%. And lastly, a weighted average share count of 116.6 million shares was used based on current shares outstanding. 
Factoring all of these, we are guiding 2017 adjusted EPS in the range of $7.60 to $7.75, which excludes $1.18 per share of estimated noncash amortization. 
Including amortization, this yield a range of $6.42 to $6.57 compared to a 2016 base of $6. This results in year-over-year increases, ranging from 7% to 10%. 
As illustrated on the document posted on our website, we derived the $6 EPS for 2016 by subtracting the $0.42 deferred tax adjustment and the $0.15 milk gain from our reported non-GAAP EPS of $6.57. 
We anticipate much of the EPS growth for the year to be weighted towards the middle 2 quarters of the fiscal years due to several factors. Last year's first quarter included the launch of Dunkin' K-Cups. Also within Coffee, this year's first quarter will be unfavorable impacted due to timing associated with the full quarter impact of the price depreciation taken in July of 2015, along with the additional price point decline taken in May of this year as compared to the recognition of lower cost. Other factors impacting quarterly comparison include the timing of synergy recognition, the timed impact related to trade spent recognition on a quarterly basis and finally, the fourth quarter comparison to this year's strong fourth quarter finish. 
Looking briefly at the segment. Our Coffee profits are projected to be comparable to the record fiscal 2015 level. For Consumer Foods, before the segment profit is expected to be down given the prior year gain on the milk divestiture and the lost milk profit but up mid-single digits when these items are excluded. 
Pet Food segment profit is also projected to be up mid-single digits, reflecting incremental synergies and organic growth, including the contributions of new products. 
And lastly, International and Foodservice is anticipated to be down, primarily reflecting the net impact of FX in Canada. 
We project free cash flow will approximate $1 billion, from which we plan to pay down debt and further reduce leverage to 3.1x by the end of this fiscal year. This assumes projected 2017 EBITDA of $1.63 billion. 
Additional assumptions related to 2017 include amortization expense of nearly $210 million; depreciation of $215 million; share-based compensation expense of $35 million; capital expenditures of $240 million; and lastly, onetime cost of $100 million, which are mostly cash related. 
In closing, we are very pleased with our overall performance in 2016 as it marked a memorable year in our company history. It is with this momentum and excitement that we look forward to executing our plans for 2017 as we remain focused on delivering continued growth. 
We thank you for your time, and we will now open up the calls for questions. Operator, if you please queue up the first question?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just, I guess, a quick one for me. In thinking about the underlying EPS growth guidance for fiscal '17, as you pointed out, it's roughly 7% to 10% or so. And I guess, you've talked about base EPS growth in the sort of 10% range, I think, for '17 and '18.
componenttext: Just, I guess, a quick one for me. In thinking about the underlying EPS growth guidance for fiscal '17, as you pointed out, it's roughly 7% to 10% or so. And I guess, you've talked about base EPS growth in the sort of 10% range, I think, for '17 and '18. So I'm just trying to get a sense of what leads to the call it that 8% at the midpoint type of growth range. Is it just conservatism? Is it coffee outperformed pretty dramatically this year and therefore, we just need to tail that back a little bit expectations for '17? Or things that I haven't mentioned? Just trying to put that in perspective.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, this is Mark Belgya. Thank you for the question. What I would say, and as Mark reiterated, we will deliver the $100 million in synergies. We have a clear line of sight on that. Where we landed in that sort of 8% is we are having a significant incr
componenttext: Andrew, this is Mark Belgya. Thank you for the question. What I would say, and as Mark reiterated, we will deliver the $100 million in synergies. We have a clear line of sight on that. Where we landed in that sort of 8% is we are having a significant increase in marketing spend for the coming year. Obviously, with sponsorship of the Olympics and reestablishing some of the marketing spend from this year. So that is the biggest driver. I think, in terms of the coffee, I would put that more in the category of where we might land in the range. Obviously, we have strong year. We will continue. We feel good about that, but that's probably a factor that comes to play a little bit as well. And then the other one probably to a lesser degree is just the FX impacts. As I mentioned, we're having about a $20 million headwind, and we hope to cover at least half of that, but there's a little bit of that affecting as well.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And just a very quick one. I noticed that distribution expense, I think, as a percent of sales was much lower than, I guess, typically as this quarter. Just try to get a sense of why that is and is that sort more of a sustainable level?

componenttext: Andrew, what that might be is that, I think, as we are aligning the Big Heart -- basically, Big Heart P&L where certain things fall in cost probably more consider distribution might have been moved. But we can follow up if there's something different from that response.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Richard, congratulations on your retirement. And Mark, what a big day. Congratulations for you and, I guess, it was May 1, but for us, it feels like today. So congratulations, guys. And Vince, all the best. I wanted to ask a follow-up on Andrew's question
componenttext: Richard, congratulations on your retirement. And Mark, what a big day. Congratulations for you and, I guess, it was May 1, but for us, it feels like today. So congratulations, guys. And Vince, all the best. I wanted to ask a follow-up on Andrew's question on the guidance. So Mark, a different way to look at this would be to say that, that $100 million of synergies, I think, that number alone gets you something like $0.57 a share in incremental EPS benefit in 2017, and that gets you to kind of the top end of the range. So maybe -- could you try to answer just slightly differently and just saying that if synergies kind of gets you just to the top end of the range, doesn't it suggest that the rest of the operations are really on balance flattish? I know there's a share count benefit, there's a milk -- there's milk dilution that goes on in there, but it still just seems like the underlying expectation of the core ex the synergies is basically flat?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, David, it's interesting because we obviously went to that same line of thought. But the way I would describe it is, that you're exactly right, the $100 million [indiscernible] $0.57 delivery, the marketing increase I would tell you is, it's a signifi
componenttext: Yes, David, it's interesting because we obviously went to that same line of thought. But the way I would describe it is, that you're exactly right, the $100 million [indiscernible] $0.57 delivery, the marketing increase I would tell you is, it's a significant increase there. We are up. So we feel very comfortable to be able to invest this marketing dollar back in the business. So there's a little bit of a discussion here on whether or not the business is flat from a performance perspective or it's flat because we've invested in the market, we would choose the latter saying that the market increase is offsetting some of that to some degree. The other thing is, I think, Mark suggested in his expected comments is that we're also investing in innovation and growth and also in China  So obviously, those dollars are embedded in the business portion of it when you just separate between synergy and non-synergy. So you could draw the conclusion coming from the business, but those are the 2 or 3 factors: Marketing, innovation and investment in China and a little bit of FX as I mentioned, that are really kind of bringing that number back down.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And for my second question, on coffee, back at your Analyst Day and, I believe, Steve have said that it would be until like 2019 before the company recovered the profitability seen in 2014. I think, as of today, you've already recovered the profits.
componenttext: Okay. And for my second question, on coffee, back at your Analyst Day and, I believe, Steve have said that it would be until like 2019 before the company recovered the profitability seen in 2014. I think, as of today, you've already recovered the profits. So can you maybe just kind of 2 settle questions in here. Why does this outperform so much relative to the expectation? And then what I really care about is how does this impact kind of going forward? I mean, you had a very different outlook on how profits were going to move in this business. I'm not complaining, by the way, this is really wonderful that the profits are up so much, but I think we all kind of worry that the massive out performance of coffee profits in '16 will somehow retard the ability of profits to grow in '17. Was that clear, guys?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, it is, David. It's Steve Oakland. Let's talk about the Coffee business. If you talk about the number, we did get 1 year or 2 ahead of what we guided. And we got there on two things, really. And the most obvious one is this, the launch of Dunkin'
componenttext: I think, it is, David. It's Steve Oakland. Let's talk about the Coffee business. If you talk about the number, we did get 1 year or 2 ahead of what we guided. And we got there on two things, really. And the most obvious one is this, the launch of Dunkin' K-Cups, and we all know that was one of the best launches in consumer products in the last 5 [indiscernible]. So that was a wonderful performance. But really, more importantly, financially, if you look at the performance of our core Red Can business, and that's an effort that started 2 years ago. I mean, in the year that we struggled in our Coffee business, Mark and his team went back and did the downsize, started those processes. And then we had an opportunity in this last year to get coffee pricing right to have both the manufacturing and the hedging strategy to get this thing -- to get it to price points that both excited the retailer and the consumer. And the retailers are key piece of this. If you got it, get that merchandising to the floor. So we're really pleased with where we are there. I think, you saw -- I'm sure you saw that there are press release and pricing that we just took. So with all of that behind us, we feel pretty comfortable that we can repeat that performance. And to your comment earlier, that would be repeating a record performance. We actually beat the 2014 numbers here, right? So on our Red Can and our core business and our Dunkin' business, we feel -- or our Dunkin' K-Cup business, we feel really good. So a loss in that though year was -- this segments that didn't perform as elected to and that is and our premium and our legacy K-Cup, our Folgers K-Cup business. So what we intend to do this year is do the same things to those, and so the pricing, we leaned in the early on the Dunkin' bag business. You saw some of the performance in the fourth quarter, we feel great about that going into this quarter. So we need to floor ourselves back on premium good momentum. We will invest to do that, and we need to make sure as the K-Cup segment shakes out, and it will shake out, I mean there's so many items, there's so much going on there that the velocity is on our core legacy items are strong, and we invested right at the end of the quarter in that as well. So I guess, what I'm saying, we feel comfortable we can repeat the record results in Red Can, the Dunkin' K-Cup business will be very solid this year. And then with what we have extra on there, we're going to invest in those other 2 segments. So I would hope we come out of the Coffee business firing on all cylinders versus firing just on those 2 big ones [indiscernible].

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: David, this is Richard Smucker. Two quick comments. One, from 50,000 square foot level, our -- 70% to 80% of our business has really good momentum, and we're firing on all 8 cylinders. We're using that opportunity to make -- as Mark said, investments in o
componenttext: David, this is Richard Smucker. Two quick comments. One, from 50,000 square foot level, our -- 70% to 80% of our business has really good momentum, and we're firing on all 8 cylinders. We're using that opportunity to make -- as Mark said, investments in our business for the future, not just for the next year, but beyond. And this just gives us the opportunity to do that. We're not making these numbers by cutting margin expenses, and it gives us the opportunity to invest back in these business -- in these brands. So I need to you to look at it from a high level we do, and that's driving a lot of our business. It's also positioning us well for growth in the future, not just the next year, but beyond. And then finally, I don't like the word retirement, so I just want to let you know that. I am not retiring, I'm just moving to a different role and most of the families peg are one desk, and we're watching that very carefully so.

componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll start that, Chris, it's Steve Oakland. And then maybe Mark can help me as we look at the seasonality of profits. If you go back to the fourth quarter of 2014 with coffee prices hit like 2 20 of [indiscernible], Arabica. And then we saw it came
componenttext: Okay, I'll start that, Chris, it's Steve Oakland. And then maybe Mark can help me as we look at the seasonality of profits. If you go back to the fourth quarter of 2014 with coffee prices hit like 2 20 of [indiscernible], Arabica. And then we saw it came down basically $1 a pound over the time. It's bumped up in the last day or so, but if you think about that, the fastest most efficient way to get that pricing to the consumer was with trade, okay? We can, in fact, shelf price on a promoted period on the trade. So in the short term, that's very efficient. In the long term, it's very inefficient because it promotes all kinds of buying low all inefficiency in the system, right? So over the last year, we've taken a couple of list price declines to mitigate that, to make the promotional aisle deck last. So we leaned in to current coffee pricing on our promotional price points and now, this has allowed us to sort of drain that out, get better list price to promoted price ratio so that our every day price gets better, and we maintained our firm prices. So we try to make that clear in the release that we did to give a little more clarity on that this time. So that the cost has been reflected in total coffee pricing. This is -- this makes over the long term in a more efficient manner.

componenttext: The other thing -- this is Mark Smucker. The only thing I would add, Steve, is just from a commodity trends standpoint, if you look at the trends on coffee cost, the decline that we've experienced has gone on for 9 months, at least 12 months, so you've had seen this very consistent, sustained lower coffee cost and that has allowed us to behave properly or responsibly, if you will, because we've had consistency in our underlying cost structure.

componenttext: Sure. Ken, the recent run up, there's always volatility in the Coffee business. We are fortunate that have teams on the ground have also seen both the 2 largest markets in Brazil and Vietnam. And so, again, the coffee is relative to price relative what we promoted to and then if we look -- if our teams up on the ground those markets look at the coffee crop, there's been some weather voice in the last day or 2 that's driven it up, but it does appear, I think, our team is going to be great Arabica crop this year, and so we think that coffee will trade in a price range that supports where we're  priced within between our position and our opinion. The good thing about this business is we have pricing capabilities here, and not only do we have the coverage, but we have the ability to move price should we need to. So we feel pretty good about this. Arabica crop as it goes forward, Robusta, might be a little bit tighter, but we think the Arabica crop is going to be big one this year and pricing should be reasonable.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then my next question, the $50 million in additional efficiencies over the next few years. Frankly, that's a little bit of a smaller amount than what I had expected it's a little bit smaller at least on a percentage of sales, from what your package appears to come up with. So I realized, you're already lean, I guess, in some other areas, headcount and so forth, but as we look at this, what's holding this number back from being as high as what we've seen, what you've seen, what you're seeing, I guess, from other food manufacturing peers out there?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Mark Smucker, and thanks for the question. I'll start and then [indiscernible] can also chime in. So a couple of things. So as you know, as you think about our performance, historically, has been very good, and we have had historically, a ver
componenttext: Ken, this is Mark Smucker, and thanks for the question. I'll start and then [indiscernible] can also chime in. So a couple of things. So as you know, as you think about our performance, historically, has been very good, and we have had historically, a very strong cost discipline in multiple areas of our business. Part of what we've embarked on, which really was the catalyst was the Big Heart acquisition was to think a little bit deeper about our overall cost-savings initiatives and how we might do a little bit better. You are right that our productivity measures versus our peers are probably better in many cases, and we are generally leaner, I would say, than some of our peers. But having said that, we have an obligation, obviously, to our shareholders to make sure that we have the best cost discipline that we can have. And so what we've been doing, and this is part of the explanation of the $50 million is on an ongoing basis making sure from a continuous improvement that we have the discipline in our supply chain, our operations, our purchasing and longer term as we think about how do we get more efficient in trade, all of those things should help drive what I would call some incremental savings to the bottom line. So it isn't -- we don't think about it as a onetime benefit, but we are comfortable that we can at least deliver that and then beyond these next couple of years, we should be able to continue to deliver annual cost-savings objectives, which we hold our teams to. The good news about that is, as  Richard mentioned, it is allowing us to invest and enhance capability and in a very high level, what those capabilities are focused on is getting better at engaging with our consumer and getting better in engaging with our retail customers. And so strategically, having the right balance between our leading #1 brand, which are really the engine that fuel our growth as well as having the right emerging brands and our portfolio is part of that strategy. And so making sure that we have dollars that can fund those enhanced capabilities, both in consumer engagement and customer engagement is really going to help drive our growth, both top and bottom line long term.

And also on as part of your launch that you talked about price points in some of your businesses, you mentioned the Folgers K-Cups, Dunkin', how do we flip those 2 in terms of moderation, competitive activity just as opposed with it sounds like a bit more competitive activity coming from you?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, it's Steve Oakland, I'll try to touch on that. I think, it's difficult to think that coffee category was one brush competitively. I think, the prepared remarks probably we're focused more on our mainstream Red Can business, right? And I do think we
componenttext: Jason, it's Steve Oakland, I'll try to touch on that. I think, it's difficult to think that coffee category was one brush competitively. I think, the prepared remarks probably we're focused more on our mainstream Red Can business, right? And I do think we've seen with Arabica [indiscernible] with the coffee prices falling where they are, we have found that price points have gotten down into those ranges where it motivates both the competitor and the consumer and the customer, right? So all of us are in price points that really work, okay? And so we're back in that zone and I think, everybody is operating in that zone. Having said that, I would argue that the premium segment was maybe the most competitive we've ever seen it last year. And so the Dunkin' bag business, as you know, we're in [indiscernible] year in a couple of tough quarters, and we've talked about how we lean into that in the fourth quarter. Premium green and other for a whole another green coffee is not all the same. There's a coffee that goes in the last premium, coffee, there's a much longer supply chain. You might expect lower coffee cost impact us up for different timing based on the type of green that it is. So in the fourth quarter that we were in a position to support that we did, and it had responded. So if you think about it, the core Red Can pricing had moderated, our competitive set moderated, the premium business probably in that space now and the last piece will be K-Cups and we're going into lean into K-Cups. The proliferation of K-Cups has caused that whole segment to be competing for a slower-growth base. And one of the levers that's been using is price. We're able not to compete in that area, but that's the last piece of the puzzle, and we feel good about the plan we put in front of you today, will give us the dollars to support that and return that business to growth.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to add as part of our momentum behind it. So we expect our stock business to be at the high single digit growth next, next fiscal year, specifically with our Milk-Bone and our Pup-Peroni brands. On the pet specialty side of the business, we're lappin
componenttext: Just to add as part of our momentum behind it. So we expect our stock business to be at the high single digit growth next, next fiscal year, specifically with our Milk-Bone and our Pup-Peroni brands. On the pet specialty side of the business, we're lapping the expanded distribution last year in the Pet Specialty channel, but we would expect mid-single-digit growth this coming year as we launch national advertising campaign behind the Natural Balance brand. We also -- there are 2 major retailers in pet specialty, but that is also significant amount of sales and independent trade. We have a push behind our Nature's Recipe brand. We think there's some real opportunities there, that's our gateway specialty brands, and we see some growth there. And then also our snacks plate significant role in pet specialty. So largely this distributed brands also tremendous growth opportunity there. Food is going to be the lower growth this year as part of the portfolio is concerned. You know what our challenges where this past year, specifically with Kibbles 'n Bits. We are encouraged that we've actually seen negative consumption trends start to decelerate at the end of -- at the last fiscal year, we put some bonus bag into the market. You're going to see more of this going to the market in June. So a lot of effort stabilizing our dry dog food business and [indiscernible] trying to that business backward needs to be. So that provides the color you were looking for?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, very helpful.
componenttext: Yes, very helpful.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of the [indiscernible] I think, showing that investments. Starting talk about the e-commerce strategy at the investor day last year. Are you able to dimensionalize how big that is for you as of now? How fast it grew last year? I presume the ke
componenttext: So a couple of the [indiscernible] I think, showing that investments. Starting talk about the e-commerce strategy at the investor day last year. Are you able to dimensionalize how big that is for you as of now? How fast it grew last year? I presume the key categories in there are probably coffee and pet food, which one of those in figure? Would just like to get some color on that because we don't see that at the measured channel. And then you mentioned China investment. Can you just give us a little bit of color on how much spending over there now, what the profit is over time? And I'll pass it on.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alexia, this is Mark Smucker. I'll start. The first -- your first question just it as it relates to e-commerce is that you're right, we are -- I would say, we're a little bit underdeveloped versus our peers in that space, and so as I talked to Ken's quest
componenttext: Alexia, this is Mark Smucker. I'll start. The first -- your first question just it as it relates to e-commerce is that you're right, we are -- I would say, we're a little bit underdeveloped versus our peers in that space, and so as I talked to Ken's question earlier relative to investments and what we're trying to amp up, that is one of those things. And so not to get into too much specifics but as we think about -- we actually have just reorganized some of our commercial functions that would include sales and some of our marketing areas, but also in the digital space, we have actually destock our capabilities there and are currently in process of reevaluating our total e-commerce strategy and how we better serve our e-commerce customers. And when we think about e-commerce, that includes both the digital only retailers like Amazon as well as our brick-and-mortar customers that have a significant online presence as well. So a little bit of a general answer, but suffice to say that it is on our radar's screen, and it is a priority for us to continue to develop that business.

componenttext: And then on China, I think you asked in terms of financial impact, I would say it's about $0.03 to $0.05 for the current year in fiscal '17.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to go back to some of your comments from your Analyst Day last year with respect to coffee. Some of cautioned around getting back to fiscal 2015 coffee EBIT levels not until 2019, some of the reason for that was related to investment around th
componenttext: So I wanted to go back to some of your comments from your Analyst Day last year with respect to coffee. Some of cautioned around getting back to fiscal 2015 coffee EBIT levels not until 2019, some of the reason for that was related to investment around the perfect measures. So obviously, you've already achieved that goal of getting to the profit recovery. But wanted to understand how the investment is going for profit measures. Is that still a major focus point for you guys?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mario, with regard to profit measures, I think, we still think it has a potential [indiscernible] way about it. I'll tell you the reason you put things on lead market or test markets is to learn, and we learned a lot. And our trial numbers candidly, we're
componenttext: Mario, with regard to profit measures, I think, we still think it has a potential [indiscernible] way about it. I'll tell you the reason you put things on lead market or test markets is to learn, and we learned a lot. And our trial numbers candidly, we're not where we needed them to be, but our repeat numbers were fantastic. And so it tells us that we probably got a positioning a little wrong, we probably get some of the initial communication a little wrong, but we got the concept right. And so this year, we're going to relaunch that with a little better packaging, a little bit of messaging, and we're going to -- it's a heavy capital investment because the technology is unique and we want to make sure we get it just right before we lean into it on a more national scale. We still think the concept has a lot of legs, but we're probably a year behind where we talked at this point. Those investment numbers are baked into the numbers of the guidance that Mark gave -- continued investment.
