headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pablo Zuanic with SIG.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pablo Zuanic with SIG.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, a couple of questions on coffee for Steve. And then I had a follow-up on Pet Food. Steve, so, Starbucks, our sales there in January, you talked about -- pretty much implied to threaten to walk away from Keurig/JAB. And then in the April call, you ca
componenttext: Look, a couple of questions on coffee for Steve. And then I had a follow-up on Pet Food. Steve, so, Starbucks, our sales there in January, you talked about -- pretty much implied to threaten to walk away from Keurig/JAB. And then in the April call, you came out and said, at least, 3x or 4x in the conference call, that they have been able to negotiate terms, very favorable terms with Keurig and that those terms gave them also more flexibility. So I'm wondering here, if Starbucks can do that with JAB, why can't Smucker's? So if you could just comment on that. I'm just surprised that they were able to negotiate terms, now that there was a change in ownership there and apparently, you haven't. Related to that, I understand the idea of sharpening price points for Folgers and K-Cups. The category has been sticky, of course, while brown moves quite a bit. But as you do that, are we expecting other competitors to also cut prices in their K-Cup brands? And then K-Cups, as a category, will become, not sticky, but pass through as ground. So I see a bit of a risk there, if you can comment on that, please.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess, I wouldn't assume, I wouldn't take the assumption that we haven't done the same kind of work on our K-Cup contract and our relationship with JV [ph] and our -- because we have a legacy relationship with JV [ph] from the Sara Lee acquisition
componenttext: Sure. I guess, I wouldn't assume, I wouldn't take the assumption that we haven't done the same kind of work on our K-Cup contract and our relationship with JV [ph] and our -- because we have a legacy relationship with JV [ph] from the Sara Lee acquisition several years ago and now from the Keurig. So the fact that maybe we're a little less public about some of that stuff, I wouldn't assume that the same things aren't going on. So those different companies manage those things differently, right? So that process is in process, and we feel good about their relationship. They are committed to have the major brands in the category in their systems. And we read the same things  you read, so our assumptions are going into those negotiations, our assumptions of similar years. So we feel fine there. And with regards to K-Cups, if you dig a little deeper into the IRI and the Nielsen data, you'll  see that K-Cups -- although we don't pass through green, because green's kind of a small portion of the overall cost structure, it's become may be the most promoted category in total cost. So there's the highest reliant -- each one of those brands relies very heavily on promotion. So maybe I'm not clear enough when I talk about leaning in. We've leaned in on our promotional price points mostly. And so those promotional points are basically down $1 a box from what they used to be. It still means -- it's still a very profitable business. But that migration has already -- that train's already left. So we are where we are. We might have been a little late to follow because of the momentum we had from the Dunkin' business.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just a quick follow-up there, so your K-Cup margins would be lower than your ground coffee margins, right?
componenttext: Understood. And just a quick follow-up there, so your K-Cup margins would be lower than your ground coffee margins, right?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, a little bit. Yes, a little bit. Our ground coffee margins are obviously because of our scale, very, very good. And our K-Cup margins are although good by consumer products standards, by company standards, aren't quite at that level.
componenttext: Yes, a little bit. Yes, a little bit. Our ground coffee margins are obviously because of our scale, very, very good. And our K-Cup margins are although good by consumer products standards, by company standards, aren't quite at that level.

componenttext: And then just a follow-up on Pet Food. I guess it's been touched already, but can you tell us where did the mix end after a decline in dry dog and dolphin snacks and specialty. If you can provide that roughly on a current run rate, not what it was on average in '16?

componenttext: Well, I'm asking 2 different questions on I guess, Pet Food, right? Because obviously, you explained that snacks and specialty are doing well in terms of your natural organic brands, Natural Balance. And the other brands are doing well, and dry is not doing so well. So I'm just trying to understand where did the sales mix end in terms of products in fiscal year '16? And then it's a separate question, what is the channel mix, right? Because some of us -- dry dog is also sold in the specialty channel, right, and snacks are sold in both, Natural Balance -- your National balance but only sold in specialty, I understand that. So I'm just trying to get a bit more color in terms of what's your current product mix? And separate, what's your current channel mix if you can provide that.

componenttext: Okay. From a channel perspective, of our total, total business, about 20% of our business is in the pet specialty. And then Mark, you want to take ...

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pablo, this is Mark Belgya. Just to make sure -- I think I understand your question. And it goes back to a little bit earlier moment that, if you look at the mix product, okay, we benefit from mix perspective. So when a growth occurs, as Barry described f
componenttext: Pablo, this is Mark Belgya. Just to make sure -- I think I understand your question. And it goes back to a little bit earlier moment that, if you look at the mix product, okay, we benefit from mix perspective. So when a growth occurs, as Barry described from a channel perspective, we're also benefiting from a product mix perspective. So whether it's just specialty or snacks or even cat probably more than dogs, there's a positive mix benefit. Obviously, Kibbles 'n Bits is a heavy product. It's a lot of volume. So that's where it's negative so it's a very positive mix story, a negative overall volume story because of the dry dog side of the equation.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry to insist, so dry dog would be what percent of your sales now, on a run rate now?
componenttext: Sorry to insist, so dry dog would be what percent of your sales now, on a run rate now?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, 10%, about 10% of pet total sales. And the only other thing I'd reiterate, and I do think it gets lost occasionally because particularly as I've had in conversations the last few quarters, clearly, Kibbles 'n Bits has been challenged. When you look a
componenttext: Yes, 10%, about 10% of pet total sales. And the only other thing I'd reiterate, and I do think it gets lost occasionally because particularly as I've had in conversations the last few quarters, clearly, Kibbles 'n Bits has been challenged. When you look at our food business, the cat food side of business is a little bit larger and has done okay, so it has balanced out a little bit. So while not trying to downside the impact of Kibbles 'n Bits and the volume and what it's had over the course of the year, the cat food performance has allowed us to manage through the overall food, a little bit from where maybe the takeaway would be.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add -- this is Mark Smucker, is just reminding everyone that the brand that participated in those 2 channels are very different. It's very similar to the natural space in human food, where we've got the natural channel with the Whol
componenttext: The only thing I would add -- this is Mark Smucker, is just reminding everyone that the brand that participated in those 2 channels are very different. It's very similar to the natural space in human food, where we've got the natural channel with the Whole Food and the sprouts and the like. In general, there's not a lot of overlap in the brand. So the brand tend to be unique to those individual channels.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Richard and just adding to that for a second. Just any acquisition that we made -- and again, this acquisition is only 18 months old, once we've integrated these businesses with our sales teams, we've seen some opportunities -- channels where our
componenttext: This is Richard and just adding to that for a second. Just any acquisition that we made -- and again, this acquisition is only 18 months old, once we've integrated these businesses with our sales teams, we've seen some opportunities -- channels where our existing sales team have said, "Hey, we're kind of weak in this channel. And with the relationships we have with these customers, we can really grow the business." And it takes a little while to identify that and then build those additional sales with those customers. And we're just in the process of doing that. So we're pretty optimistic about finding those key customers that we can build our business with. So we should see some more growth this year in a number of those channels. Don't you agree with that?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do, Richard. And just maybe to add on to the Meow Mix conversation. Some of our best innovation this year is against the Meow Mix brand. And to your point, our sales team has done an outstanding job getting acceptance of that product here the market and
componenttext: I do, Richard. And just maybe to add on to the Meow Mix conversation. Some of our best innovation this year is against the Meow Mix brand. And to your point, our sales team has done an outstanding job getting acceptance of that product here the market and especially in the grocery channel. So where we have an outstanding system that connects you there. So again, Mark to your point, Meow Mix is one of our largest brands in our portfolio. And with some of that innovation, we see some nice growth coming from that brand here.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I just wanted to follow-up on the net sales growth expectation and just trying, digging a little bit more at the segment level -- thank you for the commentary on pet. But I guess, Mark Belgya, is there any more visibility you can give us on that 1
componenttext: I guess I just wanted to follow-up on the net sales growth expectation and just trying, digging a little bit more at the segment level -- thank you for the commentary on pet. But I guess, Mark Belgya, is there any more visibility you can give us on that 1% ex divestitures sales growth, how FX plays into that? And how we should be thinking about it by segment across the rest of it?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess what I would say, Matt, is that about -- the coffee pricing would be about 1 point of the overall company. So you can kind of dollarize that and get how much the coffee would be. That's, by far, the biggest driver from the downside. If you take th
componenttext: I guess what I would say, Matt, is that about -- the coffee pricing would be about 1 point of the overall company. So you can kind of dollarize that and get how much the coffee would be. That's, by far, the biggest driver from the downside. If you take the milk loss of $150 million, I mentioned earlier. And then you had 1% of sales, call it, somewhere between $70 million, $90 million on coffee pricing, that's the two big negatives. So just do the math, it kind of attributes to the rest of the business [indiscernible]. Obviously, the FX has a little bit of effect, but it's actually not a big driver in the overall 1% decline to the total net sales --

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: Okay, all right that helps. And I guess just really quick follow-up on the Dunkin' K-Cup issue. You talked about some of the untapped adjacency opportunities and flavorings on line extensions. Your market shares sort of stabilized over the past 6 months. It gets pretty close to where your share is in roast and ground. Right now, can you just give us a sense of sort of where you see -- in terms of growth opportunities, how much of that is dependent on holding that share participating in category growth as opposed to continuing to push share higher into that high single-digit range? And what do you think is feasible?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matthew, I think, it will vary by business. I think, there's still runway for the Dunkin' business. There's some core flavors on Dunkin' and Dunkin' tends to be a more flavor-driven business. So there's new line item on the Dunkin' brand. And then quite f
componenttext: Matthew, I think, it will vary by business. I think, there's still runway for the Dunkin' business. There's some core flavors on Dunkin' and Dunkin' tends to be a more flavor-driven business. So there's new line item on the Dunkin' brand. And then quite frankly, now that the Folgers brand is in the right price points, getting the right support both from the retailers and the consumer segments, it will be better execution of our promotion strategies on Folgers. So we'll execute there on Folgers once [indiscernible].

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.

componenttext: So a couple -- 2 questions. One on coffee. Can you just explain to us or breakout of the 18% growth that you saw in operating income or segment operating income, how much of that was a result of pricing net of commodity costs? And what is the general expectation for pricing net of commodities for '17? That's the first question, and then I have a follow-up on Pet.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, it's a balanced -- I would say part of it is pricing. And the timing of the pricing is important to think about. We talked, I believe, in our first quarter call a year ago, that we leaned in and we took pricing early. We had good coverage, an
componenttext: I would say, it's a balanced -- I would say part of it is pricing. And the timing of the pricing is important to think about. We talked, I believe, in our first quarter call a year ago, that we leaned in and we took pricing early. We had good coverage, and we had an opinion on the market that we were going to get that money back in green, which we did in the fourth quarter. So in the fourth quarter, obviously, green pricing to cost was a bigger impact, but we sort of spent that money up front. So I would say it's a combination of that green pricing. When you get your #1, your high-volume item, when you get volume up on those canisters and our facilities do it, it really -- it falls to the bottom line, so that's very efficient for us. So Mark, I know Mark's digging for the exact percentage number as we speak. But it's a balance between the volume that's generated and the implications of that volume all the way through the system on Red Can and then the pricing.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And it's probably a little bit heavier on the price cost, maybe 2/3, 1/3-ish. But again, I think that goes back to what Steve said quite a while ago, which was just sort of the way, the timing on the pricing.
componenttext: And it's probably a little bit heavier on the price cost, maybe 2/3, 1/3-ish. But again, I think that goes back to what Steve said quite a while ago, which was just sort of the way, the timing on the pricing.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the volume allowed us to bring more. And at the end, the green at the end was more favorable. So it's really hard to get it down to a knit on that. Because you recognize those PPBs [ph] and the green comes in. And if your volumes up, you bring more of
componenttext: And the volume allowed us to bring more. And at the end, the green at the end was more favorable. So it's really hard to get it down to a knit on that. Because you recognize those PPBs [ph] and the green comes in. And if your volumes up, you bring more of the greens.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's some quality of the earnings -- and I'll start. Barry, if you want to jump in. If you look over the course, I mean this quarter specifically, we knew market was going to be down a little bit from where it was because of the timing of the product.
componenttext: There's some quality of the earnings -- and I'll start. Barry, if you want to jump in. If you look over the course, I mean this quarter specifically, we knew market was going to be down a little bit from where it was because of the timing of the product. But we also had the synergy recognition, which picked up in the latter part. So if you go back to the early part of the year, we expected quarter-over-quarter improvement on margin that we delivered on in Q2, 3 and 4. I think from a cost perspective going forward, the cost aligned, very similar to what we've seen our Consumer Foods. So the green continue to be favorable. I think as Barry mentioned, we are going to continue bonus bag and things like that, that might have a little bit of effect on gross profit. And then, of course, I think we said over time, of the 3 segments of the business, the Natural has the lowest profitability. And I think Barry and his team worked and as well if you integrate that into the overall Smucker Company from the opportunity there as well.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Mark. Yes, our quality of [indiscernible] for FY '17. If you think about mix, too, just as our snacks continues to drive the business, that is where the strongest margins on the business are as well. We've seen -- even cat snacks, small catego
componenttext: Absolutely, Mark. Yes, our quality of [indiscernible] for FY '17. If you think about mix, too, just as our snacks continues to drive the business, that is where the strongest margins on the business are as well. We've seen -- even cat snacks, small category, but tremendous upside there. So I think we have very solid quality earnings for next year. We haven't made any significant cut to get to our growth number next year year-over-year.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one last one for Mark. You talked about organizational structural change. Can you give us some more color on that?
componenttext: And just one last one for Mark. You talked about organizational structural change. Can you give us some more color on that?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mark Smucker. Not really. I don't think we really can give you any more color other than to say that as we -- this was a huge year. And not only did we make the largest acquisition in our history, but that acquisition was, again, the catalyst to sort
componenttext: It's Mark Smucker. Not really. I don't think we really can give you any more color other than to say that as we -- this was a huge year. And not only did we make the largest acquisition in our history, but that acquisition was, again, the catalyst to sort of think about things like, are we going to market in the most efficient way? Do we have the right capabilities to engage our consumer and our customer? We recently opened our innovation center, which is very much all about our customer retail partners. And so the long and short of it is, as we looked at our organization, we took some opportunity across not only our commercial functions, which would be sales and marketing and thinking about how we would organize those differently. But we looked across our supply chain network, our finance organization, our -- some of our administrative functions as well, just to make sure that we were running them in the most efficient way. I would say that one of the key things is that -- as I mentioned in the script, we have an individual from Big Heart, who is leading our growth and innovation organization. And so we are putting sort of a renewed focus on -- not that we haven't, we've done a good job on innovation. But making sure that our muscle, where we're building muscle is really around innovation longer term and making sure that our understanding of the consumer is sharp and that we can act against insights that we are learning about the consumer as we go forward. So I think that's probably it.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Farha Aslam with Stephens Inc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Farha Aslam with Stephens Inc.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gregory [ph] for Farha. I just have a quick question. So given sort of the excellent cash flow and success taking down leverage, can you share with us where there may be opportunities for further M&A and just your view on the M&A environment right
componenttext: This is Gregory [ph] for Farha. I just have a quick question. So given sort of the excellent cash flow and success taking down leverage, can you share with us where there may be opportunities for further M&A and just your view on the M&A environment right now?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mark Belgya. I mean I'll start and Richard, Mark, if you want to add more from a strategic perspective. But as we look at our deployment of cash coming out of the deal last year, we, obviously, emphasized the importance of paying down debt ov
componenttext: Yes, this is Mark Belgya. I mean I'll start and Richard, Mark, if you want to add more from a strategic perspective. But as we look at our deployment of cash coming out of the deal last year, we, obviously, emphasized the importance of paying down debt over the course of 3 to 5 years, which we've made great progress on, as I said earlier. It allowed us to get back into repurchasing shares. We feel very comfortable with the $1 billion of free cash flow that we'll be able to continue that debt pay down of planned obviously, continue our dividend payout policies. And it allows us a little bit of flexibility as strategic options come in. So whether that's M&A -- again, I don't think we're looking at a huge transformational like a pet, at least from a leverage perspective. But certainly, there's M&A opportunity as well as buyback. And I think, buybacks are situational. So we traditionally, do not build that into our plan. But if you ask me what is one of the opportunities for the upside of that range, you happen to provide buyback as an opportunity in there.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is Richard, just strategically, acquisitions are the key factor of our growth over long term. And so we still continue to look for those opportunities. And in fact, we're now in the Pet Food business. It gives us another [indiscernible] position
componenttext: And this is Richard, just strategically, acquisitions are the key factor of our growth over long term. And so we still continue to look for those opportunities. And in fact, we're now in the Pet Food business. It gives us another [indiscernible] position and so we'll continue to look there and again, those may not be strategic in the short term, but there may be more bolt-ons and smaller acquisitions, but they could be. So anyway, just a short answer, always important to us.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Plans are in the water.
componenttext: Plans are in the water.

componenttext: Got it. And is there a target leverage ratio that you would feel comfortable stabilizing at?

componenttext: Target leverage ratio.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we said is that it's been a little bit of maturation for us as a company. We were always very conservative. And I think now, 2x or 3x, we know is a pretty good number to work around. And we've been pretty vocal to that last 6 to 9 months as we
componenttext: Well, what we said is that it's been a little bit of maturation for us as a company. We were always very conservative. And I think now, 2x or 3x, we know is a pretty good number to work around. And we've been pretty vocal to that last 6 to 9 months as we get closer to that 3x. It just opens up the door a little bit more.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you guys are looking at your largest customer, how much of their improvement in sales is reflected in some of the volume improvement you've seen, especially with regard to promotional and repricing activity?
componenttext: If you guys are looking at your largest customer, how much of their improvement in sales is reflected in some of the volume improvement you've seen, especially with regard to promotional and repricing activity?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Richard. Just first of all, it always helps when your customers are happy and doing well, any customer. And so we're glad to see that they have kind of turned the corner, and that's great. But they didn't drive our growth. This growth is broad-bas
componenttext: This is Richard. Just first of all, it always helps when your customers are happy and doing well, any customer. And so we're glad to see that they have kind of turned the corner, and that's great. But they didn't drive our growth. This growth is broad-based, so that was not driving it.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Chuck. Steve Oakland. We have brands like Folgers that index really, really well there. And those teams are working together very strongly to participate in that. I'd like help drive their category growth. But I would argue that the other traditional
componenttext: Hi, Chuck. Steve Oakland. We have brands like Folgers that index really, really well there. And those teams are working together very strongly to participate in that. I'd like help drive their category growth. But I would argue that the other traditional retailers -- and we typically don't name them, but the top 10 retailers. If you looked at our top 10 list, our numbers are pretty good across that whole top 10 list. But we're pleased to see those guys do well. I mean we all, as an industry, need them to do well to do well longer.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when you look at how consumers are spreading their money across your brands, premium and mainstream, what does that tell you about where the consumers' head at is right now?
componenttext: And when you look at how consumers are spreading their money across your brands, premium and mainstream, what does that tell you about where the consumers' head at is right now?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the consumer's still somewhat cautious. And the great thing about our brands is our brands are pretty well positioned to supply all of our consumers. And so it is a cautious world out there, and we're still a good value. I mean whether it's
componenttext: Well, I think the consumer's still somewhat cautious. And the great thing about our brands is our brands are pretty well positioned to supply all of our consumers. And so it is a cautious world out there, and we're still a good value. I mean whether it's Folgers or whether it's Jif or whether it's Smucker's, it's a good value to the consumer. So our industry had a commodity price environment that's allowed us to be -- to maintain our margins and reflect those prices to the customer base. So we've all enjoyed, not just coffee, but the other commodities have been in a place where we've been able to  -- the market brands provide great price points and innovate, right? So we've got innovation regardless of the business and things that are very high mix and high cost and then provide items in all of our brands, in all of our businesses, to the discount channels to the growth from the dollar industry and those places. So we've been able to participate across the spectrum of channels pretty well. The cost base today, and as we look forward looks, like it's going to help us do that.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Chuck, this is Mark Smucker. Just to reiterate, making sure that we have -- that we are developing and growing our key mainstream brands, but also making sure that we have the right, the truRoots, the Sahale, the Natural Balance, those are brands that
componenttext: And Chuck, this is Mark Smucker. Just to reiterate, making sure that we have -- that we are developing and growing our key mainstream brands, but also making sure that we have the right, the truRoots, the Sahale, the Natural Balance, those are brands that aren't necessarily as big, but certainly, serve a consumer need and are important to our portfolio.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Rob Dickerson with Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: Your next question is from Rob Dickerson with Consumer Edge Research.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a clarification questions and more for Mark. So it sounds like you said in your commentary that adjusted operating profit would be growing about 4%. And I know if you kind of used that 116.6 and your diluted shares, up 30, that implies about another
componenttext: Just a clarification questions and more for Mark. So it sounds like you said in your commentary that adjusted operating profit would be growing about 4%. And I know if you kind of used that 116.6 and your diluted shares, up 30, that implies about another 2.5%. So that gets me to 6.5% EPS growth in '17. Is the assumption here that there are other kind of below-the-line, like the tax rate to be a little bit better, or interest rates comes down a little bit or the interest expense comes down a little bit? And then lastly, if we look at the shares you bought back in Q4, really, in fiscal '16, I mean that's the most amount you've ever spent on a buyback outside of fiscal '14. So could there be additional cash outlays in '17 to incremental buybacks even though you might not have as many as the onetime benefits on your working capital?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple of things. I think the way you're thinking about it from a percent increase is pretty much in line -- the simple math, say, 4% plus operating profit growth, 3% shares and 1 point in tax and interest. So that kind of leads to the 8%. In terms o
componenttext: So a couple of things. I think the way you're thinking about it from a percent increase is pretty much in line -- the simple math, say, 4% plus operating profit growth, 3% shares and 1 point in tax and interest. So that kind of leads to the 8%. In terms of buyback, what we've guided indirectly -- we have conversations, particularly with rating agencies. We kind of used a 2% as a long term model. So that's a 2% buyback. So obviously, 116 million shares [indiscernible] 2.2 share -- 2.2 million shares. So that, as I said on an earlier question, we don't factor that into our plans. I would say our cash deployment would allow a portion of that, maybe not the whole 2% without pushing the leverage target we're going after. But certainly and again, it's situational. So I don't want to sit here and say, we're going out and buy it. But if the opportunity were right, I believe we have the cash to do it, and then obviously, would be incremental. Certainly, when we do it in the year, we'll have less of an impact to do further end of the year. But that's the beauty of being the leverage where we want it to be. It's the flexibility.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow up. On the 4% on the operating profit growth, if I heard you correctly, you said the coffee expectation about the same. They're flat. Consumer should be down a little bit just because or mostly driven by milk and
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow up. On the 4% on the operating profit growth, if I heard you correctly, you said the coffee expectation about the same. They're flat. Consumer should be down a little bit just because or mostly driven by milk and then Pet's up mid-single digits. So if I kind of do that quick math, I'm still getting -- I'm getting to probably as a sub -- sub-4%. So is there -- are you -- have you tried getting some sense as to how your -- or how I should be thinking about each of the segments' growth relative to kind of this rolled up 4% number?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you will have some segment profit growth. It will be a little less than 4% because as we said in our scripted comment, our SD&A is going to be flat year-over-year. So some of that SD&A, clearly, goes up into the business, but also some of th
componenttext: Well, I think you will have some segment profit growth. It will be a little less than 4% because as we said in our scripted comment, our SD&A is going to be flat year-over-year. So some of that SD&A, clearly, goes up into the business, but also some of that falls below in what we would call, admin [ph] support. But it's below the segment profit. So you need a little bit of that benefit to get to 4% on operating profit growth perspective. So you're right, there's a little bit. But again, if you go back, part of the reason is because you put $40 million of marketing in there. So I'm not saying [indiscernible] just to make sure we're all clear on why that is the case.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then bigger picture, right, if we kind of go back to the Analyst Day and how you're investing for growth, et cetera, so the net-net of all this is you have some upside on the corporate side. You're investing a bunch back, but you're not inv
componenttext: All right. And then bigger picture, right, if we kind of go back to the Analyst Day and how you're investing for growth, et cetera, so the net-net of all this is you have some upside on the corporate side. You're investing a bunch back, but you're not investing it all back so that you can still squeeze out, kind of this 3%, 4% operating profit growth? That's the goal internally and externally?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, that's fair. The other comment on the 4%, again, it gets lost a little bit because we're saying that the buyback is offsetting the milk profit loss. If you strip out the milk profit that we incurred in the first 8 months of fiscal '16 that w
componenttext: Yes, I think, that's fair. The other comment on the 4%, again, it gets lost a little bit because we're saying that the buyback is offsetting the milk profit loss. If you strip out the milk profit that we incurred in the first 8 months of fiscal '16 that we owned the business, we're actually growing operating income at 6%. So we're offsetting. It will be negatively impacted when you look at it on reported basis. But you strip that out, we're actually at plus 6.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will now turn the conference call back to management to conclude.
componenttext: I will now turn the conference call back to management to conclude.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. This is Richard. I just wanted to close by saying that I've never been as optimistic about our business, our brands, our employees throughout the company, the best in the industry and the leadership teams, especially the new leadershi
componenttext: Thank you very much. This is Richard. I just wanted to close by saying that I've never been as optimistic about our business, our brands, our employees throughout the company, the best in the industry and the leadership teams, especially the new leadership team we have. I just think we're in a great position. And I want to thank everybody and thank our employees for the wonderful job they're doing and thank all the people on the phone for paying attention, asking great questions. So thank you and more to come -- best is yet to come.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Richard. This is Mark Smucker. Just to add to Richard's comments, I appreciate, of course, Richard's support. And thank all of you on the phone for your time today and your thoughtful questions. And again, just our employees, the phenomenal job
componenttext: Thank you, Richard. This is Mark Smucker. Just to add to Richard's comments, I appreciate, of course, Richard's support. And thank all of you on the phone for your time today and your thoughtful questions. And again, just our employees, the phenomenal job that they have done to deliver this incredible year and the future is bright. So just all of the tremendous efforts that has taken place this year and going forward. Thank you.
