componenttext: So a couple of questions about [indiscernible] and showing that investment. Started talking about the e-commerce strategy at the Investor Day last year. Are you able to dimensionalize how big that is for you as of now how fast it grew last year? I presume the key categories in there are probably coffee and pet food. Which one of those is bigger? Would just like to hear some color on that because we don't see that in the measured channels. And then you mentioned China investments. Can you just give us a little bit of color on how much is spending over there now, what the strategy is over time? And I'll pass it on.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alexia, this is Mark Smucker. I'll start. The first -- your first question just it as it relates to e-commerce is that you're right. We are -- I would say, we're a little bit underdeveloped versus our peers in that space, and so as I talked to Ken's quest
componenttext: Alexia, this is Mark Smucker. I'll start. The first -- your first question just it as it relates to e-commerce is that you're right. We are -- I would say, we're a little bit underdeveloped versus our peers in that space, and so as I talked to Ken's question earlier relative to investments and what we're trying to amp up, that is one of those things. And so not to get into too much specifics, but as we think about -- we actually have just reorganized some of our commercial functions that would include sales and some of our marketing areas. But also in the digital space, we have actually beefed up our capabilities there and are currently in process of reevaluating our total e-commerce strategy and how we better serve our e-commerce customers. And when we think about e-commerce, that includes both the digital-only retailers like Amazon as well as our brick-and-mortar customers that have a significant online presence as well. So a little bit of a general answer. But suffice it to say that it is on our radar screen, and it is a priority for us to continue to develop that business.

And so we've been pleased with that minority investment. As it relates to other things, I think it's just a little bit early for us to give any specifics.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Mario Contreras with Deutsche Bank.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to go back to some of your comments from your Analyst Day last year with respect to coffee, some of the caution around getting back to fiscal 2014 coffee EBIT levels not until 2019. Some of the reason for that was related to investment around
componenttext: So I wanted to go back to some of your comments from your Analyst Day last year with respect to coffee, some of the caution around getting back to fiscal 2014 coffee EBIT levels not until 2019. Some of the reason for that was related to investment around the perfect measures. So obviously, you've already achieved that goal of getting to the profit recovery. But wanted to understand how the investment is going in Perfect Measures? Is that still a major focus point for you guys?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mario, with regard to Perfect Measures, I think, we still think it has the potential and still feel great about it. I'll tell you, the reason you put things in lead markets or in test markets is to learn, and we learned a lot. And our trial numbers, candi
componenttext: Mario, with regard to Perfect Measures, I think, we still think it has the potential and still feel great about it. I'll tell you, the reason you put things in lead markets or in test markets is to learn, and we learned a lot. And our trial numbers, candidly, were not what we needed them to be, but repeat numbers were fantastic. And so it tells us that we probably got the positioning a little wrong. We probably got some of the initial communication a little wrong, but we got the concept right. And so this year, we're going to relaunch that with a little better packaging, a little better messaging. And we're going to -- it's a heavy capital investment because the technology is unique. And we want to make sure we get it just right before we lean into it on a more national scale. We still think the concept has a lot of legs. But we're probably a year behind where we hoped to be at this point. Those investment numbers are baked into the numbers of the guidance that Mark gave earlier, so continued investment in that.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then it had been mentioned a couple of times that increased marketing spending and advertising is included in the guidance for this year. Is there any way you can quantify roughly what that's going to be in terms of your dollar or percent increase?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Pablo Zuanic with SIG.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Pablo Zuanic with SIG.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, a couple of questions on coffee for Steve. And then I have follow-up on Pet Food. Steve, so, Starbucks, our sales [ph] there in January, you talked about -- pretty much implied to threaten to walk away from Keurig, JAB. And then the April call, you
componenttext: Look, a couple of questions on coffee for Steve. And then I have follow-up on Pet Food. Steve, so, Starbucks, our sales [ph] there in January, you talked about -- pretty much implied to threaten to walk away from Keurig, JAB. And then the April call, you came out and said, at least, 3 or 4x in the conference call that they have been able to renegotiate terms at very favorable terms with Keurig and that those terms gave them also more flexibility. So I'm wondering here, if Starbucks can do that with JAB, why can't Smucker's? So if you can comment on that. I'm just surprised that they were able to renegotiate terms now there was a change in ownership there, and, apparently, you haven't. Related to that, I understand the idea of sharpening price points for Folgers and K-Cups. The category has been sticky, of course, while ground moves quite a bit. But as you do that, are we expecting our competitors to also cut prices in their K-Cup brands? And then K-Cups, as a category, will become, not sticky but passthrough as ground. So I see a bit of a risk there. If you can comment on that, please.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess, I wouldn't assume, I wouldn't take the assumption that we haven't done the same kind of work on our K-Cup contract and our relationship with JAB and our -- because we have a legacy relationship with JAB from the Sara Lee acquisition several
componenttext: Sure. I guess, I wouldn't assume, I wouldn't take the assumption that we haven't done the same kind of work on our K-Cup contract and our relationship with JAB and our -- because we have a legacy relationship with JAB from the Sara Lee acquisition several years ago and now from the Keurig remount. so the fact that maybe we're a little less public about some of that stuff, I wouldn't assume that the same things aren't going on. So just different companies manage those things differently, right. So that process is in process, and we feel good about that relationship. They are committed to have the major brands in the category in their systems. And we read the same things you read, so our assumptions are -- going into those negotiations, our assumptions are similar to yours. So we feel fine there. And with regards to K-Cups, if you dig a little deeper into the IRI or Nielsen data, you'll see that K-Cups -- although we don't passthrough green -- because green's kind of a small portion of the overall cost structure, it's become maybe the most promoted category in total cost. So there's the highest reliant -- each one of those brands relies very heavily on promotion. So maybe I'm not clear enough when I talk about leaning in. We've leaned in on our promotional price point mostly. And so those promotional price points are basically down $1 a box from where they used to be. It still means -- it's still a very profitable business. But that migration has already -- that train's already left. So we are where we are. We might have been a little late to follow because of the momentum we had from the Dunkin' business.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just a quick follow-up there. So your K-Cup margins would be lower than your ground coffee margins, right.
componenttext: Understood. And just a quick follow-up there. So your K-Cup margins would be lower than your ground coffee margins, right.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: Yes, a little bit.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, a little bit. Our ground coffee margins are obviously, because of our scale, very, very good. And our K-Cup margins are, although good by consumer product standards, by company standards, aren't quite at that level.
componenttext: Yes, a little bit. Our ground coffee margins are obviously, because of our scale, very, very good. And our K-Cup margins are, although good by consumer product standards, by company standards, aren't quite at that level.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just a follow-up on Pet Food. I guess it's been touched upon already, but can you tell us where did the mix end after the decline in dry dog and dogs in [ph] snacks in specialty. If you can just give us what's the mix and the run rate at the mome
componenttext: And then just a follow-up on Pet Food. If you can just give us what's the mix and the run rate at the moment. And related to that, if you can also comment on the channel mix because we tend to think that snacks and specialty products are mostly in the specialty channel, but just remind us where you are. If I'm looking at the FDM data from IRI or Nielsen, what percentage of your Pet Food business is that and where are you in specialty? If you can provide that roughly on a current run rate, not what it was on average in '16?

componenttext: So you're looking for the channel mix? I just want to make sure we understand the question. You're looking for the change of channel?

componenttextpreview: Well, I'm asking 2 different questions in, I guess, Pet Food, right. Because obviously, you explained that snacks and specialty are doing well in terms of your natural organic brands, Natural Balance. And the other brands are doing well, and dry is not do
componenttext: Well, I'm asking 2 different questions in, I guess, Pet Food, right. Because obviously, you explained that snacks and specialty are doing well in terms of your natural organic brands, Natural Balance. And the other brands are doing well, and dry is not doing so well. So I'm just trying to understand where did the sales mix end in terms of products in fiscal year '16? And then it's a separate question, I think, what is the channel mix, right. Because some of us -- dry dog is also sold in the specialty channel, right, and snacks are sold in both, Natural -- your National balance but only sold in specialty, I understand that. So I'm just trying to get a bit more color in terms of what's your current product mix. And separate, what's your current channel mix if you can provide that.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. From a channel perspective, of our total, total business, about 20% of our business is in the pet specialty. And then Mark, you want to take ...
componenttext: Okay. From a channel perspective, of our total, total business, about 20% of our business is in the pet specialty. And then Mark, you want to take ...

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pablo, this is Mark Belgya. Just to make sure -- again, I think I understand your question. And it goes back to a little bit earlier moment that, if you look at the mix product, okay, we benefit from a mix perspective. So when the growth just occurs, as B
componenttext: Pablo, this is Mark Belgya. Just to make sure -- again, I think I understand your question. And it goes back to a little bit earlier moment that, if you look at the mix product, okay, we benefit from a mix perspective. So when the growth just occurs, as Barry described from a channel perspective, we're also benefiting from a product mix perspective. So whether it's specialty or snacks or even cat probably more than dogs, there's a positive of mix benefit. Obviously, Kibbles 'n Bits is a heavy product. It's a lot of volume. So that's where it's negative, so it's a very positive mix story, a negative overall volume story because of the dry dog side of the equation.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry to insist, but -- so dry dog would be what percent of your sales now, on a run rate now?
componenttext: Sorry to insist, but -- so dry dog would be what percent of your sales now, on a run rate now?

componenttextpreview: Yes, 10%, about 10% of total sales.
componenttext: Yes, 10%, about 10% of total sales.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the only other thing I'd reiterate, because I do think it gets lost occasionally because, particularly as I've had these conversations the last few quarters, clearly, Kibbles 'n Bits has been challenged. But when you look at our, our food business, th
componenttext: And the only other thing I'd reiterate, because I do think it gets lost occasionally because, particularly as I've had these conversations the last few quarters, clearly, Kibbles 'n Bits has been challenged. But when you look at our, our food business, the cat food side of the business is a little bit larger and has done okay, so it has balanced out a little bit. So while not trying to downplay the impact of the Kibbles 'n Bits and the volume and what it's had over the course of the year, the cat food performance has allowed us to manage through the overall food, a little bit more than maybe the takeaway would be.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add -- this is Mark Smucker, is just reminding everyone that the brands that participated in those 2 channels are very different. It's very similar to the natural space in human food where we've got the natural channel with the whol
componenttext: The only thing I would add -- this is Mark Smucker, is just reminding everyone that the brands that participated in those 2 channels are very different. It's very similar to the natural space in human food where we've got the natural channel with the whole foods and the sprouts and the like. In general, there's not a lot of overlap in the brand. So the brands tend to be unique to those individual channels.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Richard and just adding to that for a second. Just any acquisition that we've made -- and again, this acquisition is only 18 months old, once we've integrated these businesses with our sales teams, we've seen some opportunities in channels where o
componenttext: This is Richard and just adding to that for a second. Just any acquisition that we've made -- and again, this acquisition is only 18 months old, once we've integrated these businesses with our sales teams, we've seen some opportunities in channels where our existing sales team have said, hey, we're kind of weak in this channel. And with the relationships we have with these customers, we can really grow the business. And it takes a little while to identify that and then build those additional sales with those customers. And we're just in the process of doing that. So we're pretty optimistic about finding those key customers that we can build our business with. So we should see some more growth this year in a number of those channels. Don't you agree with that?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do, Richard. And just maybe to add on to the Meow Mix conversation is some of our best innovation this year is against the Meow Mix brand. And to your point, our sales team has done an outstanding job getting acceptance of that product in the market and
componenttext: I do, Richard. And just maybe to add on to the Meow Mix conversation is some of our best innovation this year is against the Meow Mix brand. And to your point, our sales team has done an outstanding job getting acceptance of that product in the market and especially in the grocery channel. So where we have an outstanding sales team that can execute there. So again, Mark to your point, Meow Mix is one of our largest brands in our portfolio. And with some of that innovation, we see some nice growth coming from that brand here.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I just wanted to follow up on the net sales growth expectation and just try and dig in a little bit more at the segment level. Thank you for the commentary on pet. But I guess, Mark Belgya, is there any more visibility you can give us on that 1% e
componenttext: I guess I just wanted to follow up on the net sales growth expectation and just try and dig in a little bit more at the segment level. Thank you for the commentary on pet. But I guess, Mark Belgya, is there any more visibility you can give us on that 1% ex divestiture sales growth, how FX plays into that and how we should be thinking about it by segment across the rest of it?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I'd say, Matt, is that about -- the coffee pricing would be about 1 point of the overall company. So you can kind of dollar-ize that to guess how much the coffee would be. That's, by far, the biggest driver from the downside. So if you take
componenttext: I guess, what I'd say, Matt, is that about -- the coffee pricing would be about 1 point of the overall company. So you can kind of dollar-ize that to guess how much the coffee would be. That's, by far, the biggest driver from the downside. So if you take the milk loss, the $150 million I mentioned earlier, and then you had 1% of sales, so call it, somewhere between $70 million, $90 million on coffee pricing, that's the 2 big negatives. So you just do the math, it kind of attribute to the rest of the business, that it'd give you a sense -- obviously, the FX has a little bit of an effect, but it's actually not a big driver in the overall 1% decline to the total net sales.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. That helps. And I guess just really quick follow-up on the Dunkin' K-Cup issue. You talked about some of the untapped adjacency opportunities in flavorings and line extensions. Your market share's sort of stabilized over the past 6 months
componenttext: Okay, all right. That helps. And I guess just really quick follow-up on the Dunkin' K-Cup issue. You talked about some of the untapped adjacency opportunities in flavorings and line extensions. Your market share's sort of stabilized over the past 6 months. It's pretty close to where your share is in roast and ground. Right now, can you just give us a sense of sort of where you see -- in terms of growth opportunities, how much of that is dependent on holding that share, participating in category growth as opposed to continuing to push share higher into that high single-digit range? And what do you think is feasible?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matthew, I think, it'll vary by business. I think, there's still runway for the Dunkin' business. There's some core flavors on Dunkin', and Dunkin' tends to be a more flavor-driven business. So there's some new item opportunity on the Dunkin' brand. And t
componenttext: Matthew, I think, it'll vary by business. I think, there's still runway for the Dunkin' business. There's some core flavors on Dunkin', and Dunkin' tends to be a more flavor-driven business. So there's some new item opportunity on the Dunkin' brand. And then, quite frankly, now that the Folgers brand is in the right price points, getting the right support both from the retailers and the consumer segment, it'll be better execution of our promotion strategies on Folgers. So we'll execute there on Folgers...

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple -- 2 questions. One on coffee. Can you just explain to us or break out of the 18% growth that you saw in operating income or segment operating income, how much of that was a result of pricing net of commodity cost? And what is the general expe
componenttext: So a couple -- 2 questions. One on coffee. Can you just explain to us or break out of the 18% growth that you saw in operating income or segment operating income, how much of that was a result of pricing net of commodity cost? And what is the general expectation for pricing net of commodities for '17? That's the first question, and then I have a follow-up on pet.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, it's a balance -- I would say part of it is pricing. And the timing of the pricing is important to think about. We talked, I believe, in our first quarter call a year ago, that we leaned in and we took pricing early. We had good coverage, and
componenttext: I would say, it's a balance -- I would say part of it is pricing. And the timing of the pricing is important to think about. We talked, I believe, in our first quarter call a year ago, that we leaned in and we took pricing early. We had good coverage, and we had an opinion inthe market that we were going to get that money back in green, which we did in the fourth quarter. So in the fourth quarter, obviously, green pricing to cost was a bigger impact, but we sort of spent that money upfront. So I would say it's a combination of that green pricing. When you get your #1 -- your high-volume item, when you get volume up on those canisters, and our facilities do it, it really -- it falls to the bottom line, so that's very efficient for us. So Mark, I know Mark's digging for the exact percentage number as we speak. But it's a balance between the volume it generated and the implications of that volume all the way through the system on Red Can and then the pricing.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And it's probably a little bit heavier on the price cost, maybe 2/3, 1/3-ish. But again, I think that goes back to what you said to Steve quite a while ago, which was just sort of the weight of the timing on the pricing.
componenttext: And it's probably a little bit heavier on the price cost, maybe 2/3, 1/3-ish. But again, I think that goes back to what you said to Steve quite a while ago, which was just sort of the weight of the timing on the pricing.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the volume allowed us to bring more green in the end, and the green at the end was more favorable. So it's really hard to get it down to a knit on that. Because you recognize those PPBs when the green comes in. And if your volumes up, you bring more o
componenttext: And the volume allowed us to bring more green in the end, and the green at the end was more favorable. So it's really hard to get it down to a knit on that. Because you recognize those PPBs when the green comes in. And if your volumes up, you bring more of the green in.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttextpreview: There's some quality of the earnings -- and I'll start. Barry, if you want to jump in. If you look over the course, I mean, this quarter specifically, we knew market was going to be down a little bit from where it was because of the timing of the product.
componenttext: There's some quality of the earnings -- and I'll start. Barry, if you want to jump in. If you look over the course, I mean, this quarter specifically, we knew market was going to be down a little bit from where it was because of the timing of the product. But we also had the synergy recognition, which picked up in the latter part. So if you go back to what was [ph] the early part of the year, we expected quarter-over-quarter improvement on margin, which we delivered on in Q2, 3 and 4. I think from a cost perspective going forward, the costs aligned very similar to what we've seen our Consumer Foods. So the green continued to be favorable. I think as Barry mentioned, we are going to continue bonus bags and things like that, that might have a little bit of effect on gross profit. And then, of course, I think, as we said over time, of the 3 segments of the business, the natural has the lowest profitability. And I think Barry and his team worked -- and as well if you integrate that into the overall Smucker companies, there's probably an opportunity there as well.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Mark. Yes, our quality of [indiscernible] is solid for F'17. If you think about mix, too, just as our snacks continue to drive the business, that is where the strongest margins on the business are as well. We've seen -- even cat snacks, small
componenttext: Absolutely, Mark. Yes, our quality of [indiscernible] is solid for F'17. If you think about mix, too, just as our snacks continue to drive the business, that is where the strongest margins on the business are as well. We've seen -- even cat snacks, small category but tremendous upside there. So I think we have very solid quality earnings for next year. We haven't made any significant cuts to get to our growth number for next year, year-over-year.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: And just one last one for Mark. You talked about organizational structural change. Can you give us some more color on that?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mark Smucker. Not really. I don't think we really can give you any more color other than to say that as we -- this was a huge year. And not only did we make the largest acquisition in our history, but that acquisition was, again, the catalyst to sort
componenttext: It's Mark Smucker. Not really. I don't think we really can give you any more color other than to say that as we -- this was a huge year. And not only did we make the largest acquisition in our history, but that acquisition was, again, the catalyst to sort of think about things like are we going to market in the most efficient way. Do we have the right capabilities to engage our consumer and our customer? We recently opened our innovation center, which is very much all about our customer retail partners. And so the long and short of it is, as we looked at our organization, we took some opportunity across not only our commercial functions, which would be sales and marketing and thinking about how we would organize those differently, but we looked across our supply chain network, our finance organization, our -- some of our administrative functions as well just to make sure that we were running them in the most efficient way. I would say that one of the key things is that -- as I mentioned in the script, we have an individual from Big Heart who is leading our growth and innovation organization. And so we are putting sort of a renewed focus on -- not that we haven't. We've done a good job on innovation but making sure that our muscle, where we're building muscle is really around innovation longer term and making sure that our understanding of the consumer is sharp and that we can act against insights that we are learning about the consumer as we go forward. So I think that's probably it.

componenttextpreview: This is Gregory Nep for Farha. I just have a quick question. So given sort of the excellent cash flow and success taking down leverage, can you share with us whether there may be opportunities for further M&A and just your view on the M&A environment righ
componenttext: This is Gregory Nep for Farha. I just have a quick question. So given sort of the excellent cash flow and success taking down leverage, can you share with us whether there may be opportunities for further M&A and just your view on the M&A environment right now?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mark Belgya. I mean, I'll start and Richard or Mark, if you want to add more from a strategic perspective. But as we look at our deployment of cash coming out of the deal last year, we, obviously, emphasized the importance of paying down debt
componenttext: Yes, this is Mark Belgya. I mean, I'll start and Richard or Mark, if you want to add more from a strategic perspective. But as we look at our deployment of cash coming out of the deal last year, we, obviously, emphasized the importance of paying down debt over the course of 3 to 5 years, which we've made great progress on, and as I said earlier, it allowed us to get back into repurchasing shares. We feel very comfortable with the $1 billion of free cash flow that we'll be able to continue that debt paydown planned, obviously, continue our dividend payout policies. And it allows us a little bit of flexibility as strategic options come in. So whether that's M&A -- again, I don't think we're looking at a huge transformational like a pet, at least from a leverage perspective. But certainly, there's M&A opportunity as well as buyback. And I think, buybacks are situational. So we traditionally do not build that into our plan. But if you ask me what is one of the opportunities for any upside of that range, you'd have to throw buyback as an opportunity in there.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is Richard. Just strategically, acquisitions are the key factor of our growth over long term. And so we still continue to look for those opportunities. And in fact, we're now in the Pet Food business. It gives us another lake to fish in, and so w
componenttext: And this is Richard. Just strategically, acquisitions are the key factor of our growth over long term. And so we still continue to look for those opportunities. And in fact, we're now in the Pet Food business. It gives us another lake to fish in, and so we'll continue to look there, and again, those may not be strategic in the short term, but they may be more bolt-ons and smaller acquisitions, but they could be. So anyway, that's just a short answer but always important to us.

componenttext: This is Richard. Just first of all, it always helps when your customers are happy and doing well, any customer. And so we're glad to see that they kind of turned the corner, and that's great. But they didn't drive our growth. This growth is broad based, so that was not driving it.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: Hi, Chuck. Steve Oakland. We have brands like Folgers that index really, really well there. And those teams are working together very strongly to participate in that. I'd like to help drive their category growth. But I would argue that the other traditional retailers -- and we typically don't name them, but the top 10 retailers, if you looked at our top 10 list, our numbers are pretty good across that whole top 10 list. But we're pleased to see those guys do well. I mean, we all, as an industry, need them to do well to do well longer.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when you look at how consumers are spreading their money across your brands, premium and mainstream, what does that tell you about where the consumers' head at is right now?
componenttext: And when you look at how consumers are spreading their money across your brands, premium and mainstream, what does that tell you about where the consumers' head at is right now?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the consumer's still somewhat cautious. And the great thing about our brands is our brands are pretty well positioned to supply all of our consumers. And so it is a cautious world out there, and we're still a good value. I mean, whether it's
componenttext: Well, I think the consumer's still somewhat cautious. And the great thing about our brands is our brands are pretty well positioned to supply all of our consumers. And so it is a cautious world out there, and we're still a good value. I mean, whether it's Folgers or whether it's Jif or whether it's Smucker's, it's a good value to the consumer. So and our industry, Richard [ph], has had a commodity price environment that's allowed us to be -- to maintain our margins and reflect those prices to the customer base. So we've all enjoyed, not just coffee but the other commodities have been in a place where we've been able to -- to the market the brands, provide great price points and innovate, right. So we've got innovation regardless of the business that -- and things that are very high mix and high cost and then provide items in all of our brands, in all of our businesses, to the discount channels to the growth from the dollar industry and those places that -- so we've been able to participate across the spectrum of channels pretty well. The cost base today, and as we look forward looks, like it's going to help us do that.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Chuck, this is Mark Smucker. Just to reiterate, making sure that we -- that we are developing and growing our key mainstream brands but also making sure that we have the right, the truRoots, the Sahale, the Natural Balance. Those are brands that aren'
componenttext: And Chuck, this is Mark Smucker. Just to reiterate, making sure that we -- that we are developing and growing our key mainstream brands but also making sure that we have the right, the truRoots, the Sahale, the Natural Balance. Those are brands that aren't necessarily as big but certainly serve a consumer need and are important to our portfolio.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a clarification question and more for Mark. So it sounds like you said in your commentary that adjusted operating profit will be growing about 4%. And I know if we kind of like use that 116.6 million in your diluted shares outstanding, that implies a
componenttext: Just a clarification question and more for Mark. So it sounds like you said in your commentary that adjusted operating profit will be growing about 4%. And I know if we kind of like use that 116.6 million in your diluted shares outstanding, that implies about another 2.5%. So that gets me to 6.5% EPS growth in '17. Is the assumption here that there are other kind of below-the-line -- like the tax rate could be a little bit better, interest rate comes down a little bit or the interest expense comes down a little bit. And then lastly, if we look at the shares you bought back in Q4, really, in fiscal '16, I mean, that's the most amount you've ever spent on a buyback outside of fiscal '14. So could there be additional cash outlays in '17 to incremental buybacks even though you might not have as many of the onetime benefits on your working cap?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple things. I think the way you're thinking about it from a percent increase is pretty much in line. The simple math would say 4% plus operating profit growth, 3% shares and 1 point in tax and interest. So that kind of gets you to the 8%. In terms
componenttext: So a couple things. I think the way you're thinking about it from a percent increase is pretty much in line. The simple math would say 4% plus operating profit growth, 3% shares and 1 point in tax and interest. So that kind of gets you to the 8%. In terms of buyback, what we've guided indirectly -- we have conversations, particularly with rating agencies. We kind of use a 2% as a long-term model. So that's a 2% buyback. So obviously, at a 116 million shares of -- 2.2 share -- 2.2 million shares. So that, as I said on your earlier question, we don't factor that into our plans. I would say our cash deployment would allow a portion of that, maybe not the whole 2% without pushing the leverage target we're going after. But certainly -- and again, it's situational. So I don't want to sit here and say, we're going out and buy it. But if the opportunity were right, I believe we have the cash to do it, and then obviously, it would be incremental. Certainly, when we do it in the year, we'll have less of an impact to do further into the year. But that's the beauty of being the leverage where we want it to be. It's the flexibility.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up. On the 4% on the operating profit growth, if I heard you correctly, you said the coffee expectation about the same. They're flat. Consumer should be down a little bit just because -- or mostly driven by milk,
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up. On the 4% on the operating profit growth, if I heard you correctly, you said the coffee expectation about the same. They're flat. Consumer should be down a little bit just because -- or mostly driven by milk, and then pet's up mid-single digit. So if I kind of do that quick math, I'm still getting -- I'm getting to probably as a sub -- sub-4%. So is there -- are you -- have you tried getting a sense as to how your -- or how I should be thinking about each of the segments' growth relative to kind of this rolled up 4% number?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you will have some segment profit growth. It'll be a little less than 4% because, as we said in our scripted comments, our SD&A is going to be flat year-over-year. So some of that SD&A, clearly, goes up into the business but also some of tha
componenttext: Well, I think you will have some segment profit growth. It'll be a little less than 4% because, as we said in our scripted comments, our SD&A is going to be flat year-over-year. So some of that SD&A, clearly, goes up into the business but also some of that falls below in what we would call admin support. But it's below the segment profit. So when you need a little bit of that benefit to get to 4% on operating profit growth perspective. So you're right. There's a little bit. But again, if you go back, part of their reasoning is because you put $40 million of marketing in there. So I'm not saying [indiscernible] impact but just to make sure we're all clear on why that is the case.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then a bigger picture, right. I think if we kind of go back to the Analyst Day and how you're investing for growth, et cetera, so the net-net of all this is you have some upside on the corporate side. You're investing a bunch back, but you'
componenttext: All right. And then a bigger picture, right. I think if we kind of go back to the Analyst Day and how you're investing for growth, et cetera, so the net-net of all this is you have some upside on the corporate side. You're investing a bunch back, but you're not investing it all back so you can still squeeze out kind of this 3%, 4% operating profit growth. That's the goal internally and externally.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, that's fair. The other comment on the 4%, again, it gets lost a little bit because we're saying that the buyback is offsetting the milk profit loss. If you strip out the milk profit that we incurred in the first 8 months of fiscal '16 that w
componenttext: Yes, I think, that's fair. The other comment on the 4%, again, it gets lost a little bit because we're saying that the buyback is offsetting the milk profit loss. If you strip out the milk profit that we incurred in the first 8 months of fiscal '16 that we owned the business, we're actually growing operating income at 6%. So we're offsetting it, so we're being negatively impacted when you look at it on a reported basis. But you strip that out, we're actually up plus 6.
