componenttext: I guess I just wanted to follow up on the net sales growth expectation and just try and dig in a little bit more at the segment level. Thank you for the commentary on pet. But I guess, Mark Belgya, is there any more visibility you can give us on that 1% ex divestiture sales growth, how FX plays into that and how we should be thinking about it by segment across the rest of it?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, what I'd say, Matt, is that about -- the coffee pricing would be about 1 point of the overall company. So you can kind of dollar-ize that to guess how much the coffee would be. That's, by far, the biggest driver from the downside. So if you take
componenttext: I guess, what I'd say, Matt, is that about -- the coffee pricing would be about 1 point of the overall company. So you can kind of dollar-ize that to guess how much the coffee would be. That's, by far, the biggest driver from the downside. So if you take the milk loss, the $150 million I mentioned earlier, and then you had 1% of sales, so call it, somewhere between $70 million, $90 million on coffee pricing, that's the 2 big negatives. So you just do the math, it kind of attribute to the rest of the business, that it'd give you a sense -- obviously, the FX has a little bit of an effect, but it's actually not a big driver in the overall 1% decline to the total net sales.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, all right. That helps. And I guess just really quick follow-up on the Dunkin' K-Cup issue. You talked about some of the untapped adjacency opportunities in flavorings and line extensions. Your market share's sort of stabilized over the past 6 months
componenttext: Okay, all right. That helps. And I guess just really quick follow-up on the Dunkin' K-Cup issue. You talked about some of the untapped adjacency opportunities in flavorings and line extensions. Your market share's sort of stabilized over the past 6 months. It's pretty close to where your share is in roast and ground. Right now, can you just give us a sense of sort of where you see -- in terms of growth opportunities, how much of that is dependent on holding that share, participating in category growth as opposed to continuing to push share higher into that high single-digit range? And what do you think is feasible?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matthew, I think, it'll vary by business. I think, there's still runway for the Dunkin' business. There's some core flavors on Dunkin', and Dunkin' tends to be a more flavor-driven business. So there's some new item opportunity on the Dunkin' brand. And t
componenttext: Matthew, I think, it'll vary by business. I think, there's still runway for the Dunkin' business. There's some core flavors on Dunkin', and Dunkin' tends to be a more flavor-driven business. So there's some new item opportunity on the Dunkin' brand. And then, quite frankly, now that the Folgers brand is in the right price points, getting the right support both from the retailers and the consumer segment, it'll be better execution of our promotion strategies on Folgers. So we'll execute there on Folgers...

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: So a couple -- 2 questions. One on coffee. Can you just explain to us or break out of the 18% growth that you saw in operating income or segment operating income, how much of that was a result of pricing net of commodity cost? And what is the general expectation for pricing net of commodities for '17? That's the first question, and then I have a follow-up on pet.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, it's a balance -- I would say part of it is pricing. And the timing of the pricing is important to think about. We talked, I believe, in our first quarter call a year ago, that we leaned in and we took pricing early. We had good coverage, and
componenttext: I would say, it's a balance -- I would say part of it is pricing. And the timing of the pricing is important to think about. We talked, I believe, in our first quarter call a year ago, that we leaned in and we took pricing early. We had good coverage, and we had an opinion inthe market that we were going to get that money back in green, which we did in the fourth quarter. So in the fourth quarter, obviously, green pricing to cost was a bigger impact, but we sort of spent that money upfront. So I would say it's a combination of that green pricing. When you get your #1 -- your high-volume item, when you get volume up on those canisters, and our facilities do it, it really -- it falls to the bottom line, so that's very efficient for us. So Mark, I know Mark's digging for the exact percentage number as we speak. But it's a balance between the volume it generated and the implications of that volume all the way through the system on Red Can and then the pricing.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And it's probably a little bit heavier on the price cost, maybe 2/3, 1/3-ish. But again, I think that goes back to what you said to Steve quite a while ago, which was just sort of the weight of the timing on the pricing.
componenttext: And it's probably a little bit heavier on the price cost, maybe 2/3, 1/3-ish. But again, I think that goes back to what you said to Steve quite a while ago, which was just sort of the weight of the timing on the pricing.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the volume allowed us to bring more green in the end, and the green at the end was more favorable. So it's really hard to get it down to a knit on that. Because you recognize those PPBs when the green comes in. And if your volumes up, you bring more o
componenttext: And the volume allowed us to bring more green in the end, and the green at the end was more favorable. So it's really hard to get it down to a knit on that. Because you recognize those PPBs when the green comes in. And if your volumes up, you bring more of the green in.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's some quality of the earnings -- and I'll start. Barry, if you want to jump in. If you look over the course, I mean, this quarter specifically, we knew market was going to be down a little bit from where it was because of the timing of the product.
componenttext: There's some quality of the earnings -- and I'll start. Barry, if you want to jump in. If you look over the course, I mean, this quarter specifically, we knew market was going to be down a little bit from where it was because of the timing of the product. But we also had the synergy recognition, which picked up in the latter part. So if you go back to what was [ph] the early part of the year, we expected quarter-over-quarter improvement on margin, which we delivered on in Q2, 3 and 4. I think from a cost perspective going forward, the costs aligned very similar to what we've seen our Consumer Foods. So the green continued to be favorable. I think as Barry mentioned, we are going to continue bonus bags and things like that, that might have a little bit of effect on gross profit. And then, of course, I think, as we said over time, of the 3 segments of the business, the natural has the lowest profitability. And I think Barry and his team worked -- and as well if you integrate that into the overall Smucker companies, there's probably an opportunity there as well.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, Mark. Yes, our quality of [indiscernible] is solid for F'17. If you think about mix, too, just as our snacks continue to drive the business, that is where the strongest margins on the business are as well. We've seen -- even cat snacks, small
componenttext: Absolutely, Mark. Yes, our quality of [indiscernible] is solid for F'17. If you think about mix, too, just as our snacks continue to drive the business, that is where the strongest margins on the business are as well. We've seen -- even cat snacks, small category but tremendous upside there. So I think we have very solid quality earnings for next year. We haven't made any significant cuts to get to our growth number for next year, year-over-year.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one last one for Mark. You talked about organizational structural change. Can you give us some more color on that?
componenttext: And just one last one for Mark. You talked about organizational structural change. Can you give us some more color on that?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Mark Smucker. Not really. I don't think we really can give you any more color other than to say that as we -- this was a huge year. And not only did we make the largest acquisition in our history, but that acquisition was, again, the catalyst to sort
componenttext: It's Mark Smucker. Not really. I don't think we really can give you any more color other than to say that as we -- this was a huge year. And not only did we make the largest acquisition in our history, but that acquisition was, again, the catalyst to sort of think about things like are we going to market in the most efficient way. Do we have the right capabilities to engage our consumer and our customer? We recently opened our innovation center, which is very much all about our customer retail partners. And so the long and short of it is, as we looked at our organization, we took some opportunity across not only our commercial functions, which would be sales and marketing and thinking about how we would organize those differently, but we looked across our supply chain network, our finance organization, our -- some of our administrative functions as well just to make sure that we were running them in the most efficient way. I would say that one of the key things is that -- as I mentioned in the script, we have an individual from Big Heart who is leading our growth and innovation organization. And so we are putting sort of a renewed focus on -- not that we haven't. We've done a good job on innovation but making sure that our muscle, where we're building muscle is really around innovation longer term and making sure that our understanding of the consumer is sharp and that we can act against insights that we are learning about the consumer as we go forward. So I think that's probably it.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Farha Aslam with Stephens Inc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Farha Aslam with Stephens Inc.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gregory Nep for Farha. I just have a quick question. So given sort of the excellent cash flow and success taking down leverage, can you share with us whether there may be opportunities for further M&A and just your view on the M&A environment righ
componenttext: This is Gregory Nep for Farha. I just have a quick question. So given sort of the excellent cash flow and success taking down leverage, can you share with us whether there may be opportunities for further M&A and just your view on the M&A environment right now?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Mark Belgya. I mean, I'll start and Richard or Mark, if you want to add more from a strategic perspective. But as we look at our deployment of cash coming out of the deal last year, we, obviously, emphasized the importance of paying down debt
componenttext: Yes, this is Mark Belgya. I mean, I'll start and Richard or Mark, if you want to add more from a strategic perspective. But as we look at our deployment of cash coming out of the deal last year, we, obviously, emphasized the importance of paying down debt over the course of 3 to 5 years, which we've made great progress on, and as I said earlier, it allowed us to get back into repurchasing shares. We feel very comfortable with the $1 billion of free cash flow that we'll be able to continue that debt paydown planned, obviously, continue our dividend payout policies. And it allows us a little bit of flexibility as strategic options come in. So whether that's M&A -- again, I don't think we're looking at a huge transformational like a pet, at least from a leverage perspective. But certainly, there's M&A opportunity as well as buyback. And I think, buybacks are situational. So we traditionally do not build that into our plan. But if you ask me what is one of the opportunities for any upside of that range, you'd have to throw buyback as an opportunity in there.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is Richard. Just strategically, acquisitions are the key factor of our growth over long term. And so we still continue to look for those opportunities. And in fact, we're now in the Pet Food business. It gives us another lake to fish in, and so w
componenttext: And this is Richard. Just strategically, acquisitions are the key factor of our growth over long term. And so we still continue to look for those opportunities. And in fact, we're now in the Pet Food business. It gives us another lake to fish in, and so we'll continue to look there, and again, those may not be strategic in the short term, but they may be more bolt-ons and smaller acquisitions, but they could be. So anyway, that's just a short answer but always important to us.

componenttext: Lines are in the water.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, what we said is that it's been a little bit of maturation for us as a company. We were always very conservative. And I think now, 2 or 3x, we know is a pretty good number to work around. And we've been pretty vocal to that the last 6 to 9 months. As
componenttext: Well, what we said is that it's been a little bit of maturation for us as a company. We were always very conservative. And I think now, 2 or 3x, we know is a pretty good number to work around. And we've been pretty vocal to that the last 6 to 9 months. As we get closer to that 3x, it just opens up the door a little bit more.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Chuck Cerankosky with Northcoast Research.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you guys are looking at your largest customer, how much of their improvement in sales is reflected in some of the volume improvement you've seen, especially with regard to promotional and repricing activity?
componenttext: If you guys are looking at your largest customer, how much of their improvement in sales is reflected in some of the volume improvement you've seen, especially with regard to promotional and repricing activity?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Richard. Just first of all, it always helps when your customers are happy and doing well, any customer. And so we're glad to see that they kind of turned the corner, and that's great. But they didn't drive our growth. This growth is broad based, s
componenttext: This is Richard. Just first of all, it always helps when your customers are happy and doing well, any customer. And so we're glad to see that they kind of turned the corner, and that's great. But they didn't drive our growth. This growth is broad based, so that was not driving it.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Chuck. Steve Oakland. We have brands like Folgers that index really, really well there. And those teams are working together very strongly to participate in that. I'd like to help drive their category growth. But I would argue that the other tradition
componenttext: Hi, Chuck. Steve Oakland. We have brands like Folgers that index really, really well there. And those teams are working together very strongly to participate in that. I'd like to help drive their category growth. But I would argue that the other traditional retailers -- and we typically don't name them, but the top 10 retailers, if you looked at our top 10 list, our numbers are pretty good across that whole top 10 list. But we're pleased to see those guys do well. I mean, we all, as an industry, need them to do well to do well longer.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And when you look at how consumers are spreading their money across your brands, premium and mainstream, what does that tell you about where the consumers' head at is right now?
componenttext: And when you look at how consumers are spreading their money across your brands, premium and mainstream, what does that tell you about where the consumers' head at is right now?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the consumer's still somewhat cautious. And the great thing about our brands is our brands are pretty well positioned to supply all of our consumers. And so it is a cautious world out there, and we're still a good value. I mean, whether it's
componenttext: Well, I think the consumer's still somewhat cautious. And the great thing about our brands is our brands are pretty well positioned to supply all of our consumers. And so it is a cautious world out there, and we're still a good value. I mean, whether it's Folgers or whether it's Jif or whether it's Smucker's, it's a good value to the consumer. So and our industry, Richard [ph], has had a commodity price environment that's allowed us to be -- to maintain our margins and reflect those prices to the customer base. So we've all enjoyed, not just coffee but the other commodities have been in a place where we've been able to -- to the market the brands, provide great price points and innovate, right. So we've got innovation regardless of the business that -- and things that are very high mix and high cost and then provide items in all of our brands, in all of our businesses, to the discount channels to the growth from the dollar industry and those places that -- so we've been able to participate across the spectrum of channels pretty well. The cost base today, and as we look forward looks, like it's going to help us do that.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Chuck, this is Mark Smucker. Just to reiterate, making sure that we -- that we are developing and growing our key mainstream brands but also making sure that we have the right, the truRoots, the Sahale, the Natural Balance. Those are brands that aren'
componenttext: And Chuck, this is Mark Smucker. Just to reiterate, making sure that we -- that we are developing and growing our key mainstream brands but also making sure that we have the right, the truRoots, the Sahale, the Natural Balance. Those are brands that aren't necessarily as big but certainly serve a consumer need and are important to our portfolio.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Rob Dickerson with Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: Your next question is from Rob Dickerson with Consumer Edge Research.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a clarification question and more for Mark. So it sounds like you said in your commentary that adjusted operating profit will be growing about 4%. And I know if we kind of like use that 116.6 million in your diluted shares outstanding, that implies a
componenttext: Just a clarification question and more for Mark. So it sounds like you said in your commentary that adjusted operating profit will be growing about 4%. And I know if we kind of like use that 116.6 million in your diluted shares outstanding, that implies about another 2.5%. So that gets me to 6.5% EPS growth in '17. Is the assumption here that there are other kind of below-the-line -- like the tax rate could be a little bit better, interest rate comes down a little bit or the interest expense comes down a little bit. And then lastly, if we look at the shares you bought back in Q4, really, in fiscal '16, I mean, that's the most amount you've ever spent on a buyback outside of fiscal '14. So could there be additional cash outlays in '17 to incremental buybacks even though you might not have as many of the onetime benefits on your working cap?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: So a couple things. I think the way you're thinking about it from a percent increase is pretty much in line. The simple math would say 4% plus operating profit growth, 3% shares and 1 point in tax and interest. So that kind of gets you to the 8%. In terms
componenttext: So a couple things. I think the way you're thinking about it from a percent increase is pretty much in line. The simple math would say 4% plus operating profit growth, 3% shares and 1 point in tax and interest. So that kind of gets you to the 8%. In terms of buyback, what we've guided indirectly -- we have conversations, particularly with rating agencies. We kind of use a 2% as a long-term model. So that's a 2% buyback. So obviously, at a 116 million shares of -- 2.2 share -- 2.2 million shares. So that, as I said on your earlier question, we don't factor that into our plans. I would say our cash deployment would allow a portion of that, maybe not the whole 2% without pushing the leverage target we're going after. But certainly -- and again, it's situational. So I don't want to sit here and say, we're going out and buy it. But if the opportunity were right, I believe we have the cash to do it, and then obviously, it would be incremental. Certainly, when we do it in the year, we'll have less of an impact to do further into the year. But that's the beauty of being the leverage where we want it to be. It's the flexibility.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up. On the 4% on the operating profit growth, if I heard you correctly, you said the coffee expectation about the same. They're flat. Consumer should be down a little bit just because -- or mostly driven by milk,
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just a quick follow-up. On the 4% on the operating profit growth, if I heard you correctly, you said the coffee expectation about the same. They're flat. Consumer should be down a little bit just because -- or mostly driven by milk, and then pet's up mid-single digit. So if I kind of do that quick math, I'm still getting -- I'm getting to probably as a sub -- sub-4%. So is there -- are you -- have you tried getting a sense as to how your -- or how I should be thinking about each of the segments' growth relative to kind of this rolled up 4% number?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you will have some segment profit growth. It'll be a little less than 4% because, as we said in our scripted comments, our SD&A is going to be flat year-over-year. So some of that SD&A, clearly, goes up into the business but also some of tha
componenttext: Well, I think you will have some segment profit growth. It'll be a little less than 4% because, as we said in our scripted comments, our SD&A is going to be flat year-over-year. So some of that SD&A, clearly, goes up into the business but also some of that falls below in what we would call admin support. But it's below the segment profit. So when you need a little bit of that benefit to get to 4% on operating profit growth perspective. So you're right. There's a little bit. But again, if you go back, part of their reasoning is because you put $40 million of marketing in there. So I'm not saying [indiscernible] impact but just to make sure we're all clear on why that is the case.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then a bigger picture, right. I think if we kind of go back to the Analyst Day and how you're investing for growth, et cetera, so the net-net of all this is you have some upside on the corporate side. You're investing a bunch back, but you'
componenttext: All right. And then a bigger picture, right. I think if we kind of go back to the Analyst Day and how you're investing for growth, et cetera, so the net-net of all this is you have some upside on the corporate side. You're investing a bunch back, but you're not investing it all back so you can still squeeze out kind of this 3%, 4% operating profit growth. That's the goal internally and externally.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Jun 09, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, that's fair. The other comment on the 4%, again, it gets lost a little bit because we're saying that the buyback is offsetting the milk profit loss. If you strip out the milk profit that we incurred in the first 8 months of fiscal '16 that w
componenttext: Yes, I think, that's fair. The other comment on the 4%, again, it gets lost a little bit because we're saying that the buyback is offsetting the milk profit loss. If you strip out the milk profit that we incurred in the first 8 months of fiscal '16 that we owned the business, we're actually growing operating income at 6%. So we're offsetting it, so we're being negatively impacted when you look at it on a reported basis. But you strip that out, we're actually up plus 6.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to The J.M. Smucker Company's Fiscal 2017 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the conference over to Aaron Broholm, Vice President, Investor Relations
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to The J.M. Smucker Company's Fiscal 2017 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the conference over to Aaron Broholm, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our first quarter earnings conference call. With me today and presenting our prepared comments are Mark Smucker, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Belgya, Vice Chair and Chief Financial Office
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our first quarter earnings conference call. With me today and presenting our prepared comments are Mark Smucker, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Belgya, Vice Chair and Chief Financial Officer. Also joining us for the Q&A portion of the call are Steve Oakland, Vice Chair and President, U.S. Food and Beverage; and Barry Dunaway, President, Pet Food and Pet Snacks. 
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements that reflect the company's current expectations about future plans and performance. These statements rely on a number of assumptions and estimates, and actual results may differ materially due to risks and uncertainties. I encourage you to read the full disclosure concerning forward-looking statements in this morning's press release, which is located on our corporate website at jmsmucker.com. 
Additionally, please note the company uses non-GAAP results for the purpose of evaluating performance internally as detailed in the press release. We have also posted to our website a supplementary slide deck summarizing first quarter results, which can be accessed through the link to the webcast of this call. These slides and a replay of this call will be archived on our website. 
On July 25, we issued a Form 8-K regarding our new definition of segment profit and non-GAAP operating income, income and earnings per share, all of which now exclude intangible amortization expense. Modified prior year results that reflect this new definition were included in the Form 8-K. Please note, we now refer to our non-GAAP profit measures as adjusted gross profit, operating income, income and earnings per share. If you have any questions after today's call, please contact me. 
I will now turn the call over to Mark Smucker.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Aaron. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. This is truly an exciting time at Smucker. As we look to continue the momentum from a historic fiscal 2016, we are pleased to have delivered a strong first quarter earnings performanc
componenttext:
Thank you, Aaron. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. This is truly an exciting time at Smucker. As we look to continue the momentum from a historic fiscal 2016, we are pleased to have delivered a strong first quarter earnings performance. These results reflect our team's ability to execute and deliver our 2017 financial plan while building for the future. This balance is critical since delivering the core business and achieving our targets for synergies, cost savings and working capital supports our development of new capabilities and the continued growth of key brands and on-trend platforms. Ultimately,, this will allow us to meet our long-term objectives for top and bottom line growth and deliver against our consumer-centric corporate vision as we look to further engage, delight and inspire our consumers. 
With that background, let me provide a brief overview of first quarter results. Excluding the impact of divestitures and foreign exchange, net sales decreased 5% compared to 2016. This decline was largely planned due to a cumulative 12% list price decrease for coffee across most of the quarter and lapping the prior year rollout of Dunkin' Donuts K-Cups. Lower pet food sales also contributed. Adjusted operating income was up 2% as the lower net sales were more than offset by a decrease in commodity cost and incremental synergies. Aided by a more normalized tax rate as compared to the previous year and a decrease in shares, adjusted earnings per share grew 16% to $1.86. Free cash flow was $189 million, a portion, of which was used during the quarter to further reduce our net borrowed position. In addition, last month, we announced a 12% increase in our quarterly dividend rate. While net sales fell slightly short of our projection for the quarter, earnings per share exceeded our expectations. This was mostly attributable to higher-than-anticipated segment profit for coffee and lower-than-anticipated spending in a number of areas. As a portion of the over-delivery is expected to be timing-related, including projected year-over-year increases in marketing spend shifting to the remaining 3 quarters, we remain on track to achieve our previously stated full year guidance for adjusted earnings per share. That said, we expect softness in pet food sales to continue in the near term, leading us to adjust our full year sales guidance, as Mark will discuss in a moment. 
Let me now provide additional comments on our U.S. Retail businesses. We were pleased with the start of the fiscal year for our Coffee business. Profitability was in line with the strong first quarter of 2016 despite the anticipated top line impact of price declines and lapping the prior year launch of Dunkin' Donuts K-Cups. Volume gains for Folgers roast and ground coffee continued in the first quarter, reflecting consumer response to lower price points. Tonnage for our mainstream brands is up 3%, while unit shift were up even more given the prior year canister downsize was not fully lapped until late in the quarter. Folgers K-Cup volume trends improved in the quarter, responding favorably to planned price investments. In addition, we are currently rolling out new K-Cup packaging that leverages the iconic Folgers Red Can brand equity, providing additional support for the product line. For the Dunkin' Donuts brand, we are pleased with the continued consumption growth for our K-Cup offerings, with over $230 million in retail sales for the latest 52-week scan period. While shipments were down significantly in the first quarter, as expected to to the prior year sell-in, we project volume growth for the remaining 9 months, including contributions from new varieties. In addition, volumes for Dunkin' bagged coffee was up 4% in the first quarter, and we expect positive trends to continue as lower prices, supported by favorable input costs, have improved the competitive positioning of the brand. 
Turning to Consumer Foods. First quarter net sales were consistent with our expectations. Across many of our key brands and categories, volume was in line, or in several cases up, compared to the prior year. In addition, our brands maintained or grew both volume and dollar share in the latest 12-week scan period for most of the food categories in which we participate. For the first time in 5 years, volume for Smucker's Uncrustables Frozen Sandwiches experienced a quarterly decline. However, this was related to timing of customer shipments that have already rebounded in August. Overall consumption trends remain strong, and we continue to expect double-digit growth for the full year. In addition, Uncrustables remain a key growth driver for our Foodservice business where volume for the brand was up 40% during the first quarter. For the pet food segment, first quarter sales performance was below our projection. We have revised our full year outlook as we expect this softness to continue in the near term. Our teams are focused on the key factors impacting current performance and are already executing on opportunities to provide future growth. Specifically, improving the performance of our mainstream dog and cat brands remains a key area of focus. We have introduced bonus bags for Kibbles 'n Bits, supported by lower input costs, which entered the market in late June. We expect this will help moderate declines for the brand. We also have plans to introduce new packaging later this fiscal year and enhance brand support, consistent with its heritage around taste and fun to further improve the competitive positioning of Kibbles 'n Bits. In the cat segment, we remain encouraged by the strong equity of the Meow Mix brand. With recent innovation, a new television advertising campaign that began this month and upcoming pricing support, we are confident in our ability to reverse recent softness in this business. In addition to these areas, we continue to progress on whitespace opportunities in mainstream pet food, driven by consumer preference for additional protein and natural ingredient options. Looking at the rest of the Pet Food business, sales for pet snacks were up 2% in the quarter, on top of a 9% increase in the prior year, and were a key driver of overall category growth. Our category leadership in pet snacks and innovation, particularly for the Milk-Bone and Meow Mix brands, continues to be an important component of results. Within premium pet food, sales for the Natural Balance brand were down as we lapped the pipeline fill associated with distribution gains in last year's first quarter. While consumer takeaway for the brand remains strong, we are tempering our near-term growth expectations for our premium brands given the recent softness in the overall pet superstore channel. 
Lastly, as it relates to our Pet Food business and broader organization, let me provide a brief update on our synergy and cost-savings activities, which remain on track. In the first quarter, we realized $32 million of incremental synergies, approximately 25% of which benefited gross profit with the rest related to SD&A savings. We continue to anticipate $100 million of incremental synergies for the full fiscal year, which would bring our total to nearly $140 million of the $200 million targeted by the end of fiscal 2018. In addition, we continue to target $50 million of annual cost savings to be fully realized over the next few years related to our organizational redesign program and the previously announced plant closures. As we have indicated, we expect to initially invest much of these incremental savings in several identified areas to support top and bottom line growth. 
In closing, I would like to thank our employees for their continued efforts towards delivering the core business, building on our product innovation activities and marketing support, expanding our capabilities to enhance future growth and achieving our synergy and cost-savings goals. This strong execution continues to position the company well for 2017 and beyond. 
I will now turn the call over to Mark Belgya.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. I will begin by providing additional color on our first quarter results and then conclude with our outlook for the full year. Net sales decreased by $136 million or 7% in the quarter. The prior year divestitu
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. I will begin by providing additional color on our first quarter results and then conclude with our outlook for the full year. 
Net sales decreased by $136 million or 7% in the quarter. The prior year divestiture of the canned milk business detracted 2 percentage points, while lower net price realization, which was mostly attributable to coffee, had a 4-point impact. Volume and mix combined to subtract 1 percentage point, reflecting declines in pet food. The impact of foreign exchange was immaterial to consolidated results. GAAP earnings per share were $1.46 this quarter, 28% above the prior year. Included in GAAP earnings were $8 million of unallocated derivative gain compared to a loss of $10 million last year. In addition, GAAP earnings for both the current and prior year included $26 million of special project cost related to merger and integration and restructuring activities, along with just over $50 million of amortization expense related to intangible assets. Excluding all of these items, adjusted EPS was $1.86, for an increase of 16%. 
Adjusted gross profit declined at a slower rate than sales, resulting in a 160 basis point improvement in gross margin to 39.6%, representing the highest quarterly gross margin percentage since 2011. Year-over-year gross margin expansion was realized by all of our reportable segments, most notably for coffee. Overall commodity costs were lower in the quarter, driven by green coffee and mostly offset the lower net pricing. In addition, $8 million of the incremental synergies in the first quarter contributed to gross margin growth. For the full year, we now anticipate gross margin to be approximately 50 basis points higher than our previous guidance of 39%. 
SD&A decreased $32 million in the first quarter or 8% compared to 2016, mostly attributable to synergies. Lower royalties associated with the Dunkin' donuts business also contributed to reduced selling costs. Excluding the benefits of synergy, marketing spend was in line with the prior year, but 13% lower than forecasted for the quarter. Factoring all of this in, adjusted operating income was up $8 million or 2% compared to the prior year, with operating margin increasing 180 basis points to 20%. Below the line, lower income tax expense and a decrease in a number of shares outstanding were key drivers of the earnings per share growth. As a reminder, the effective tax rate for the prior year first quarter was unusually high due to deferred state tax adjustments. In addition, the current year first quarter rate was slightly lower than anticipated. As a result, we now expect the full year rate to approximate 33.5% compared to our previous guidance of 34%. 
Let me provide a brief overview of segment results beginning with coffee. First quarter net sales decreased 9% due to lower net price realization as the net impact of volume and mix was neutral in the quarter. Lower pricing reflected a full quarter impact of the 6% price decline taken in July 2015, along with the additional 6% decrease taken in mid-May of this year. Incremental price [indiscernible] Folgers K-Cup and Dunkin' Donuts bagged coffee also contributed. 
Net sales for the Folgers brand declined 8% as the lower net price realization was partially offset by mainstream roast and ground volume growth. For the Dunkin' Donuts brand, sales were down 14%, reflecting both lower pricing and the impact of lapping the prior year launch of Dunkin' K-Cups. Lastly, Café Bustelo sales were up 5% as the double-digit growth in volume/mix more than offset lower net pricing. 
Segment profit was flat with the prior year but exceeded expectations. Segment margin increased 310 basis points to 33.9%. The net impact of lower pricing, as compared with the recognition of lower cost, was unfavorable to segment profit in the quarter; however, to a lesser degree than originally anticipated due to timing. The price to cost impact was mostly offset by profit contributions from favorable volume/mix. And increasing marketing spend was offset by lower royalty expense associated with the Dunkin' Donuts brand. 
Turning to Consumer Foods. Net sales were down 2%, excluding the impact of the canned milk divestiture. The decline reflected lower net price realization, which was impacted by the timing of certain trade program expenses compared to the prior year. Volume/mix was flat with the prior year. 
Looking at key brands. Sales for Jif and Smucker's were down generally in line with the overall segment. In the bake aisle, sales for both the Crisco and Pillsbury brands decreased 5% as lower net pricing was partially offset by volume gains. Lastly, the Sahale Snacks brand achieved strong double-digit sales growth in the quarter, benefiting from distribution gains. Segment profit declined 7%, mostly attributable to lapping $6 million of prior year earnings related to the divested milk business. In addition, favorable input cost did not fully offset lower net price realization. 
Net sales for our pet food segment decreased 6%, reflecting unfavorable volume/mix. The lower sales were mostly driven by double-digit declines for our Natural Balance and Kibbles 'n Bits brands. Mid-single-digit declines from Meow Mix and 9Lives cat food also contributed. Sales for our pet snack portfolio were up low single digits with gains across all our key snacking brands, including Milk-Bone, Pup-Peroni, Milo's Kitchen and Canine Carry Outs. Segment profit increased 5% as the impact of unfavorable volume/mix was offset by incremental synergy realization and lower input costs. In addition, marketing spend was down double digits in the first quarter. A significant portion of the marketing impact is timing-related due to a shift of certain key marketing activities into the second quarter. We now anticipate full year pet food segment profit to be up low single digits, which is less than previously projected. 
Net sales for International and Foodservice decreased 3% in the quarter. However, excluding the impact of the canned milk divestiture and FX, net sales were in line with the prior year. Segment profit was up 9%, reflecting the net benefit of lower coffee cost and pricing along with favorable volume/mix. Partially offsetting these factors was lapping $2 million of prior year profit related to the divested milk business and unfavorable impact of foreign exchange in Canada. 
Turning to cash flow. Cash provided by operations was $239 million for the quarter. This compares to $307 million in the prior year, which included a $50 million benefit related to the timing of tax payments and refunds. Factoring in capital expenditures of $50 million in the current year, free cash flow was $189 million in the quarter. We continue to project full year free cash flow of $1 billion, assuming CapEx of $240 million. We paid down additional $100 million on our term loan in May and ended the quarter with total debt of $5.35 billion. Based on trailing 12-month EBITDA of $1.6 billion, leverage currently stands at just over 3.3x. 
Let me now conclude with an update on our full year sales and earnings outlook. Excluding the 2 percentage point impact of the divested milk business, we now expect net sales to be in the range of flat to down 1% compared to the prior year. The reduction from our previous guidance of plus 1% is primarily attributable to lower expectations for our pet food segment as projections for the remaining businesses remain relatively unchanged. With input cost lower than originally expected in our Consumer Foods segment, along with a lower effective tax rate, we expect to offset the margin impact of the net sales shortfall. As a result, we continue to project adjusted earnings per share to be in the range of $7.60 to $7.75 with the bias towards the middle to high end of the range. Reflecting the timing impact, which benefited first quarter results, most notably the shift in timing of marketing spend for pet foods segments, we now project our second quarter EPS will be comparable to the prior year. 
In closing, we anticipate the challenges to revenue growth in certain categories will persist in the near term as reflected in our revised sales guidance. However, our long-term expectations remain intact. As Mark indicated, we are executing on plans and initiatives to improve top line trends while investing in our capabilities to enhance future growth. At the same time, we are pleased with the earnings and cash flow performance of the company. Overall, we remain confident in achieving solid earnings growth this fiscal year and beyond. 
We thank you for your time, and we'll now open the call up to your questions. Operator, if you would please queue up the first question.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Ken Goldman at JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Ken Goldman at JPMorgan.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question for Steve and then one for Barry, if I can. Steve, and maybe this is more for Mark Belgya also, but I get the sense last quarter you priced some higher beans into your outlook. But prices of beans have risen since then. So I wanted to ge
componenttext: I have a question for Steve and then one for Barry, if I can. Steve, and maybe this is more for Mark Belgya also, but I get the sense last quarter you priced some higher beans into your outlook. But prices of beans have risen since then. So I wanted to get a sense of how much, if at all, those costs have risen above your expectation. And I guess, maybe the more direct question is, do you see any risk to guidance if bean [indiscernible] stay where they are right now? And do they have to kind of revert a little bit to get you more comfortable in that range?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, it's Steve Oakland. I think if we look at where we are today and where we were then, we wouldn't change our thoughts on the near term. Our coverage allowed us -- we feel very comfortable with the pricing changes that we made given the coverage that w
componenttext: Ken, it's Steve Oakland. I think if we look at where we are today and where we were then, we wouldn't change our thoughts on the near term. Our coverage allowed us -- we feel very comfortable with the pricing changes that we made given the coverage that we have. Mark and Mark talked a lot about the pricing lapse and the effect on net sales in coffee for the first quarter. But as we get into the key selling season, I think we get the sharpest price points we've had in quite a while. So the merchandising is strong. The price points are good. And honestly, the coverage supports that. We would have done those things. So if we had to look at pricing change, if that happened, it would be much later in the year. And frankly, I think we have a bias that, over the next few months, we're going to get a good look at what coffee is going to end up at. I think there's a lot of coffee in the farmers field and in Brazil. Typically, the next few months will let us know where that's going to sell out. So we're in good shape until then. And given the fact that we've gone down twice over the last 12 months, I think we've got room if we had to to absorb some of that even if we [indiscernible] pricing.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then my next question for Barry or Mark Smucker, I realize turning around dry dog food is not easy. And you guys cautioned us at CAGNY it would take some time. But it does seem some of the challenges are maybe a little bit bigger
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then my next question for Barry or Mark Smucker, I realize turning around dry dog food is not easy. And you guys cautioned us at CAGNY it would take some time. But it does seem some of the challenges are maybe a little bit bigger than expected. You did talk about some tactics bonus bags, new packaging. But frankly, just my opinion, they seem a little more like Band-Aid than sustainable fixes to the problem in that positioning. So I'm just curious, in the face of these tough trends, what gives you confidence that the issue is solely temporary? Is the strategy around the dry dog still the right one? Or do you have to make more dramatic changes for things to get fixed in the next couple of quarters?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Barry and Mark can add additional comments to this. As you know, the Kibbles 'n Bits brands, its struggle is not just recent. That brand has been struggling over the past year. So as we step in to the business with a new team, we felt fundame
componenttext: Ken, this is Barry and Mark can add additional comments to this. As you know, the Kibbles 'n Bits brands, its struggle is not just recent. That brand has been struggling over the past year. So as we step in to the business with a new team, we felt fundamentals had to be right, especially around pricing. So we thought that was the first thing we needed to do to fix the price on shelf. What we're seeing with the bonus bags is it is decelerating the losses that we are seeing previously. So we do think it's working. That was fundamental to fixing the business. We still think the brand is relevant. We've shared our marketing plans with our key retail partners. And they also believe the brand still has a relevance in that segment of dry dog food. They support our plans behind the brand and are willing to continue to work with us in that segment. So we're not going to turn it around in a quarter or 2, but we still think the Kibbles 'n Bits brands has relevance to the consumer in that segment. And then the mass premium segment, which is we do not have a place in that segment currently, we continue to evaluate acquisitions, licensing or launching one of our existing brands in that segment. That is front and center for our team, and we will continue to focus on a solution for that segment based on what's right long term for us to participate in that category. So we're still committed to the brand. We think it has a place, and we think just getting the fundamentals are just foundational.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mark Smucker, Ken. I think Barry said it. I mean, at the end of the day, it's really about blocking and tackling, getting the fundamentals right, as Barry said, and making sure that we have the right plans over the next few quarters to address the
componenttext: This is Mark Smucker, Ken. I think Barry said it. I mean, at the end of the day, it's really about blocking and tackling, getting the fundamentals right, as Barry said, and making sure that we have the right plans over the next few quarters to address the mass premium segment. And I feel better certainly now with Barry's support and his leadership that we'll get there in the relatively near future.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from the line of Andrew Lazar of Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question will come from the line of Andrew Lazar of Barclays.
