componenttext: This is Mark Belgya. It would be the restated number, if you will, that would have been in the 8-K that we issued last month. I think $1.91, if I recall.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. That's helpful. And I guess, a little bit broader, I think in terms of some of the Natural Balance commentary, you have mentioned the pet superstore channel having slowed a bit. I think the reason you pointed to maybe thinking growth there will b
componenttext: Perfect. That's helpful. And I guess, a little bit broader, I think in terms of some of the Natural Balance commentary, you have mentioned the pet superstore channel having slowed a bit. I think the reason you pointed to maybe thinking growth there will be a little bit less robust, at least in the near and intermediate term on that brand. And we have seen some of that into data to be sure. But I guess, maybe the depth of the decline in the quarter itself, I know some of that was the year-over-year lap, but I guess, I'm just trying to get a sense of whether it was -- do you think it's purely just a superstore channel that's impacting your outlook or perhaps you can comment on where you are around sort of shelf space and whether you've held on to share, and I guess share of shelf given all the space that you are able to commandeer over the last year with a lot of the launches into the PetSmart and supply, things like that. Just trying to get a sense of where, I guess, how the shelf productivity is and how the repeat purchase has been in some of these channels where you've stepped up for your presence.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, this is Barry. Let me just have a commentary on Natural Balance. I'd say, overall, we are -- we've pulled back our expectations similar to our competitors, where we've seen slowing in the pet specialty channel. Relative to the health of the Natura
componenttext: Andrew, this is Barry. Let me just have a commentary on Natural Balance. I'd say, overall, we are -- we've pulled back our expectations similar to our competitors, where we've seen slowing in the pet specialty channel. Relative to the health of the Natural Balance brand shelf space and performance, we're still encouraged by it. We think we're where we're expected to be. We have not lost any shelf space. Both of the -- our key retailers in the pet specialty channel are supporting the brand and working with us, taking incremental SKUs. We've actually added some additional items that we've recently presented to to those retailers. So overall, we're still pleased with the performance of that brand based on the expanded distribution last year. But I think that, that channel is seeing some overall slowdown in traffic. Just one other comment I would add around that brand is we are seeing some nice growth in e-commerce. And that channel is growing double digits, high double digits, small base, but we're really seeing some nice growth with that brand in that specific channel. And we'll continue to look how we can further accelerate that growth as well.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from David Driscoll of Citi.
componenttext: And our next question will come from David Driscoll of Citi.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask a question about the synergies. So can you -- it's $100 million for the year, $32 million in the quarter. Can you just explain a little bit here why if I annualize that number, obviously, I get to well more than $100 million. Is there upside
componenttext: Wanted to ask a question about the synergies. So can you -- it's $100 million for the year, $32 million in the quarter. Can you just explain a little bit here why if I annualize that number, obviously, I get to well more than $100 million. Is there upside potential for the synergies on the year and kind of maybe why not if given the performance of the quarter?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of things, David. This is Mark Belgya. We put out $100 million, and that will bring us up to about $140 million in total. There is some upside, some of which is the timing. We have a lot of activities we're tied in around the end of the fiscal ye
componenttext: A couple of things, David. This is Mark Belgya. We put out $100 million, and that will bring us up to about $140 million in total. There is some upside, some of which is the timing. We have a lot of activities we're tied in around the end of the fiscal year, so some of that came through, but we expect that to continue to pace through. And again, we feel pretty confident. We're very confident on the $200 million by the end of next year. It might pick up a little bit in the pace during the year. We'll have a little bit more color on that as we move to the next quarter probably, but we're very pleased -- I think if I recall, at the end of the fourth quarter, I think, we have $15 million or $16 million recognized and picked up to 32. So nice jump. And we'll see if we can keep the pace going.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to add one more on this pet food topic. And Barry, I really like to understand kind of -- you knew many of the problems that were going on a few months ago when you gave the original forecast. To see the sales reduction guidance again, I mean, we
componenttext: I wanted to add one more on this pet food topic. And Barry, I really like to understand kind of -- you knew many of the problems that were going on a few months ago when you gave the original forecast. To see the sales reduction guidance again, I mean, we've got to be hit with multiple revisions to your overall guidance on pet food. And it seems to keep happening. Number one, what's the confidence on this forecast? And number two, what changed in -- during the quarter? Was it the slowdown on the superstore growth that really causes the revision? Or is it really just an ongoing worsening issue with Kibbles? Because we already know that one was a problem. I guess, what I'm really trying to get after is what changed just within the last several months that caused the latest of the guide down on revenues?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think just going to take a little longer to stabilize the business. We -- it's just going to, I think, take just a little more time to get that stabilization. And once we stabilize the business, then we can get it growing again. I just think our perform
componenttext: I think just going to take a little longer to stabilize the business. We -- it's just going to, I think, take just a little more time to get that stabilization. And once we stabilize the business, then we can get it growing again. I just think our performance in the first quarter was not what we expected. And based on the combination both Kibbles and Meow Mix and the softness in the first quarter is what really drove us to be a bit more conservative on the back half of the year.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And remember, David, this is Mark Smucker, that we got the pricing and the fundamentals in the bonus bags right basically in June. So we're now just starting to see those products in markets. So to Barry's point, we do feel confident that we should see so
componenttext: And remember, David, this is Mark Smucker, that we got the pricing and the fundamentals in the bonus bags right basically in June. So we're now just starting to see those products in markets. So to Barry's point, we do feel confident that we should see some leveling off here in the next quarter or so and start to shore up that business. And then again going back to slightly longer-term view is making sure we have the right actions right in the mass premium segment. And as we think about how we address that, we certainly want to think about growing into the market and getting it right the first time. So we're incredibly focused on the execution and making sure that as we do roll out plans in that segment, we're prepared, and we're going to do it right.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one quick follow-up. Did you guys say what you expectation was for the premium pet food growth this year? I know the expectation has moderated, but I apologize if I missed it, but did you say to what? What level of growth do you think premium goe
componenttext: And just one quick follow-up. Did you guys say what you expectation was for the premium pet food growth this year? I know the expectation has moderated, but I apologize if I missed it, but did you say to what? What level of growth do you think premium goes for the year?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: The growth would be low single digits for the premium brands.
componenttext: The growth would be low single digits for the premium brands.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Robert Moskow from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Robert Moskow from Crédit Suisse.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: This question is for Mark Belgya. Mark, I think, in your prepared remarks, you said that this was a quarter where your pricing lagged -- or I guess your pricing was down more than deflation helped you. And I want to know, is that a trend that we should ex
componenttext: This question is for Mark Belgya. Mark, I think, in your prepared remarks, you said that this was a quarter where your pricing lagged -- or I guess your pricing was down more than deflation helped you. And I want to know, is that a trend that we should expect to continue for the rest of the year? Your gross profit dollars were down in first quarter. And I just want to get a sense of how you're thinking about the rest of the year, too.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rob, for the question. No, it's not something that we would necessarily expect we continue to be favorable input cost. I think in my comments in Consumer Foods, in particular. But in terms of the current quarter, what we saw a little bit of, and I
componenttext: Thanks, Rob, for the question. No, it's not something that we would necessarily expect we continue to be favorable input cost. I think in my comments in Consumer Foods, in particular. But in terms of the current quarter, what we saw a little bit of, and I think we mentioned this in our call in June and touched on today as well, is that in addition to the price declines we took, we also had some additional trade came through, sort of from a change in timing. So that, too, is considered price. So a combination of those 2 exceeded the net commodity cost reduction, but we wouldn't expect that to continue throughout the year. So obviously, the biggest price impact in general over a year ago hit in Q1 because of the coffee. So just a pricing impact overall would be less as we move here. We obviously still feel the 6% we took on coffee this year, but as you know, we lapped it otherwise. So little bit of anomaly. And I guess, just if I can, while I'm thinking pricing and just sales in general, I think I just a like to lay this out there, and again, I respect everyone's modeling, but if we do look at the combination of the milk and the impact of pricing that coffee had, and I guess I'm just turning back the clock a couple of months, those 2 pieces in total were probably about $90 million to $100 million first quarter sales impact. So I think in Mark's comments, we talked about our sales being just slightly below plans. So we have factored a good portion of that in. But certainly, I can understand the reaction when you see the negative 7 year-over-year. So I just wanted to call that out in additional data point for everybody.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That might be a good segue for a question on revenue management. Mark Smucker, I believe you have a new functional head in revenue management internally. Can you give us a little bit of an update on what he's working on for you? And when do you expe
componenttext: Okay. That might be a good segue for a question on revenue management. Mark Smucker, I believe you have a new functional head in revenue management internally. Can you give us a little bit of an update on what he's working on for you? And when do you expect to see the results of that?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question. Yes, we do actually have a new head of revenue management. In fact, one of the things that we spoke about, I think, on the last call was that some of the incremental savings that we've targeted are going to be invested in capabili
componenttext: Thanks for the question. Yes, we do actually have a new head of revenue management. In fact, one of the things that we spoke about, I think, on the last call was that some of the incremental savings that we've targeted are going to be invested in capabilities like that. That is one of several. I would describe some of the capabilities as we've sort of taken a step back and reorganize ourselves to make sure that we're building the right capabilities that relate to the consumer. And that could be things like insights and data to ensure a robust innovation pipeline as well as the customer in terms of how we do business with them and how we ensure that we're giving them the absolute best content. So revenue management would be one piece of that. And we're at the stage now where we've done a nice job of building the organization, and we're in the process of ensuring that those new organizations and functions are wired properly. And so that takes a little bit of time as we get to a full year planning and so forth. But at this point, we're very, very pleased with the leadership we have across many of our functions. And as it relates specifically to the revenue management, our goal over the next year or 2 are to begin to become increasingly more efficient in our trade spend so that we can truly drive incremental sales. That's ultimately the goal.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Mario Contreras of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Mario Contreras of Deutsche Bank.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I believe last quarter you mentioned that your cat food brands had seen some growth. It looks like the trends reversed a little bit this quarter. I believe you mentioned those were down. Can you talk a little bit about the trends in that category? Is t
componenttext: So I believe last quarter you mentioned that your cat food brands had seen some growth. It looks like the trends reversed a little bit this quarter. I believe you mentioned those were down. Can you talk a little bit about the trends in that category? Is there anything specific to worsen competitive conditions or some specific to your brands?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mario, this is Barry. I would say what we experienced, especially this last quarter, was some competitive pricing activity with our major competitor in that category, which put the pressure on the brand. So we've taken some programs back to our retail par
componenttext: Mario, this is Barry. I would say what we experienced, especially this last quarter, was some competitive pricing activity with our major competitor in that category, which put the pressure on the brand. So we've taken some programs back to our retail partners and are working with them to get again the price right relative to our competition. That, combined with our advertising campaign we just -- are on TV effective August 1, with our new advertising campaign behind the Meow Mix brand, we think will provide great support for the business. So between those 2 activities, we think we'll address some of the short-term pressure that, that brand has experienced. No other fundamental concerns with the brand, more short term versus longer term.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just one quick one on the Dunkin' K-Cups. So obviously, you're lapping the pipeline fill. Can you talk about some of the share trends you're seeing, especially in the last few weeks here? Are you still pretty confident that
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just one quick one on the Dunkin' K-Cups. So obviously, you're lapping the pipeline fill. Can you talk about some of the share trends you're seeing, especially in the last few weeks here? Are you still pretty confident that you're holding share or gaining share? And how do you feel about that trending over the next few quarters?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Mario, Steve. I think we're very encouraged by total K-Cup. I don't think it was in the prepared comments, but we saw what we call legacy or Folgers K-Cups increase in volume for the quarter. And that's a nice turnaround given getting everything goi
componenttext: Sure. Mario, Steve. I think we're very encouraged by total K-Cup. I don't think it was in the prepared comments, but we saw what we call legacy or Folgers K-Cups increase in volume for the quarter. And that's a nice turnaround given getting everything going on in the K-Cup category and all of the noise there and the deflation there. We saw strong K-Cup volume in our legacy brands. We continue to see strong takeaway for Dunkin'. We literally had trucks lined up at the door at midnight on May 1 a year ago when we launched this. So given the strength of that, we did not expect the same results obviously a year later. But we have more distribution today than we did a year ago. The turns remain very, very strong. And the Dunkin' Original K-Cup is the #1 K-Cup in most of the channels and most of the customers we sold to. So that franchise continues to be alive and growing. So we're really pleased with that, but more pleased I would say that the legacy business is up over a year ago. So that's a great trend to reverse.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess, just to clarify, so would you expect the Dunkin' brand to return to growth here in the second quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess, just to clarify, so would you expect the Dunkin' brand to return to growth here in the second quarter?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes. We would expect the Dunkin' brand in total. Our bagged coffee business is up for the quarter, in the first quarter, which again is a nice trend reversal. Although we had a fantastic year last year, that was driven mostly by core Folgers Red Can.
componenttext: Yes, yes. We would expect the Dunkin' brand in total. Our bagged coffee business is up for the quarter, in the first quarter, which again is a nice trend reversal. Although we had a fantastic year last year, that was driven mostly by core Folgers Red Can. It's nice to see our Red Can momentum continue in the first quarter, but also our legacy K-Cup and our Dunkin' bag business improved. So both of those things have improved in the first quarter.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Alexia Howard of Bernstein.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Alexia Howard of Bernstein.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll focus in on the U.S. Retail business for a moment. The 2% organic sales growth decline, I understand that it was largely price investments, but it sounds as though that was broadly in line with your expectations. Is that -- should we think about t
componenttext: So I'll focus in on the U.S. Retail business for a moment. The 2% organic sales growth decline, I understand that it was largely price investments, but it sounds as though that was broadly in line with your expectations. Is that -- should we think about that as the continued run rate for the business, given the challenges that are going on in that retail environment? And as you think about the bits that are growing nicely like Sahale and -- does that shape how you think about your bolt-on acquisition strategy going forward? I know you're probably not in a position to do acquisitions yet, but might you have to shore up that business with some more softer-growing health and wellness-type brand?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alexia, it's Mark Smucker. The second part of your question, yes. I think we're really pleased with our natural and organic -- not only the smaller businesses like our beverage business and Sahale, both we're very pleased with right now. And so as we thin
componenttext: Alexia, it's Mark Smucker. The second part of your question, yes. I think we're really pleased with our natural and organic -- not only the smaller businesses like our beverage business and Sahale, both we're very pleased with right now. And so as we think about other segments or categories, that would be one area that we would look in terms of bolt-ons, but we just also remain focused as well, even our mainstream businesses, that in some cases where we have businesses where we have simple ingredients, more natural offerings, cleaner ingredient those businesses are areas that we will continue to focus on. And I think, quite frankly, you're seeing that pretty broadly from our entire industry, so I don't think -- I think most of us are saying a lot of the same things based on a lot of the same trends. So yes. In the first part of your question, did I answer?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kind of the 2% decline in organic sales growth with the price investment, is that kind of a run rate for now in terms of how we should think about the business?
componenttext: Kind of the 2% decline in organic sales growth with the price investment, is that kind of a run rate for now in terms of how we should think about the business?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alexia, this as Mark Belgya. What I would do is I would say that for our Consumer Foods business, it gives money a little bit because [indiscernible] if you take the milk out, we would expect that business to be up modestly. And then coffee, it's going to
componenttext: Alexia, this as Mark Belgya. What I would do is I would say that for our Consumer Foods business, it gives money a little bit because [indiscernible] if you take the milk out, we would expect that business to be up modestly. And then coffee, it's going to be dragged down a little bit in the continuing quarters because of the 6% price decline we took here in July -- or I'm sorry, in May of this year. But the short of that, we will see some volume growth [indiscernible] a little bit of that price impact. So the math probably works out to somewhere kind of flattish, I would guess, if you look at the Consumer Foods and the coffee together with the U.S. Retail. And as we've mentioned, the pet is going to be down, so that would pull the overall average of those 3 reported segments down below flat, probably negative 1 to 2, I guess.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: But at the same time, we are in a very deflationary environment several of our customers have reported top line good come sales growth, but some still top line challenges. And I think that's just systemic at the moment, with commodities moving we're movin
componenttext: But at the same time, we are in a very deflationary environment several of our customers have reported top line good come sales growth, but some still top line challenges. And I think that's just systemic at the moment, with commodities moving we're moving, we're probably going to see some change there over time.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from John Baumgartner of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question will come from John Baumgartner of Wells Fargo.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Barry, I'd like to ask, in terms of mainstream pet, a few of your larger competitors have adopted natural or grain-free offshoots of their core brands. When you think about it, I mean, how much of an incremental headwind is that proving for you in mainstr
componenttext: Barry, I'd like to ask, in terms of mainstream pet, a few of your larger competitors have adopted natural or grain-free offshoots of their core brands. When you think about it, I mean, how much of an incremental headwind is that proving for you in mainstream maybe relative to view the landscape at the time of the acquisition?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's clearly a trend in mainstream. And as we look at entering the mass premium segment, that has to be front and center for us as we look at our enter strategy would be. So again as we look at consumer is interested in and what their preferences a
componenttext: Yes, that's clearly a trend in mainstream. And as we look at entering the mass premium segment, that has to be front and center for us as we look at our enter strategy would be. So again as we look at consumer is interested in and what their preferences are, so that will be a part of our thinking as we think about an entry strategy.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we think about -- as a follow-up, when we think about the premium space, the next phase of distribution for Natural Balance or even Nature's Recipe -- I think a few months ago, I think there was some commentary pertaining to runway independence, as a
componenttext: When we think about -- as a follow-up, when we think about the premium space, the next phase of distribution for Natural Balance or even Nature's Recipe -- I think a few months ago, I think there was some commentary pertaining to runway independence, as an example. What is the phasing for the standard? What point is incremental distribution you need to kick in? And then maybe lastly, how are you seeing the interplay between the Nature's Recipe and Natural Balance in terms of incrementality versus some cannibalization impact there?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: They each have their own position in the pet specialty segment where Nature's Recipe is more of an entry brand into pet specialty, the Natural Balance is a much more premium segment with a focus on ingredient diet. So they each have a unique positioning i
componenttext: They each have their own position in the pet specialty segment where Nature's Recipe is more of an entry brand into pet specialty, the Natural Balance is a much more premium segment with a focus on ingredient diet. So they each have a unique positioning in that channel. As far as the independent channel being incremental, we focus on that channel just like we do the other main retailers in pet specialty, but that -- the independent trade is not going to drive the growth of those brands. Most of our growth is going to come from the lead retailers in that channel.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Farha Aslam from Stephens.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Farha Aslam from Stephens.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on Dunkin'. A couple of times, we heard kind of lower payments to Dunkin' brands. Is that simply a function of the lower volume in K-Cups? Or is there anything structural in terms of renegotiation of rates?
componenttext: First question is on Dunkin'. A couple of times, we heard kind of lower payments to Dunkin' brands. Is that simply a function of the lower volume in K-Cups? Or is there anything structural in terms of renegotiation of rates?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Farha, it's Mark. It's just a function of it's variable cost of sales, which is a lower royalty, total dollar, not a change in the rate.
componenttext: Farha, it's Mark. It's just a function of it's variable cost of sales, which is a lower royalty, total dollar, not a change in the rate.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then the second one is back on pet food. You are about the cycle into some very low and very favorable input costs in both corn and soybeans and a lot of your other inputs. How are you thinking about managing pricing versus margin in t
componenttext: That's helpful. And then the second one is back on pet food. You are about the cycle into some very low and very favorable input costs in both corn and soybeans and a lot of your other inputs. How are you thinking about managing pricing versus margin in that mainstream brands given that you're getting such a great commodity tailwind?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: As prior as the pricing, again, we have to be front and center competitive with our -- the other 2 primary competitors that we compete with. So as a third player in that category, we'll continue to just be competitive with the 2 primary competitors. So th
componenttext: As prior as the pricing, again, we have to be front and center competitive with our -- the other 2 primary competitors that we compete with. So as a third player in that category, we'll continue to just be competitive with the 2 primary competitors. So that will be our focus. We'll manage our commodities in our pet business just like we do in our other businesses, and that will be part of our pricing strategy.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just add over to Barry's point, first of all, I think we've made pretty consistently over the years we've owned Crisco business and coffee that there's always going to be timing as you match up the cost of that commodity with the pricing, but we've d
componenttext: I'll just add over to Barry's point, first of all, I think we've made pretty consistently over the years we've owned Crisco business and coffee that there's always going to be timing as you match up the cost of that commodity with the pricing, but we've done a very good job both as prices gone up and prices gone down generally to maintain the margin dollars and grow those dollars over time. So I think we would as Barry's [indiscernible] we have to move this price between the category but focus on the fact that we've been able to grow those margin dollars over time.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Farha, one thing that when Barry talked about getting the fundamentals right, one of the things that Big Heart business coming into Smucker one is the capabilities that they got is our commodity buying team or hedging team. We have a much more sophi
componenttext: Well, Farha, one thing that when Barry talked about getting the fundamentals right, one of the things that Big Heart business coming into Smucker one is the capabilities that they got is our commodity buying team or hedging team. We have a much more sophisticated -- driven by the fact that we're in the Coffee business as we are in the other grains businesses that we're in. So a number of the commodities that input cost for that all all run through those same systems. So I think we have a more sophisticated system. And we have capabilities that allow Barry and the team to know what their cost are going out further to be able to participate in the downside, projecting from the upside. So it's a much more robust set of capabilities quite against that business. Now it takes time for those to impact it. And we're in the process of that now. But those commodity tailwinds, as you call them, that you spoke about, Barry and the team will have the same capabilities to achieve those that we have in the other businesses now.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Akshay Jagdale of Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Akshay Jagdale of Jefferies.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is for Mark Belgya. So on the marketing spending and timing, thanks for calling that out, first of all. But can you give us a sense of what the plan is now on total dollars spending relative to what it was? And where that -- so give us some
componenttext: First question is for Mark Belgya. So on the marketing spending and timing, thanks for calling that out, first of all. But can you give us a sense of what the plan is now on total dollars spending relative to what it was? And where that -- so give us some sense of where those funds are shifting to like what quarter and if there's any particular reason why they have shifted even relative to your plan.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks, Akshay, for the question. In terms of total spend for the total company for the total year, we expect them to basically on our plan as expected. What you're going this is it going to see a little bit of the shift in that there's a likelihood
componenttext: Okay, thanks, Akshay, for the question. In terms of total spend for the total company for the total year, we expect them to basically on our plan as expected. What you're going this is it going to see a little bit of the shift in that there's a likelihood -- although the first quarter that it was timing on pets, most of the 13% decline I think we spoke to with pet monkey related. That's going to shift [indiscernible] shift in Q2. Probably still a little bit less than planned for the whole year. However, in our other businesses, we're seeing a little bit uptick in marketing. So net-net, we'll be at exactly where we thought we're going to be starting the year, which is I think around 6.2%, 6.3% of sales.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just a couple more sort of high-level. First one is on coffee related to revenue management and perhaps your hedging strategy. And Mark you manage the Coffee business as well. So in term -- as you look at the next 3 to 5 years, I mean, when you previous ownership Folgers had a pretty open policy hedging, which [indiscernible] to the market on where prices are going to go and from talking to people in the industry, since you've gone away from that over the last 4, 5 years. There's been a little bit more disruption competitively as a result. That's one argument. Have you considered maybe just making a broader change there with not only [indiscernible] modeling one way to argue maybe makes the competitive environment a little bit more rational. That's one question. And I have a [indiscernible] on pet.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Akshay, it's Steve Oakland. I think before Smucker bought it under PNG, it might have been a little more formulaic, right? And I think it might have been a little bit more transparent. But if you think about how different the coffee category is toda
componenttext: Sure. Akshay, it's Steve Oakland. I think before Smucker bought it under PNG, it might have been a little more formulaic, right? And I think it might have been a little bit more transparent. But if you think about how different the coffee category is today than it was then, that was pretty K-Cups. That was when blue can was a material piece of this category. And then that was related to different owners of our competitive brands that the different strategies and different behavior. So I think if you look at the moment to last year, you look at the first quarter in coffee, really good about our balance of cost in our balance of coverage. I think we think we're uniquely different in that we tie our commodity team to our business team and that our commodity team not only understands how to buy the right [indiscernible] to understand when we need those prices in the marketplace. So it may be more difficult for the outside world to understand, but I think we're really happy with how is -- what it's delivering for us from a business unit standpoint. I think we'll stick -- we'll probably stay with where we are.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one on pet. Again, just long-term focus question. I mean, I understand there's some competitive issues on the dry side and you're sharpening price points. And that seems like more like surgical moves. But the broader trend is the pet population s
componenttext: And just one on pet. Again, just long-term focus question. I mean, I understand there's some competitive issues on the dry side and you're sharpening price points. And that seems like more like surgical moves. But the broader trend is the pet population seems to have started growing in the recent past, so that's a good trend and there's a broader trend of premiumization. Your portfolio should be better suited to that than your competitors. I mean, are we entering a stage like we were like maybe 4 years ago on coffee where there's a shift from mainstream to premium, a broader shift, that we should be maybe thinking of in light of your exposure to the mainstream side? Is that what we're seeing broadly as people are premium-izing maybe the mainstream category is over skewed, and that's why we're seeing as much competitive activity as they're seeing?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Akshay, it's Barry. Just provide some commentary on that. You're seeing more humanization of pets and consumers looking at premium products. And I think it was stay consistent with our strategy and making sure we participate in every segment of the catego
componenttext: Akshay, it's Barry. Just provide some commentary on that. You're seeing more humanization of pets and consumers looking at premium products. And I think it was stay consistent with our strategy and making sure we participate in every segment of the category. It's still a place for our value brands like Kibbles 'n Bits and Gravy Train in that segment. We have some great brands in pet specialty. Our snack brands cut across all other segments as well and are great brands. We've been driving category growth in the snack category, and our retailers attribute that to our innovation efforts. So I think our strategy in pet is going to be like it is in every other segment is just category we participate in, just make sure we meet the consumer needs however they define value. And that will be a consistent strategy for pet. So we -- it's a great category, great brands. We think, long term, it's definitely the right business for us to be in. So we're going to leverage the scale and capabilities of [indiscernible] $1 billion [ph] company to continue to grow the pet business.

componenttextpreview: All right, this is Mark Smucker. Just a couple closing comments I have. Obviously, there been a few obviously, a lot of questions on pet. Just want to reiterate our confidence in the business. We believe in the business, Barry just mentioned a minutes ago
componenttext: All right, this is Mark Smucker. Just a couple closing comments I have. Obviously, there been a few obviously, a lot of questions on pet. Just want to reiterate our confidence in the business. We believe in the business, Barry just mentioned a minutes ago just the brands are fantastic. And although we've talked quite a bit about mainstream dog today, we feel very good about where we're at in our premium segment, our ability to address, and we've started to do that on the mainstream side. And very importantly, our snacks business, pet snacks is going very well, our shares are very healthy there. And so as with all of the other categories that we're in, we're very comfortable and confident in competing with our peers, and we compete against many of the same players and some of the other categories, and we've got a proven ability to grow brands, in which are categories. So leave you with that. And then, again, we didn't talk much today about the Olympics, but the Olympics has been very good for our brands. We're going to probably see some halo affect from a consumer perspective. And then we're going to continue to focus on what we're good at: executing, blocking and tackling, making sure that we have the best consumer engagement possible by supporting our products that we have in market; and then of course, delivering against or exceeding our synergy and our working capital targets. So once again, just want to thank our talented team of employees. They are fantastic. We would not have been able to deliver the fantastic results this quarter without them. And so many, many thanks to our dedicated employees, and thank you to all of you for joining us today. Have a great week.

Good morning, and welcome to The J.M. Smucker Company's Fiscal 2017 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. This conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now turn the conference over to Aaron Broholm, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our first quarter earnings conference call. With me today and presenting our prepared comments are Mark Smucker, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Belgya, Vice Chair and Chief Financial Office
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining us on our first quarter earnings conference call. With me today and presenting our prepared comments are Mark Smucker, Chief Executive Officer; and Mark Belgya, Vice Chair and Chief Financial Officer. Also joining us for the Q&A portion of the call are Steve Oakland, Vice Chair and President, U.S. Food and Beverage; and Barry Dunaway, President, Pet Food and Pet Snacks. 
During this call, we will make forward-looking statements that reflect the company's current expectations about future plans and performance. These statements rely on a number of assumptions and estimates, and actual results may differ materially due to risks and uncertainties. I encourage you to read the full disclosure concerning forward-looking statements in this morning's press release, which is located on our corporate website at jmsmucker.com. 
Additionally, please note the company uses non-GAAP results for the purpose of evaluating performance internally as detailed in the press release. We have also posted to our website a supplementary slide deck summarizing first quarter results, which can be accessed through the link to the webcast of this call. These slides and a replay of this call will be archived on our website. 
On July 25, we issued a Form 8-K regarding our new definition of segment profit and non-GAAP operating income, income and earnings per share, all of which now exclude intangible amortization expense. Modified prior year results that reflect this new definition were included in the Form 8-K. Please note, we now refer to our non-GAAP profit measures as adjusted gross profit, operating income, income and earnings per share. If you have any questions after today's call, please contact me. 
I will now turn the call over to Mark Smucker.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Aaron. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. This is truly an exciting time at Smucker. As we look to continue the momentum from an historic fiscal 2016, we are pleased to have delivered a strong first quarter earnings performan
componenttext:
Thank you, Aaron. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. This is truly an exciting time at Smucker. As we look to continue the momentum from an historic fiscal 2016, we are pleased to have delivered a strong first quarter earnings performance. These results reflect our team's ability to execute and deliver our 2017 financial plan while building for the future. This balance is critical since delivering the core business and achieving our targets for synergies, cost savings and working capital supports our development of new capabilities and the continued growth of key brands and on-trend platforms. Ultimately, this will allow us to meet our long-term objectives for top and bottom line growth and deliver against our consumer-centric corporate vision as we look to further engage, delight and inspire our consumers. 
With that background, let me provide a brief overview of first quarter results. Excluding the impact of divestitures and foreign exchange, net sales decreased 5% compared to 2016. This decline was largely planned due to a cumulative 12% list price decrease for coffee across most of the quarter and lapping the prior year rollout of Dunkin' Donuts K-Cups. Lower Pet Food sales also contributed. 
Adjusted operating income was up 2% as the lower net sales were more than offset by a decrease in commodity costs and incremental synergies. Aided by a more normalized tax rate as compared to the previous year and a decrease in shares, adjusted earnings per share grew 16% to $1.86. Free cash flow was $189 million, a portion of which was used during the quarter to further reduce our net borrowed position. In addition, last month, we announced a 12% increase in our quarterly dividend rate. 
While net sales fell slightly short of our projection for the quarter, earnings per share exceeded our expectations. This was mostly attributable to higher-than-anticipated segment profit for coffee and lower-than-anticipated spending in a number of areas. As a portion of the overdelivery is expected to be timing-related, including projected year-over-year increases in marketing spend shifting to the remaining 3 quarters, we remain on track to achieve our previously stated full year guidance for adjusted earnings per share. That said, we expect softness in Pet Food sales to continue in the near term, leading us to adjust our full year sales guidance, as Mark will discuss in a moment. 
Let me now provide additional comments on our U.S. Retail businesses. We were pleased with the start of the fiscal year for our coffee business. Profitability was in line with the strong first quarter of 2016 despite the anticipated top line impact of price declines and lapping the prior year launch of Dunkin' Donuts K-Cups. Volume gains for Folgers roast and ground coffee continued in the first quarter, reflecting consumer response to lower price points. Tonnage for our mainstream brands was up 3%, while units shipped were up even more given the prior year canister downsize was not fully lapped until late in the quarter. 
Folgers K-Cup volume trends improved in the quarter, responding favorably to planned price investments. In addition, we are currently rolling out new K-Cup packaging that leverages the iconic Folgers Red Can brand equity, providing additional support for the product line. 
For the Dunkin' Donuts brand, we are pleased with the continued consumption growth for our K-Cup offerings, with over $230 million in retail sales for the latest 52-week scan period. While shipments were down significantly in the first quarter as expected due to the prior year sell-in, we project volume growth for the remaining 9 months, including contributions from new varieties. In addition, volume for Dunkin' bagged coffee was up 4% in the first quarter, and we expect positive trends to continue as lower prices, supported by favorable input costs, have improved the competitive positioning of the brand. 
Turning to Consumer Foods. First quarter net sales were consistent with our expectations. Across many of our key brands and categories, volume was in line or, in several cases, up compared to the prior year. In addition, our brands maintained or grew both volume and dollar share in the latest 12-week scan period for most of the food categories in which we participate. 
For the first time in 5 years, volume for Smucker's Uncrustables frozen sandwiches experienced a quarterly decline. However, this was related to timing of customer shipments that have already rebounded in August. Overall consumption trends remained strong, and we continue to expect double-digit growth for the full year. In addition, Uncrustables remain a key growth driver for our Foodservice business where volume for the brand was up 40% during the first quarter. 
For the Pet Food segment, first quarter sales performance was below our projection. We have revised our full year outlook as we expect this softness to continue in the near term. Our teams are focused on the key factors impacting current performance and are already executing on opportunities to provide future growth. 
Specifically, improving the performance of our mainstream dog and cat brands remains a key area of focus. We have introduced bonus bags for Kibbles 'n Bits, supported by lower input costs, which entered the market in late June. We expect this will help moderate declines for the brand. We also have plans to introduce new packaging later this fiscal year and enhance brand support, consistent with its heritage around taste and fun to further improve the competitive positioning of Kibbles 'n Bits. 
In the cat segment, we remain encouraged by the strong equity of the Meow Mix brand. With recent innovation, a new television advertising campaign that began this month and upcoming pricing support, we are confident in our ability to reverse recent softness in this business. 
In addition to these areas, we continue to progress on whitespace opportunities in mainstream pet food, driven by consumer preference for additional protein and natural ingredient options. 
Looking at the rest of the Pet Food business, sales for pet snacks were up 2% in the quarter, on top of a 9% increase in the prior year, and were a key driver of overall category growth. Our category leadership in pet snacks and innovation, particularly for the Milk-Bone and Meow Mix brands, continues to be an important component of results. 
Within premium pet food, sales for the Natural Balance brand were down as we lapped the pipeline fill associated with distribution gains in last year's first quarter. While consumer takeaway for the brand remains strong, we are tempering our near-term growth expectations for our premium brands given the recent softness in the overall pet superstore channel. 
Lastly, as it relates to our Pet Food business and broader organization, let me provide a brief update on our synergy and cost-savings activities, which remain on track. In the first quarter, we realized $32 million of incremental synergies, approximately 25% of which benefited gross profit, with the rest related to SD&A savings. We continue to anticipate $100 million of incremental synergies for the full fiscal year, which would bring our total to nearly $140 million of the $200 million targeted by the end of fiscal 2018. 
In addition, we continue to target $50 million of annual cost savings to be fully realized over the next few years related to our organizational redesign program and the previously announced plant closures. As we have indicated, we expect to initially invest much of these incremental savings in several identified areas to support top and bottom line growth. 
In closing, I would like to thank our employees for their continued efforts towards delivering the core business, building on our product innovation activities and marketing support, expanding our capabilities to enhance future growth and achieving our synergy and cost-savings goals. This strong execution continues to position the company well for 2017 and beyond. 
I will now turn the call over to Mark Belgya.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. I will begin by providing additional color on our first quarter results and then conclude with our outlook for the full year. Net sales decreased by $136 million or 7% in the quarter. The prior year divestitu
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and good morning, everyone. I will begin by providing additional color on our first quarter results and then conclude with our outlook for the full year. 
Net sales decreased by $136 million or 7% in the quarter. The prior year divestiture of the canned milk business detracted 2 percentage points, while lower net price realization, which was mostly attributable to coffee, had a 4-point impact. Volume and mix combined to subtract 1 percentage point, reflecting declines in Pet Food. The impact of foreign exchange was immaterial to consolidated results. 
GAAP earnings per share were $1.46 this quarter, 28% above the prior year. Included in GAAP earnings were $8 million of unallocated derivative gains compared to a loss of $10 million last year. In addition, GAAP earnings for both the current and prior years included $26 million of special project costs related to merger and integration and restructuring activities, along with just over $50 million of amortization expense related to intangible assets. Excluding all of these items, adjusted EPS was $1.86 for an increase of 16%. 
Adjusted gross profit declined at a slower rate than sales, resulting in a 160 basis point improvement in gross margin to 39.6%, representing the highest quarterly gross margin percentage since 2011. Year-over-year gross margin expansion was realized by all of our reportable segments, most notably for coffee. Overall commodity costs were lower in the quarter, driven by green coffee, and mostly offset the lower net pricing. In addition, $8 million of the incremental synergies in the first quarter contributed to gross margin growth. For the full year, we now anticipate gross margin to be approximately 50 basis points higher than our previous guidance of 39%. 
SD&A decreased $32 million in the first quarter or 8% compared to 2016, mostly attributable to synergies. Lower royalties associated with the Dunkin' Donuts business also contributed to reduced selling costs. Excluding the benefits of synergy, marketing spend was in line with the prior year but 13% lower than forecasted for the quarter. Factoring all of this in, adjusted operating income was up $8 million or 2% compared to the prior year, with operating margin increasing 180 basis points to 20%. 
Below the line, lower income tax expense and a decrease in the number of shares outstanding were key drivers of the earnings per share growth. As a reminder, the effective tax rate for the prior year first quarter was unusually high due to deferred state tax adjustments. In addition, the current year first quarter rate was slightly lower than anticipated. As a result, we now expect the full year rate to approximate 33.5% compared to our previous guidance of 34%. 
Let me provide a brief overview of segment results, beginning with coffee. First quarter net sales decreased 9% due to lower net price realization as the net impact of volume and mix was neutral in the quarter. Lower pricing reflected the full quarter impact of the 6% price decline taken in July 2015, along with the additional 6% decrease taken in mid-May of this year. Incremental price support of Folgers K-Cup and Dunkin' Donuts bagged coffee also contributed. 
Net sales for the Folgers brand declined 8% as the lower net price realization was partially offset by mainstream roast and ground volume growth. For the Dunkin' Donuts brand, sales were down 14%, reflecting both lower pricing and the impact of lapping the prior year launch of Dunkin' K-Cups. Lastly, Café Bustelo sales were up 5% as double-digit growth in volume/mix more than offset lower net pricing. 
Segment profit was flat with the prior year but exceeded expectations. Segment margin increased 310 basis points to 33.9%. The net impact of lower pricing, as compared to the recognition of lower cost, was unfavorable to segment profit in the quarter, however, to a lesser degree than originally anticipated due to timing. The price-to-cost impact was mostly offset by profit contributions from favorable volume/mix. And the increase in marketing spend was offset by lower royalty expense associated with the Dunkin' Donuts brand. 
Turning to Consumer Foods. Net sales were down 2%, excluding the impact of the canned milk divestiture. The decline reflected lower net price realization, which was impacted by the timing of certain trade program expenses compared to the prior year. Volume/mix was flat with the prior year. 
Looking at key brands. Sales for Jif and Smucker's were down, generally in line with the overall segment. In the bake aisle, sales for both the Crisco and Pillsbury brands decreased 5% as lower net pricing was partially offset by volume gains. Lastly, the Sahale Snacks brand achieved strong double-digit sales growth in the quarter, benefiting from distribution gains. 
Segment profit declined 7%, mostly attributable to lapping $6 million of prior year earnings related to the divested milk business. In addition, favorable input cost did not fully offset lower net price realization. 
Net sales for our Pet Food segment decreased 6%, reflecting unfavorable volume/mix. The lower sales were mostly driven by double-digit declines for our Natural Balance and Kibbles 'n Bits brands. Mid-single-digit declines from Meow Mix and 9Lives cat food also contributed. Sales for our pet snack portfolio were up low single digits, with gains across all our key snacking brands, including Milk-Bone, Pup-Peroni, Milo's Kitchen and Canine Carry Outs. 
Segment profit increased 5% as the impact of unfavorable volume/mix was offset by incremental synergy realization and lower input costs. In addition, marketing spend was down double digits in the first quarter. A significant portion of the marketing impact is timing-related due to a shift of certain key marketing activities into the second quarter. We now anticipate full year Pet Food segment profit to be up low single digits, which is less than previously projected. 
Net sales for International and Foodservice decreased 3% in the quarter. However, excluding the impact of the canned milk divestiture and FX, net sales were in line with the prior year. Segment profit was up 9%, reflecting the net benefit of lower coffee cost and pricing along with favorable volume/mix. Partially offsetting these factors was lapping $2 million of prior year profit related to the divested milk business and unfavorable impact of foreign exchange in Canada. 
Turning to cash flow. Cash provided by operations was $239 million for the quarter. This compares to $307 million in the prior year, which included a $50 million benefit related to the timing of tax payments and refunds. Factoring in capital expenditures of $50 million in the current year, free cash flow was $189 million in the quarter. We continue to project full year free cash flow of $1 billion, assuming CapEx of $240 million. 
We paid down an additional $100 million on our term loan in May and ended the quarter with total debt of $5.35 billion. Based on trailing 12-month EBITDA of $1.6 billion, leverage currently stands at just over 3.3x. 
Let me now conclude with an update on our full year sales and earnings outlook. Excluding the 2 percentage point impact of the divested milk business, we now expect net sales to be in the range of flat to down 1% compared to the prior year. The reduction from our previous guidance of plus 1% is primarily attributable to lower expectations for our Pet Food segment as projections for the remaining businesses remain relatively unchanged. With input costs lower than originally expected in our Consumer Foods segment, along with a lower effective tax rate, we expect to offset the margin impact of the net sales shortfall. 
As a result, we continue to project adjusted earnings per share to be in the range of $7.60 to $7.75, with the bias towards the middle to high end of the range. Reflecting the timing impact, which benefited first quarter results, most notably the shift in timing of marketing spend for Pet Food segments, we now project our second quarter EPS will be comparable to the prior year. 
In closing, we anticipate the challenges to revenue growth in certain categories will persist in the near term, as reflected in our revised sales guidance. However, our long-term expectations remain intact. As Mark indicated, we're executing on plans and initiatives to improve top line trends while investing in our capabilities to enhance future growth. At the same time, we are pleased with the earnings and cash flow performance of the company. Overall, we remain confident in achieving solid earnings growth this fiscal year and beyond. 
We thank you for your time, and we will now open the call up to your questions. Operator, if you would please queue up the first question.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
