componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from Ken Goldman at JPMorgan.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question for Steve and then one for Barry if I can. Steve, and maybe this is more for Mark Belgya also, but I got the sense last quarter you had priced some higher beans into your outlook, but prices for beans have risen since then. So I kind of
componenttext: I have a question for Steve and then one for Barry if I can. Steve, and maybe this is more for Mark Belgya also, but I got the sense last quarter you had priced some higher beans into your outlook, but prices for beans have risen since then. So I kind of wanted to get a sense of how much, if at all, those costs have risen above your expectation. And I guess maybe the more direct question is, do you see any risk to guidance if bean futures merely stay where they are right now? Do they have to kind of revert a little bit to get you more comfortable in that range?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve Oakland. I think if we look at where we are today and where we were then, we wouldn't change our thoughts on the near term. Our coverage allowed us -- we felt very comfortable with the pricing changes that we made given the coverage that we have. Ma
componenttext: Steve Oakland. I think if we look at where we are today and where we were then, we wouldn't change our thoughts on the near term. Our coverage allowed us -- we felt very comfortable with the pricing changes that we made given the coverage that we have. Mark and Mark talked a lot about the pricing laps and the effect on net sales in coffee for the first quarter. But as we get into the key selling season, I think we've got the sharpest price points we've had in quite a while. So the merchandising is strong, the price points are good, and honestly, the coverage supports that or we wouldn't have done those things. So if we had to look at pricing change if that happened, it would be much later in the year. And frankly, I think we have a bias that over the next few months, we're going to get a good look at what coffee is going to end up at. I think there's a lot of coffee in the farmers' field and in Brazil, and typically, the next few months will let us know where that's going to sell out. So we're in good shape until then. And given the fact that we've gone down twice over the last 12 months, I think we've got room if we had to, to absorb some of that even if we have to do pricing.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then my next question for Barry or Mark Smucker, I realize turning around dry dog food is not easy, and you guys cautioned us at CAGNY it would take some time. But it does seem some of the challenges are maybe a little bit bigger
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then my next question for Barry or Mark Smucker, I realize turning around dry dog food is not easy, and you guys cautioned us at CAGNY it would take some time. But it does seem some of the challenges are maybe a little bit bigger than expected. You did talk about some tactics, bonus bags, new packaging. But frankly and just my opinion, they seem a little more like Band-Aid than real sustainable fixes to the product and its positioning. So I'm just curious, in the face of these tough trends, what gives you the confidence that the issues are still only temporary? Is the strategy around dry dog still the right one? Or do you have to make more dramatic changes if things don't get fixed in the next couple of quarters?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Barry, and Mark, you can add additional comments to this. As you know, the Kibbles 'n Bits brand, its struggle is not just recent. That brand has been struggling over the past year or so. As we stepped into the business with a new team, we felt fu
componenttext: This is Barry, and Mark, you can add additional comments to this. As you know, the Kibbles 'n Bits brand, its struggle is not just recent. That brand has been struggling over the past year or so. As we stepped into the business with a new team, we felt fundamentals had to be right, especially around pricing. So we felt that was the first thing we needed to do to fix the price on shelf. What we're seeing with the bonus bags is it is decelerating the losses that we were seeing previously. So we do think it's working. That was fundamental to fixing the business. We still think the brand is relevant. We've shared our marketing plans with our key retail partners, and they also believe the brand still has a relevance in that segment of dry dog food. They support our plans behind the brand and are willing to continue to work with us in that segment. So we're not going to turn it around in a quarter or 2, but we still think the Kibbles 'n Bits brand has relevance to the consumer in that segment. And then the mass premium segment, which, as you know, we do not have a place in that segment currently, we continue to evaluate acquisitions, licensing or launching one of our existing brands in that segment. That is front and center for our team, and we will continue to focus on a solution for that segment based on what's right long term for us to participate in that category. So we're still committed to the brand. We think it has a place, and we think just getting the fundamentals are just foundational.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- this is Mark Smucker, Ken. I think Barry said it. I mean, at the end of the day, it's really about blocking and tackling, getting the fundamentals right, as Barry said, and then making sure that we have the right plans over the next few quarter
componenttext: I think -- this is Mark Smucker, Ken. I think Barry said it. I mean, at the end of the day, it's really about blocking and tackling, getting the fundamentals right, as Barry said, and then making sure that we have the right plans over the next few quarters to address the mass premium segment. And I feel better certainly now with Barry's support and his leadership that we'll get there in the relatively near future.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from the line of Andrew Lazar of Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question will come from the line of Andrew Lazar of Barclays.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick things. One quick one first. With the earnings guidance for fiscal 2Q, I just want to make sure I'm using the correct base from last year's 2Q from which you expect, I think, earnings to be comparable because I know -- I don't know if you're usi
componenttext: Two quick things. One quick one first. With the earnings guidance for fiscal 2Q, I just want to make sure I'm using the correct base from last year's 2Q from which you expect, I think, earnings to be comparable because I know -- I don't know if you're using before amortization, before excluding amortization or not.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: It would -- Andrew, this is Mark Belgya. It would be the restated number, if you will, that would have been in the 8-K that we issued last month. I think $1.91, if I recall.
componenttext: It would -- Andrew, this is Mark Belgya. It would be the restated number, if you will, that would have been in the 8-K that we issued last month. I think $1.91, if I recall.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Perfect. That's helpful. And then I guess a little bit broader, I think in terms of the -- some of the Natural Balance commentary, you've mentioned the pet superstore channel having slowed a bit, and that was, I think, the reason you pointed to, maybe thi
componenttext: Perfect. That's helpful. And then I guess a little bit broader, I think in terms of the -- some of the Natural Balance commentary, you've mentioned the pet superstore channel having slowed a bit, and that was, I think, the reason you pointed to, maybe thinking growth there would be a little bit less robust, at least in the near to intermediate term on that brand. And we have seen some of that in the data to be sure. But I guess the -- maybe the depth of the decline in the quarter itself, I know some of that was the year-over-year lap. But I guess I'm just trying to get a sense of whether it was -- do you think it's purely just the superstore channel that's impacting your outlook? Or perhaps whether you can comment on where you are around sort of shelf space and whether you've held on to share and, I guess, share of shelf given all the space that you were able to commandeer over the last year with a lot of the launches into PetSmart and Tractor Supply, things like that. Just trying to get a sense of where -- I guess, how the shelf productivity is and how the repeat purchase has been in some of these channels where you've stepped up for your presence.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Barry. Let me just add some commentary on Natural Balance. I'd say, overall, we are -- we've pulled back our expectations similar to our competitors, where we've just seen slowing in the pet specialty channel. Relative to the health of the Natural Ba
componenttext: It's Barry. Let me just add some commentary on Natural Balance. I'd say, overall, we are -- we've pulled back our expectations similar to our competitors, where we've just seen slowing in the pet specialty channel. Relative to the health of the Natural Balance brand as far as shelf space and performance, we're still encouraged by it. We think it's where we expect it to be. We have not lost any shelf space. Both of the -- our key retailers in the pet specialty channel are supporting the brand and working with us, taking incremental SKUs. Actually, we've actually added some additional items that we've recently presented to those retailers. So overall, we're still pleased with the performance of that brand based on the expanded distribution last year. But I think that, that channel is just seeing some overall slowdown in traffic. This one other comment I would add is -- around that brand is we are seeing some nice growth in e-commerce. And that channel is growing double digits, high double digits, small base, but we're really seeing some nice growth with that brand in that specific channel. And we'll continue to look how we can further accelerate that growth as well.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from David Driscoll of Citi.
componenttext: And our next question will come from David Driscoll of Citi.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask a question about the synergies. So can you -- it's $100 million for the year, $32 million in the quarter. Can you just explain a little bit here why annualize that number? Obviously, I get to well more than $100 million. Is there upside pote
componenttext: Wanted to ask a question about the synergies. So can you -- it's $100 million for the year, $32 million in the quarter. Can you just explain a little bit here why annualize that number? Obviously, I get to well more than $100 million. Is there upside potential for the synergies on the year and kind of maybe why not if given the performance in the quarter?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of things, David. This is Mark Belgya. We put out $100 million, and that will bring us up to about $140 million in total. There is some upside, some of which is the timing. We have a lot of activities we're tied in around the end of the fiscal ye
componenttext: A couple of things, David. This is Mark Belgya. We put out $100 million, and that will bring us up to about $140 million in total. There is some upside, some of which is the timing. We have a lot of activities we're tied in around the end of the fiscal year, so some of that came through, but we expect that to continue to pace through. And again, we feel pretty confident. We're very confident on the $200 million by the end of next year. It might pick up a little bit in the pace during the year. We'll have a little bit more color on as we move to the next quarter probably, but we're very pleased. I think, if I recall, at the end of the fourth quarter, I think, we were at $15 million or $16 million recognized and picked up to 32. So nice jump. And we'll see if we can keep that pace going.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to add one more on this pet food topic. Barry, really like to understand kind of -- you knew many of the problems that were going on a few months ago when you gave the original forecast. To see the sales reduction guidance again, I mean, we've ki
componenttext: I wanted to add one more on this pet food topic. Barry, really like to understand kind of -- you knew many of the problems that were going on a few months ago when you gave the original forecast. To see the sales reduction guidance again, I mean, we've kind of been hit with multiple revisions, [indiscernible] guidance on pet food, and it seems to keep happening. Number one, what's the confidence on this forecast? And number two, what changed in -- during the quarter? Was it the slowdown on the superstore growth that really causes the revision? Or is it just an ongoing worsening issue within Kibbles? Could we already knew that one was a problem? I guess and I'm really trying to get after is what changed just within the last several months that's caused the latest of the guide downs on revenues?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- just think, it's just going to take us a little longer to stabilize the business. We -- it's just going to, I think just taken a little more time to get that stabilization. And once we stabilize the business, then we can get it growing again. I
componenttext: I think -- just think, it's just going to take us a little longer to stabilize the business. We -- it's just going to, I think just taken a little more time to get that stabilization. And once we stabilize the business, then we can get it growing again. I just think our performance in the first quarter was not what we expected. And based on a combination of both Kibbles and Meow Mix and the softness in the first quarter is what really drove us to be a bit more conservative on the back half of the year.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And remember, David, this is Mark Smucker, that we got the pricing and the fundamentals in the bonus bags right in -- basically in June. So we're now just starting to see those products in markets. So to Barry's point, we do feel confident that we should
componenttext: And remember, David, this is Mark Smucker, that we got the pricing and the fundamentals in the bonus bags right in -- basically in June. So we're now just starting to see those products in markets. So to Barry's point, we do feel confident that we should see some leveling off here in the next quarter or so and start to shore up that business. And then again going back to slightly longer-term view is making sure we have the right actions, right in the mass premium segment. And as we think about how we address that, we certainly want to think about growing into the market and getting it right at the first time. So we're incredibly focused on the execution and making sure that as we do roll out plans in that segment, we're prepared, and we're going to do it right.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one quick follow-up. Did you guys say what's your expectation was for the premium pet food growth this year? I know the expectation has moderated, but -- and apologize if I missed it, but did you say to what level of growth do you think premium g
componenttext: And just one quick follow-up. Did you guys say what's your expectation was for the premium pet food growth this year? I know the expectation has moderated, but -- and apologize if I missed it, but did you say to what level of growth do you think premium grows for the year?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: The growth would be low single digits for the premium brands.
componenttext: The growth would be low single digits for the premium brands.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Robert Moskow of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Robert Moskow of Crédit Suisse.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: This question is for Mark Belgya. Mark, I think, in your prepared remarks, you said that this was a quarter where your pricing lagged, or I guess, your pricing was down more than deflation helped you. And I want to know, is that a trend that we should exp
componenttext: This question is for Mark Belgya. Mark, I think, in your prepared remarks, you said that this was a quarter where your pricing lagged, or I guess, your pricing was down more than deflation helped you. And I want to know, is that a trend that we should expect to continue for the rest of the year? Your gross profit dollars were down in first quarter. And I just want to get a sense of how you're thinking about the rest of the year, too.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rob, for the question. No, it's not something that we would necessarily expect continue to be favorable in the input costs, I think in my comments in Consumer Foods, in particular. But in terms of the current quarter, what we saw a little bit on -
componenttext: Thanks, Rob, for the question. No, it's not something that we would necessarily expect continue to be favorable in the input costs, I think in my comments in Consumer Foods, in particular. But in terms of the current quarter, what we saw a little bit on -- and I think we mentioned to this at our call in June and then touched on today as well, is that in addition to the price declines we took, we also had some additional trade came through sort of from a change in timing. So that too is considered price. So the combination of those 2 exceeded the net commodity cost reduction, but we wouldn't expect that to continue throughout the year. So obviously, the biggest pricing impact in general versus a year ago hit in Q1 because of the coffee. So just a pricing impact overall would be less as we move through. We'll, obviously, still feel the 6% we took on coffee this year, but as you know, we lapped it otherwise. So a little bit of an anomaly. And I guess, just if I can, while I'm thinking of pricing and just sales in general, I think it's -- I'd like to just laid it out there, and again, I respect everyone's modeling, but if we do look at the combination of the milk and the impact of pricing the coffee had, and I guess I'm just turning back the clock a couple of months, those 2 pieces in total were probably about $90 million to $100 million, the first quarter sales impact. So I think in Mark's scripted comments, we talked about our sales being just slightly below plans. So we had factored a good portion of that in. But certainly, I can understand for the reaction when you see the negative 7 year-over-year. So I just wanted to call that out an additional data point for everybody.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That might be a good segue for a question on revenue management. Mark Smucker, I believe, you have a new functional head in revenue management internally. Can you give us a little bit of an update on what he's working on for you? And when do you exp
componenttext: Okay. That might be a good segue for a question on revenue management. Mark Smucker, I believe, you have a new functional head in revenue management internally. Can you give us a little bit of an update on what he's working on for you? And when do you expect to see the results of that?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question, Rob. Yes, we do actually have a new head of revenue management. In fact, one of the things that we spoke about, I think, on the last call was that some of the incremental savings that we've targeted are going to be invested in cap
componenttext: Thanks for the question, Rob. Yes, we do actually have a new head of revenue management. In fact, one of the things that we spoke about, I think, on the last call was that some of the incremental savings that we've targeted are going to be invested in capabilities like that. That is one of several. I would describe some of the capabilities as we've sort of taken a step back and reorganized ourselves to make sure that we're building the right capabilities that related to the consumer. And that could be things like insights and data to ensure a robust innovation pipeline as well as the customer in terms of how we do business with them, and how we ensure that we're giving them the absolute best content. So revenue management would be one piece of that. And we're at a stage now where we've done a nice job of building the organization, and we're in the process of ensuring that those new organizations and functions are wired properly. And so that takes a little bit of time as we get to a full year planning and so forth. But at this point, we're very, very pleased with the leadership we have across many of our functions. And as it relates specifically to the revenue management, our goal over the next year or 2 are to begin to become increasingly more efficient in our trade spend so that we can truly drive incremental sales. That's ultimately the goal.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Mario Contreras of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Mario Contreras of Deutsche Bank.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I believe last quarter you mentioned that your cat food brands had seen some growth. It looks like the trends reversed a little bit this quarter. I believe you mentioned that those were down. Can you talk a little bit about the trends in that category?
componenttext: So I believe last quarter you mentioned that your cat food brands had seen some growth. It looks like the trends reversed a little bit this quarter. I believe you mentioned that those were down. Can you talk a little bit about the trends in that category? Is this anything specific to worsen competitive conditions or something specific to your brands?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mario, this is Barry. I would say what we experienced, especially this last quarter, was some competitive pricing activity with our major competitor in that category, which puts some pressure on the brand. So we've taken some programs back to our retail p
componenttext: Mario, this is Barry. I would say what we experienced, especially this last quarter, was some competitive pricing activity with our major competitor in that category, which puts some pressure on the brand. So we've taken some programs back to our retail partners and are working with them to get, again, the price right relative to our competition. That, combined with our advertising campaign, we just -- are on TV effective August 1, with a new advertising campaign behind the Meow Mix brand, which we think will provide great support for the business. So between those 2 activities, we think we'll address some of the short-term pressure that, that brand has experienced, but no other fundamental concerns with the brand, more short term versus longer term.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just one quick one on the Dunkin' K-Cups. So obviously, you're lapping the pipeline fill. Can you talk about some of the share trends you're seeing, especially in the last few weeks here? Are you still pretty confident that
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just one quick one on the Dunkin' K-Cups. So obviously, you're lapping the pipeline fill. Can you talk about some of the share trends you're seeing, especially in the last few weeks here? Are you still pretty confident that you're holding share or gaining share? And how do you feel about that trending over the next few quarters?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Mario, it's Steve. I think we're very encouraged by total K-Cup. I don't think it was in the prepared comments, but we saw what we call legacy or Folgers K-Cups in increase in volume for the quarter. And that's a nice turnaround given everything goi
componenttext: Sure. Mario, it's Steve. I think we're very encouraged by total K-Cup. I don't think it was in the prepared comments, but we saw what we call legacy or Folgers K-Cups in increase in volume for the quarter. And that's a nice turnaround given everything going on in the K-Cup category and all of the noise there and the deflation there. We saw strong K-Cup volume in our legacy brands. We continue to see strong takeaway for Dunkin'. We literally had trucks lined up at the door at midnight on May 1 a year ago when we launched this. So given the strength of that, we did not expect the same results, obviously, a year later. But we have more distribution today than we did a year ago. The turns remain very, very strong. And the Dunkin' Original K-Cup is the #1 K-Cup in most of the channels and most of the customers we saw up to. So that franchise continues to be alive and growing. So we're really pleased with that, but more pleased, I would say, that the legacy business is up over a year ago. So that's a great trend to reverse.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess, just to clarify, so would you expect the Dunkin' brand to return to growth here in the second quarter?
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess, just to clarify, so would you expect the Dunkin' brand to return to growth here in the second quarter?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, we would expect the Dunkin' brand in total. Our bag coffee business is up for the quarter, in the first quarter, which again is a nice trend reversal. Although we had a fantastic year last year, that was driven mostly by core Folgers Red Can. It
componenttext: Yes. Yes, we would expect the Dunkin' brand in total. Our bag coffee business is up for the quarter, in the first quarter, which again is a nice trend reversal. Although we had a fantastic year last year, that was driven mostly by core Folgers Red Can. It's nice to see our Red Can momentum continue in the first quarter, but also our legacy K-Cup and our Dunkin' bag business improved. So both of those things have improved in the first quarter.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from Alexia Howard of Bernstein.
componenttext: And our next question will come from Alexia Howard of Bernstein.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I am focusing on the U.S. Retail business side for a moment. The 2% organic sales growth decline, I understand that it was largely price investment, but it sounds as though that was broadly in line with your expectations. Is that -- should we think abo
componenttext: So I am focusing on the U.S. Retail business side for a moment. The 2% organic sales growth decline, I understand that it was largely price investment, but it sounds as though that was broadly in line with your expectations. Is that -- should we think about that as the continued run rate for the business, given the challenges that are going on in that retailer environment? And as you think about the bits that are growing nicely, like Sahale and Knudsen, does that shape how you think about your bolt-on acquisition strategy going forward? I know you're probably not in a position to do acquisitions yet, but might you have to shore up that business with the more softer-growing health and wellness-type brand?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alexia, it's Mark Smucker. The second part of your question, yes. I think we're really pleased with our natural and organic -- not only the smaller businesses like our beverage business and Sahale, both we're very pleased with right now. And so as we thin
componenttext: Alexia, it's Mark Smucker. The second part of your question, yes. I think we're really pleased with our natural and organic -- not only the smaller businesses like our beverage business and Sahale, both we're very pleased with right now. And so as we think about other segments or categories, that would be one area that we would look in terms of bolt-ons, but we just also remain focused as well, even in our mainstream businesses, that in some cases where we have businesses where we have simple ingredients, more natural offerings, cleaner ingredient decks, so those businesses are areas that we will continue to focus on. And I think, quite frankly, you're hearing that pretty broadly from our entire industry, so I don't think -- I think most of us are saying a lot of the same things based on a lot of the same trends. So, yes. In the first part of your question, did I answer?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kind of the 2% decline in organic sales growth with the price investments, is that kind of a run rate for now in terms of how we should think about business?
componenttext: Kind of the 2% decline in organic sales growth with the price investments, is that kind of a run rate for now in terms of how we should think about business?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alexia, this as Mark Belgya. What I would do is, I would say that for our Consumer Foods business and if you [indiscernible] little bit to Knudsen and milk. But if you take the milk out, we would expect that business to be up modestly. And then coffee, it
componenttext: Alexia, this as Mark Belgya. What I would do is, I would say that for our Consumer Foods business and if you [indiscernible] little bit to Knudsen and milk. But if you take the milk out, we would expect that business to be up modestly. And then coffee, it's going to get drag down a little bit in the continuing quarters because of the 6% price decline we took here in July -- or I'm sorry, in May of this year. But short of that, we will see some volume growth come out, which will offset a little bit of that price impact. So the math probably works out for somewhere kind of flattish, I would guess, if you just look at the Consumer Foods and the coffee together with your [indiscernible] U.S. Retail. And as we've mentioned out, the pet is going to be down, so that would pull the overall average of those 3 reportable segments down below flat, probably negative 1 to 2, I guess.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: But at the same time, we are in a very deflationary environment as we've seen several of our customers have reported top line good comp sales growth, but some still top line challenges. And I think that's just systemic at the moment, though we should -- w
componenttext: But at the same time, we are in a very deflationary environment as we've seen several of our customers have reported top line good comp sales growth, but some still top line challenges. And I think that's just systemic at the moment, though we should -- with commodities moving, we're probably going to see some change there over time.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from John Baumgartner of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: And our next question will come from John Baumgartner of Wells Fargo.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Barry, I'd like to ask, in terms of mainstream pet, a few of your larger competitors have adopted natural or grain-free offshoots of their core brands. When you think about it, I mean, how much of an incremental headwind is that proving to be free you in
componenttext: Barry, I'd like to ask, in terms of mainstream pet, a few of your larger competitors have adopted natural or grain-free offshoots of their core brands. When you think about it, I mean, how much of an incremental headwind is that proving to be free you in mainstream, maybe relative to view the landscape at the time of the acquisition?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's clearly a trend in mainstream. And as we look at entering the mass premium segment, that has to be front and center for us as we look at what entry strategy would be. So again, as we look at what the consumer is interested in and what their pr
componenttext: Yes, that's clearly a trend in mainstream. And as we look at entering the mass premium segment, that has to be front and center for us as we look at what entry strategy would be. So again, as we look at what the consumer is interested in and what their preferences are, so that will be a part of our thinking as we think about an entry strategy.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we think about the -- as a followup, when we think about the premium space, the next phase of distribution for Natural Balance or even Nature's Recipe, I think a few months ago, there was some commentary pertaining to runway independence, as an examp
componenttext: When we think about the -- as a followup, when we think about the premium space, the next phase of distribution for Natural Balance or even Nature's Recipe, I think a few months ago, there was some commentary pertaining to runway independence, as an example. What is the phasing for that stand? And at what point is incremental distribution begin to kick in? And [indiscernible] lastly, how are you seeing the interplay between Nature's Recipe and Natural Balance in terms of incrementality versus some cannibalization impact there?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: They each have their own position in the pet specialty segment, where Nature's Recipe is more of an entry brand into pet specialty, the Natural Balance is a much more premium segment with a focus on limited ingredient diet. So they each have a unique posi
componenttext: They each have their own position in the pet specialty segment, where Nature's Recipe is more of an entry brand into pet specialty, the Natural Balance is a much more premium segment with a focus on limited ingredient diet. So they each have a unique positioning in that channel. As far as the independent channel being incremental, we focus on that channel just like we do the other main retailers in pet specialty, but that -- the independent trade is not going to drive the growth of those brands. Most of our growth is going to come from the lead retailers in that channel.

componenttext: That's helpful. And then the second one is back on pet food. You are about to cycle into some very low and very favorable input costs in both corn and soybeans and a lot of your other inputs. How are you thinking about managing pricing versus margin in that mainstream brands given that you're getting such a great commodity tailwind?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the pricing, again, we have to be front and center competitive with our -- the other 2 primary competitors that we compete with. So as a third player in that category, we'll continue just to be competitive with the 2 primary competitors. So that
componenttext: As far as the pricing, again, we have to be front and center competitive with our -- the other 2 primary competitors that we compete with. So as a third player in that category, we'll continue just to be competitive with the 2 primary competitors. So that will be our focus. We'll manage our commodities in our pet business just like we do in our other businesses, and that will be part of our pricing strategy.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] to that if I may just add is that, I guess, to the Barry's latter point, I think we've made pretty consistently over the years that we've owned, first of all, with the Crisco business and then the coffee that there's always going to be tim
componenttext: [indiscernible] to that if I may just add is that, I guess, to the Barry's latter point, I think we've made pretty consistently over the years that we've owned, first of all, with the Crisco business and then the coffee that there's always going to be timing as you match up the cost of that commodity with the pricing, but we've done a very good job both as prices gone up and prices gone down generally to maintain the margin dollars and grow those dollars over time. So I think, we would, as Barry suggested, we're going to have to move it's price being #3 in the category, but focus on the fact that we've been able to grow those margin dollars over time.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well. And Farha, Steve Oakland. One thing that when Barry talked earlier about getting the fundamentals right, one of the things that the Big Heart business coming into Smucker one of the capabilities that they got is our commodity buying team or hedging
componenttext: Well. And Farha, Steve Oakland. One thing that when Barry talked earlier about getting the fundamentals right, one of the things that the Big Heart business coming into Smucker one of the capabilities that they got is our commodity buying team or hedging team. We have a much more sophisticated -- driven by the fact that we're in the coffee business as we are, and we're in the other grains businesses that we're in. So a number of the commodities that are input costs for that all run through those same systems. So I think we have a more sophisticated system. And we have capabilities that will allow Barry and the team to know what their costs are going out further to be able to participate in the downside projecting from the upside. So it's a much more robust set of capabilities applied against that business. Now it takes time for those to impact it, and we're in the process of that now. But those commodity tailwinds, as you call them, that you spoke about, Barry and the team will have the same capabilities to achieve those that we have in the other businesses now.

But can you give us a sense of what the plan is now on total dollars spending relative to what it was? And where that -- so give us some sense of where those funds are shifting to like what quarter? And if there's any particular reason why they may have shifted even relative to your plan.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Akshay, for the question. In terms of total marketing spend for the total company for the total year, we expect to be basically on our plan as expected. What you're going to see is, you're going to see a little bit of a shift in that. There'
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Akshay, for the question. In terms of total marketing spend for the total company for the total year, we expect to be basically on our plan as expected. What you're going to see is, you're going to see a little bit of a shift in that. There's a likelihood -- although the first quarter that it was timing on pets, mostly the 13% decline, I think, we spoke to with pet related. That's going to shift -- a good portion of that's going to shift in Q2. There probably still be a little bit less than planned for the whole year. However, in our other businesses, we're seeing a little bit uptick in marketing. So net-net, we'll be at exactly where we thought we're going to be at the start of the year which is, I think, around 6.2%, 6.3% of sales.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a couple more sort of high level. First one is on coffee related to revenue management and perhaps your hedging strategy. And I know, Mark, you've managed the coffee business as well. So in term -- as you look at the next 3 to 5 years,
componenttext: Okay. And then just a couple more sort of high level. First one is on coffee related to revenue management and perhaps your hedging strategy. And I know, Mark, you've managed the coffee business as well. So in term -- as you look at the next 3 to 5 years, I mean, when you previous to your ownership, Folgers had a pretty open-policy hedging, which [indiscernible] to the market on [indiscernible] prices are going to go and from talking to people in the industry, since you've gone away from that over the last 4 or 5 years, there's been a little bit more disruption competitively as a result. That's one argument. Have you considered maybe just making a broader change there with not only [indiscernible] modeling, but one would argue maybe makes the competitive environment a little bit more rational. That's one question. And I have a followup on pet.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Akshay, it's Steve Oakland. I think, before Smucker bought it under P&G, it might have been a little more formulaic, right? And I think it might have been a little bit more transparent. But if you think about how different the coffee category is tod
componenttext: Sure. Akshay, it's Steve Oakland. I think, before Smucker bought it under P&G, it might have been a little more formulaic, right? And I think it might have been a little bit more transparent. But if you think about how different the coffee category is today than it was then, that was pre-K-Cups. That was when blue can was a material piece of this category. And then that was when we had different owners of our competitive brands that had different strategies and different behavior. So I think if you look at the momentum last year, you look at the first quarter in coffee, we feel really good about our balance of cost and our balance of coverage. I think, we think we're uniquely different in that we tie our commodity team to our business team, and that our commodity team not only understands how to buy at the right prices, they understand when we need those prices in the marketplace. So it may be more difficult for the outside world to understand, but I think we're really happy with how is -- what it's delivering for us from a business unit standpoint. I think we'll stick -- we'll probably stay with where we are.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one on pet. Again, this is more a long-term focus question. I mean, I understand there's some competitive issues on the dry side, and you're sharpening your price points and then that seems like, more like surgical moves. But the broader trend is
componenttext: And just one on pet. Again, this is more a long-term focus question. I mean, I understand there's some competitive issues on the dry side, and you're sharpening your price points and then that seems like, more like surgical moves. But the broader trend is the pet population seems to have started growing in the recent past, so that's a good trend, and there's a broader trend of premiumization. Your portfolio should be better suited to that than your competitors. I mean, are we entering a stage like we were like, maybe 4 years ago on coffee, where there is a shift from mainstream to premium, a broader shift, that we should be maybe thinking of in light of your exposure to the mainstream side? Is that what we're seeing broadly as people are premiumizing maybe the mainstream category is just over skewed, and that's why we're seeing as much competitive activity as we're seeing?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: Akshay, it's Barry. Let me just provide some commentary on that. To you point, as we're seeing more humanization of pets and consumers looking you at more premium products. But I think we would stay consistent with our strategy of making sure we participa
componenttext: Akshay, it's Barry. Let me just provide some commentary on that. To you point, as we're seeing more humanization of pets and consumers looking you at more premium products. But I think we would stay consistent with our strategy of making sure we participate in every segment of the category. It's still a place for our value brands like Kibbles 'n Bits and Gravy Train in that segment. We have some great brands in pet specialty. Our snack brands cut across all other segments as well and are great brands. We've been driving category growth in the snack category, and our retailers attribute that to our innovation efforts. So I think our strategy in pet is going to be like it is in every other segment, is just every other category we participate in, is just make sure we meet the consumer needs however they define value and that will be a consistent strategy we apply in pet. So we -- it's a great category, great brands. We think, for long term, it's definitely the right business for us to be in. So we're going to leverage the scale and capabilities of broader $8 billion company to continue to grow the pet business.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Aug 23, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right, this is Mark Smucker. Just a couple of closing comments, I have. Obviously, there have been a few, obviously, lot of questions on pet. Just want to reiterate our confidence in the business. We believe in the business. Barry just mentioned a few
componenttext: All right, this is Mark Smucker. Just a couple of closing comments, I have. Obviously, there have been a few, obviously, lot of questions on pet. Just want to reiterate our confidence in the business. We believe in the business. Barry just mentioned a few minutes ago, just the brands are fantastic. And although we've talked quite a bit about mainstream dog today, we feel very good about where we're at in our premium segment, our ability to address, and we started to do that on the mainstream side. And very importantly, our snacks business, pet snacks is going very well, our shares are very healthy there. And so as with all of the other categories that we're in, we're very comfortable and confident in competing with our peers, and we compete against many of the same players in some of the other categories, and we've got a proven ability to grow brands, in which are categories. So wanted to leave you with that thought. And then, again, we didn't talk much today about the Olympics, but the Olympics has been very good for our brands. We're going to probably see some halo affect from a consumer perspective. And then we're going to continue to focus on what we're good at: executing, blocking and tackling, making sure that we have the best consumer engagement possible by supporting our products that we have in market; and then of course, delivering against or exceeding our synergy and our working capital targets. So once again, just want to thank our talented team of employees. They are fantastic. We would not have been able to deliver the fantastic results this quarter without them. And so many, many thanks to our dedicated employees, and thank you to all of you for joining us today. Have a great week.
