componenttext: The treats part, the pet's treats part, that's obviously high margin historically, but the growth peak of the business seems to be falling in measured channels.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a fair point. One of the things that Mark commented is we had seen some of the shift as part of their sales this quarter where we have some promotional activity that shifted into the third quarter. But the snack category is still growing. Ther
componenttext: Yes, that's a fair point. One of the things that Mark commented is we had seen some of the shift as part of their sales this quarter where we have some promotional activity that shifted into the third quarter. But the snack category is still growing. There has been a slight decline in that growth. Milk-Bone though is still growing. We have a 60% share of the biscuit category. We just took #1 position with Pup-Peroni in the soft and chewy category. So we still have some great momentum with our brands and some innovation in the pipeline that, we think, will be recharge the growth of that category. So overall, brands are healthy. The category is growing. And our -- we still have a lot of upside in that segment of our business.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And as a follow-up, can I ask about your appetite for acquisition? Has leverage now come down to a point where you can start to consider medium to large-scale acquisitions again? What are your criteria there? And how much incremental leverage will
componenttext: Great. And as a follow-up, can I ask about your appetite for acquisition? Has leverage now come down to a point where you can start to consider medium to large-scale acquisitions again? What are your criteria there? And how much incremental leverage will be -- would you be prepared to take on at this point if there was something out there that you really wanted?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alexia, Mark Belgya. Great question. As we have consistently said prior, the better part of over a year now is the closer we get to a 3-timer undelevered, it opens up the door to some of the strategic things we can do. It's not a hard and fast. We need to
componenttext: Alexia, Mark Belgya. Great question. As we have consistently said prior, the better part of over a year now is the closer we get to a 3-timer undelevered, it opens up the door to some of the strategic things we can do. It's not a hard and fast. We need to get there. If there's an opportunity that comes along, we're comfortable of levering up. I think in terms -- and maybe I'll ask for Mark to comment on this in a moment, but just in terms of what we're looking for and what's out there, there are a number of assets that you can imagine that I would call more of the small to mid-sized bolt-on opportunities, a lot around sort of the trends, whether it's convenience, good -- and good-for-you type products, clean label products, a lot in the natural space. And so we have been looking and have not necessarily limited ourselves just because where we are from a leveraged position, particularly as it relates to bolt-ons, and we'll continue to do that. In terms of where we would lever, we went over 4x with the transaction of Big Heart. And what I would frame in is to say that we were comfortable there. And the reason we were comfortable is the cash generation that came out of that transaction, both from the business itself and the synergy opportunities, and the quickness of the pay down made it comfortable. So is that a hard and fast target? Maybe, maybe not. But certainly, we've proven that we were willing to go up there as long as there is a good sense of the cash generation out of that.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alexia. It's Mark Smucker. Just to add that strategically, acquisitions for us are clearly still part of our strategy. We've deemphasized them for our long-term growth rates because we've -- as we talk to our investors and you folks, we wanted to mak
componenttext: Yes, Alexia. It's Mark Smucker. Just to add that strategically, acquisitions for us are clearly still part of our strategy. We've deemphasized them for our long-term growth rates because we've -- as we talk to our investors and you folks, we wanted to make sure that we are focusing on the growth that we can deliver out of our existing business. But it certainly is still part of our strategy. We always say we keep our lines in the water and if things come up, whether they'd be large iconic leading brands or businesses like that, but also as Mark mentioned, the more -- the smaller more on-trend things are clearly part of the strategy as well and getting that balance right is key.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert Moskow with Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Moskow with Crédit Suisse.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just trying to go back to recent history. I think the last time you took an increase on pricing in coffee was fiscal '15 and that led to a pretty substantial decline in profits for the division. So my question is, do you think you're in better shape
componenttext: I was just trying to go back to recent history. I think the last time you took an increase on pricing in coffee was fiscal '15 and that led to a pretty substantial decline in profits for the division. So my question is, do you think you're in better shape this time once you have to start raising coffee prices to manage your portion of the profit pool and still grow profits? Or do you think there's a risk to that? The second question, I dug a little deeper into Meow Mix. I saw the declines in the retail sales. And I remember you said that the advertising campaign had actually started in August, but you were on air in August. Did you have to take that ad campaign off air? And is that part of the reason why the sales on Meow Mix declined?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rob, Steve. I'll start with the coffee price increase dialogue. And then Barry, you can follow up on the cat food. Rob, I think there's a couple of things we need to think about today versus then. Obviously, we took coffee pricing down because we had coff
componenttext: Rob, Steve. I'll start with the coffee price increase dialogue. And then Barry, you can follow up on the cat food. Rob, I think there's a couple of things we need to think about today versus then. Obviously, we took coffee pricing down because we had coffee cost that could support that. Coffee costs were relatively low even compared to any kind of averages, right? So it would be reasonable to think that in that kind of environment, we would have been longer than normal, right? And so as we've seen coffee cost go up, yes, they're up, but they're only up. If you think about $1.70 Arabica, it's not that much over the 5- or 10-year average, right? So those are not high coffee costs. If you think about what we've seen in past years in the $2, $2.50, $2.70 type of thing. So we don't think Arabica is in -- anywhere near those kinds of price points. We've also learned a lot from that one instance where we took price up and we crossed 2 deciles. If you remember, we took 2 deciles on our key promoted sizes. And we would have coverage in place that would not cause us to have to do that. So if there is pricing in coffee, we think it will be much more measured. And then the last thing I'll remind you, Rob, is the downsize we did in the container. And so if you remember in that time frame, our competitor was promoting an 11% smaller container than we were, and now that our containers are similar. So I think there's a couple of dynamics that would suggest the coffee pricing that we would see today are project, certainly through this fiscal year, but well into next year. It's not going to put us in the position that we were in when it impacted our margins. So we feel good about it.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, the only other thing I would add is -- and I just kind of thought this and I'm not sure how material it is. But the other thing is if you look since that time, we had the addition of the Dunkin' K-Cup. So we've got another couple hundred million do
componenttext: Steve, the only other thing I would add is -- and I just kind of thought this and I'm not sure how material it is. But the other thing is if you look since that time, we had the addition of the Dunkin' K-Cup. So we've got another couple hundred million dollars of sales that are in the category that's not impacted as much by pricing change.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And dynamics?
componenttext: Okay. And dynamics?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, happy -- this is Barry. Just happy to answer that for you as well. As far as Meow Mix is concerned, we have had some of the most significant innovation against that brand this past year in the form of our Bistro launch with the strategy of how do we
componenttext: Sure, happy -- this is Barry. Just happy to answer that for you as well. As far as Meow Mix is concerned, we have had some of the most significant innovation against that brand this past year in the form of our Bistro launch with the strategy of how do we leverage our strength in dry across wet and treats. The -- that launch where we have that product place has gone very well. We've seen trial and repeat strong. And we have advertising in place supporting that brand and that launch. So we're not off air. We're actually on air advertising. Sorry if you haven't seen that. But we are supporting that launch. And we're starting to see some nice momentum behind our total Meow Mix brand as a result of that launch. And we'll continue to fill distribution gaps with Bistro based on its performance in market. So we think that was the right decision across our -- what we're calling our Meow Mix total solution across each segment in cat. So innovation is  performing well and we think that has strengthened our position across the cat food category.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Jason English with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Jason English with Goldman Sachs.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to come back to the Nature's Recipe line of questioning. Are you planning for declines in pet specialty going forward across the portfolio?
componenttext: I want to come back to the Nature's Recipe line of questioning. Are you planning for declines in pet specialty going forward across the portfolio?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there will be some declines in pet specialty on that pet brand. So I think we'll probably see some reduced SKUs and assortment in pet specialty. So yes, there will be some decline in that channel. But what it allows us to do is focus on Natural Balan
componenttext: Yes, there will be some declines in pet specialty on that pet brand. So I think we'll probably see some reduced SKUs and assortment in pet specialty. So yes, there will be some decline in that channel. But what it allows us to do is focus on Natural Balance. We've said that's our flagship brand in that channel. And what it does is allow our team to really focus and get behind that brand because that will be the main driver of growth in that channel.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is a long time ago, but I think P&G did something similar 15, 20 years ago, somewhere in that time frame and it impacted your whole portfolio in terms of retailer backlash. I'm sure you guys have studied that case study. It sounds like, from a planni
componenttext: This is a long time ago, but I think P&G did something similar 15, 20 years ago, somewhere in that time frame and it impacted your whole portfolio in terms of retailer backlash. I'm sure you guys have studied that case study. It sounds like, from a planning perspective, you're not really viewing that as the appropriate precedent since you're expecting sort of the rest of your portfolio do better. So can you help us understand maybe why that isn't the appropriate precedent?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're certainly aware of what took place. But I think as I stated earlier, I think there's no question that the consumer demand for this type of product in the mass and grocery channels is there, and our retailers have confirmed that with us. So yes, we'v
componenttext: We're certainly aware of what took place. But I think as I stated earlier, I think there's no question that the consumer demand for this type of product in the mass and grocery channels is there, and our retailers have confirmed that with us. So yes, we've given this a lot of thought, Jason, just based on precedent and understanding channel impact. But we're confident based on the launch, both in specialty and in mass and grocery that this was the right decision. And the marketing investment we're going to put behind this brand to make sure that it turns and it's successful with the consumer as well.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jason, it's Mark Smucker. I would add that they are -- we're in different times. As Barry said, I think the demand in the mass premium segment is strong. But I actually think a lot of the credit goes to our team and Barry -- our sales team and Barry's tea
componenttext: Jason, it's Mark Smucker. I would add that they are -- we're in different times. As Barry said, I think the demand in the mass premium segment is strong. But I actually think a lot of the credit goes to our team and Barry -- our sales team and Barry's team as you think about how good our relationships are with our customers. They go all the way up to the very top of the organization, and that really does make a difference. And even just thinking about what we're bringing to the table in the pet specialty channel, and we're able to support the Natural Balance brand as well, and so bringing those additional -- that additional support to the table helps with that relationship as well and helps offset some of what might be -- maybe a reduced SKU count.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from John Baumgartner with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from John Baumgartner with Wells Fargo.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, I wanted to come back to your comments on mainstream pet. So I can appreciate that the magnitude of the volume declines have moderated, but the depth of decline, it's still pretty meaningful even after you went on reduced prices. So can you speak t
componenttext: Sorry, I wanted to come back to your comments on mainstream pet. So I can appreciate that the magnitude of the volume declines have moderated, but the depth of decline, it's still pretty meaningful even after you went on reduced prices. So can you speak to what comes next? I mean, what really gets you back to flat volumes in that mainstream price point and ideally back to growth? Is it something of a hybrid approach where you can go and renovate around ingredients, but more of a mass price point? I mean, would you expect margin pressure to do that? Just maybe how much have you looked and really remains in that price point?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: So John, this is Barry. Let me add some color on that. First, we have recently seen even expanded distribution on the bonus bags, so we continue to make sure we get that distribution more broadly across the channel. And then as we think about support behi
componenttext: So John, this is Barry. Let me add some color on that. First, we have recently seen even expanded distribution on the bonus bags, so we continue to make sure we get that distribution more broadly across the channel. And then as we think about support behind the brand, we just have -- we have to bring some news to the Kibbles 'n Bits brand, go back to the taste equity. There's a consumer segment that is looking for taste and not at the expense of quality or a helpful product to their dog. So as we're thinking about that brand, how do we get back to the taste equity, offer that at a price that makes sense and then have some meaningful marketing support behind the brand to drive the growth of the Kibbles 'n Bits brands. So that is our plan, and we're confident that we're seeing enough stabilization that -- with that marketing investment. We'll get that brand back to slow growth.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Farha Aslam with Stephens.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Farha Aslam with Stephens.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is on Folgers. The volumes on that core business were down 10% in the quarter. Is there something to do with timing? Will that turn around next quarter?
componenttext: My first question is on Folgers. The volumes on that core business were down 10% in the quarter. Is there something to do with timing? Will that turn around next quarter?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Farha, I think if you look at the dollars, we're down 10%.  Volume was down 5%.  And if you look at that, most of that volume -- and again, this is a deep dive into IRI of Nielsen, but virtually, all of that was in our opening price point SKUs, what we ca
componenttext: Farha, I think if you look at the dollars, we're down 10%.  Volume was down 5%.  And if you look at that, most of that volume -- and again, this is a deep dive into IRI of Nielsen, but virtually, all of that was in our opening price point SKUs, what we call customer and -- those are items that we promote when coffee prices are very high. When coffee prices are low, they tend to struggle because there's very little gap between the 2. So I think we can provide that detail. But no, our -- in our classic roast item is actually up 2% in volume if you go through the numbers.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Farha, it's Mark Smucker. When you -- remember, when you see commodity cost, coffee cost as low as they have been and you get price compression in the category, our opening price point SKUs don't do as well because people trade up to classic roast, a
componenttext: Yes, Farha, it's Mark Smucker. When you -- remember, when you see commodity cost, coffee cost as low as they have been and you get price compression in the category, our opening price point SKUs don't do as well because people trade up to classic roast, and that's what we've seen.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's good for you if people trade up to classic roast. Is that ...
componenttext: And that's good for you if people trade up to classic roast. Is that ...

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, when -- yes. When you see coffee prices as low as they've been, people will trade up to classic roast. When they're -- when we see excessively high commodity cost, the elasticity will drive people down to the opening price point SKUs.
componenttext: Yes, when -- yes. When you see coffee prices as low as they've been, people will trade up to classic roast. When they're -- when we see excessively high commodity cost, the elasticity will drive people down to the opening price point SKUs.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you'll recall -- Farha, Mark here. If you'll recall couple of years ago, and actually a couple of times over the last 3 or 4 years, we talked about sort of the $10 price point. This is a good case where that obviously had come down and narrowed that pr
componenttext: As you'll recall -- Farha, Mark here. If you'll recall couple of years ago, and actually a couple of times over the last 3 or 4 years, we talked about sort of the $10 price point. This is a good case where that obviously had come down and narrowed that price gap between opening price points in our classic line.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And the price points -- our promoted price points on our 30.9 ounce canisters has been in the $6.99 realm, so we're well below those thresholds.
componenttext: Yes. And the price points -- our promoted price points on our 30.9 ounce canisters has been in the $6.99 realm, so we're well below those thresholds.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then for Barry, if you think about Natural Balance and Natural [sic] [ Nature's ] Recipe, what kind of growth can we expect on those 2 brands in 2017? And then if we think longer term, 2018 and beyond, how should we think about the growth of tho
componenttext: Okay. And then for Barry, if you think about Natural Balance and Natural [sic] [ Nature's ] Recipe, what kind of growth can we expect on those 2 brands in 2017? And then if we think longer term, 2018 and beyond, how should we think about the growth of those 2 brands?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me just -- we're actually not putting out specific numbers on Nature's Recipe. We're just in stage of launching that brand. What I would share with you is we would expect to have shelf space similar to our competitors in the mass and grocery channels,
componenttext: Let me just -- we're actually not putting out specific numbers on Nature's Recipe. We're just in stage of launching that brand. What I would share with you is we would expect to have shelf space similar to our competitors in the mass and grocery channels, so if you would just frame it in, in terms of shelf space based on our initial distribution. As far as Natural Balance growth, the balance of this year for this fiscal year -- remember, we're lapping last year's incremental distribution within the major retailer in that channel. But I would say year-over-year, if you take that out, we would expect to see growth of low single digits.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then beyond, like long term, is that the growth rate we can expect?
componenttext: And then beyond, like long term, is that the growth rate we can expect?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next year, I think, again, with the focus of our team on Natural Balance and the specialty channel, I think we'll see growth accelerate.  And we're also seeing some fantastic growth within e-commerce. We're seeing double-digit growth in that channel a
componenttext: The next year, I think, again, with the focus of our team on Natural Balance and the specialty channel, I think we'll see growth accelerate.  And we're also seeing some fantastic growth within e-commerce. We're seeing double-digit growth in that channel and a significant amount of the Natural Balance brand is similar to what we've seen in -- with other brands in pet specialty is that shift into e-commerce. We're experiencing the same thing, and that's where we're experiencing and seeing double-digit growth and would expect that to continue in that channel.

It seems like there might be a similar decline in both. And then two, regarding coffee. Is it fair to say that K-Cup sales growth were flat for the quarter with Folgers offsetting Dunkin' growth?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I guess what I would say is we haven't really changed much from what we said previously. I mean, mass right now has always been sort of a flat to just modestly above. We clearly have been running below that, but that's kind of where we see that ca
componenttext: Yes. So I guess what I would say is we haven't really changed much from what we said previously. I mean, mass right now has always been sort of a flat to just modestly above. We clearly have been running below that, but that's kind of where we see that category. It's a little plenary quite candidly to give you a really good number on the traditional grocery and mass channel just because we need to sort of see the effect of Nature's Recipe. I just --  I think Barry has commented about what we expect from the distribution capability of that Nature's Recipe. And there's enough out there that you can do some comparables to see kind of where the expectation is there. And then in specialty, I know that we've commented previously that the channel has slowed some. I think other competitors have noted similarities. But to Barry's point, albeit somewhat still small, but growing, the e-commerce cannot be taken lightly. And we still think there's a lot of opportunity in that channel. I think the other thing I'd reinforce in the Natural -- or the specialty area of for us, in particular, is there's still profitability opportunity. And we've seen that start to turn. We've talked about that. That was certainly an under-indexed category force as it related to our segment profit, we're seeing turns on that. So we still feel good about those channels. And again, I think with e-commerce, the Natural Balance focus, we'll see good growth.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And let me comment on K-Cups. And I think it depends on if you're looking at dollars or units because I'm sure we've guided to -- that there has been price compression in mainstream K-Cups or across all of K-Cups. I think you've heard that talked ab
componenttext: Sure. And let me comment on K-Cups. And I think it depends on if you're looking at dollars or units because I'm sure we've guided to -- that there has been price compression in mainstream K-Cups or across all of K-Cups. I think you've heard that talked about in our peers, our competitors' releases. And so our K-Cups in actual units and equivalent volume are up, both in Folgers, in Dunkin' and up dramatically, and quite frankly, in Bustelo, although a small business. That volume gain translates into dollar gains in Bustelo and in Dunkin'. The dollars are down a little bit in Folgers only because of the pricing that we've taken to support that. But the total K-Cup business is up nicely. So we feel really good the fact that our legacy K-Cup business grew in units. Our Dunkin' business is up dramatically. And our Bustelo business, frankly, is on fire. So those segments, all 3 were helping drive the mix on our coffee business.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Akshay Jagdale with Jefferies.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow up quickly, not specific to K-Cups, but related, so it's a coffee question. So you mentioned when coffee prices are low, you're opening price points and so the lower priced items struggle a bit and the premium items do better. Can yo
componenttext: I just want to follow up quickly, not specific to K-Cups, but related, so it's a coffee question. So you mentioned when coffee prices are low, you're opening price points and so the lower priced items struggle a bit and the premium items do better. Can you give us a rough estimate of the overall portfolio, like how much you would consider OPP, how much mainstream versus premium? And as prices go up next year, I'm guessing that, that -- this phenomena is going to reverse. So net-net, I think it's better for your company to have lower coffee cost. So just help me understand that dynamic. I mean, I'm just trying to think about next year your -- with prices going up, it looks like the environment to produce growth is a little bit worse than it was this year.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Akshay, let me attempt to do that. Our OPP business is relatively small in the mix, and it's concentrated in the retailers you would expect it to become concentrated in. It's a big business at the value retailers, right, whether that be the dollar channel
componenttext: Akshay, let me attempt to do that. Our OPP business is relatively small in the mix, and it's concentrated in the retailers you would expect it to become concentrated in. It's a big business at the value retailers, right, whether that be the dollar channel, mass retail channel, the club channel, okay? So those SKUs exist in those environments where the consumer goes for value. When you're promoting our 30.9 ounce canister at $6.99, a small difference in the everyday price of OPP does -- is not that exciting to the consumer. So yes, that will be a backstop for those consumers as coffee pricing moves up. But moving coffee price from, say, $6.99 to $7.99 doesn't scare me there. I think, Mark mentioned this in his opening, when OPP becomes very attractive is when you get to those $9.99, $10.99 price points. We have seen that in history. Remember, we downsized the canister. So I think we're insulated from some of that. So I don't want us to think that $1.70 Arabica takes us into any price point that we should all be afraid of, right? We obviously still think this is relatively moderately priced Arabica. So I think we're some way away from us having a discussion where we will be concerned about that the absolute price points having some kind of dramatic effect and swinging our volume within our mix.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Akshay, it's Mark Belgya. I guess, as I think back about what we've talked about over the years in terms of breakdown, broad-broad, I'd say about 2/3 of our total U.S. Retail Coffee sales will be considered mainstream, so that would include everythin
componenttext: Yes. Akshay, it's Mark Belgya. I guess, as I think back about what we've talked about over the years in terms of breakdown, broad-broad, I'd say about 2/3 of our total U.S. Retail Coffee sales will be considered mainstream, so that would include everything we talked about, complements, classic, OPPs, and then the other third obviously would fall between K-Cups and premium.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And just one quick follow-up on synergies. So this quarter, it seems like the synergy capture was certainly -- I mean, it was better than we had expected. Was it better than what you would had expected? And I don't think you've changed you
componenttext: That's helpful. And just one quick follow-up on synergies. So this quarter, it seems like the synergy capture was certainly -- I mean, it was better than we had expected. Was it better than what you would had expected? And I don't think you've changed your synergy guidance for the year. So can you help me bridge the 2?

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, it's Mark. Yes, our performance on synergies did exceed our expectations for Q2. And you're right, we haven't adjusted. I think, we would like to get a little bit more time. But there's no indications that we will not continue down our synergy
componenttext: Yes. Again, it's Mark. Yes, our performance on synergies did exceed our expectations for Q2. And you're right, we haven't adjusted. I think, we would like to get a little bit more time. But there's no indications that we will not continue down our synergy path. I think one way to think about our synergy number is we're talking about $100 million incremental through this year and $140 million capture through the end of this fiscal. But with programs in place, I would say that we're probably on a run rate right now at $180 million to $185 million. So said differently, we've got about $15 million to $20 million to tie down here in the next several months, and we'll have that $200 million locked in as we head into fiscal '18. So we're in really good shape. And the other comment, Akshay, I would say about synergies is on the SD&A, one of the things -- we talked about marketing. I know there's probably some discussion about the market shift being a major contributor to the earnings. But we did deliver pretty significant reductions in our, what I would call, administrative costs. So is that a combination of synergy recognitions? Though some of the additional synergies were falling there and some are quite candidly just very strong cost management across those organizations. So some of those dollars are just incremental savings program that people put in place above and beyond the $200 million synergy target.

componenttext: I just had 2. One, coming back to pet. I just -- I don't have a strong sense yet for what you're doing to build out that channel more aggressively and ensure that you don't end up in an under-indexed position 12, 18 months from now.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matthew, this is Mark Smucker. I'll start and if Barry has anything to add, he can certainly chime in. So first of all, as you know, our industry is, generally speaking, underdeveloped in the e-commerce channel. And it, obviously, is a focus for all of us
componenttext: Matthew, this is Mark Smucker. I'll start and if Barry has anything to add, he can certainly chime in. So first of all, as you know, our industry is, generally speaking, underdeveloped in the e-commerce channel. And it, obviously, is a focus for all of us. Where -- I think, we clearly have an e-commerce business. We are serving the e-commerce channels and the different customers there. We do have plans to continue to strengthen our e-commerce organization as well as meet the needs of -- the unique needs of each of our e-commerce customers. And it's a journey, but it is something that is one of our key priorities. As it relates to the pet specifically, one of the reasons why that -- those products are uniquely qualified to grow in that channel is because typically, they are recurring purchase and they are very heavy. And so it's helpful to the consumer to actually have many folks have those stuff delivered to their front doorstep. And so really, it is the nature of the business that is helping to drive growth there.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016

componenttext: That's a great, Mark. And what I would also add from a pet perspective is we deal directly with the major e-commerce retailers. And so that has really attributed to a lot of our growth. And so that direct relationship is how we build our business together.

componenttext: Okay, understood. And then just last question, the price increase you mentioned in fruit spreads. If you could just talk about the competitive dynamic at the moment. It seemed fairly rational recently, just whether there's any sensitivity right now to the risk of widening price gaps with your key competitor there. And whether you would have any news or innovation plan that would help support the pricing that you've announced.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think we've built so much credibility as a retailer that -- and they understand that we wouldn't take that pricing if it wasn't ingredient-based and commodity-based. And so that -- you'll see it reflected on the shelf, but went into effect the end o
componenttext: No. I think we've built so much credibility as a retailer that -- and they understand that we wouldn't take that pricing if it wasn't ingredient-based and commodity-based. And so that -- you'll see it reflected on the shelf, but went into effect the end of last quarter. And we see it at all major retailers in place, and the initial look at volume is very encouraging. So that's a relatively small category for us, but important. And I think the dynamics that we face, I would imagine the industry faces, so I would expect that both the private label and our competitors would be in the same situation.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016

componenttext: So at the top of the call, there was some discussion around new capabilities. We've obviously talked a lot about innovation here, e-commerce. One of the items that was discussed was revenue management. And I was just wondering if you could talk a little bit more about what that encompasses, what your kind of plans and expectations around that revenue management initiative hours, so that we can start thinking about maybe benefits of that efforts and the timing of those benefits.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jon, it's Mark Smucker. I'll start and then maybe ask Steve if he has anything to add. But first of all, a couple of things. As it relates to -- everybody thinks about revenue management a lot of time as trade. As we all know, it is the combination of tra
componenttext: Jon, it's Mark Smucker. I'll start and then maybe ask Steve if he has anything to add. But first of all, a couple of things. As it relates to -- everybody thinks about revenue management a lot of time as trade. As we all know, it is the combination of trade pricing, all of those and the strategies behind them that encompass revenue growth management. And so as it relates to our trade practices, we are pretty good at doing that. We have had a very good track record with our customers at providing the right programs and efficiencies there. I think what you'll see changing over time, and this is a Smucker comment and probably an industry comment as well, is, as Steve mentioned earlier, the need to get more dialed in and precise. And so as we think about being more strategic as it relates to the total revenue growth management, our goal over time through the development of skills, potentially new systems, better analytics, more centralized data, those types of things, over time, should provide us with the capability to become more strategic in revenue management and more focused as we think about how we deploy pricing and trade across our respective customer base.

headline: The J. M. Smucker Company, Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Nov 17, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The only thing I would add is maybe an example on the fruit spreads' price increase that we have discussed today. If you think about the fruit spread category, it includes a number of segments, a number of sizes and a number of different retailer env
componenttext: Yes. The only thing I would add is maybe an example on the fruit spreads' price increase that we have discussed today. If you think about the fruit spread category, it includes a number of segments, a number of sizes and a number of different retailer environments, right? It's in everything from that EDLP retailer to the higher-level retailer. We've got a 10-ounce small specialty jar and at 32-ounce promoted grape jelly. So in order to understand each one of those slopes, in order to better understand, they hit the penny's business, right? So if we can get a couple of pennies right on each one of those slopes, if our slope between 18 ounce and 32 ounces is right on, what's going to drive the most volume at the best price point? We can make some headway on that. And I think the technology is there today and I think us, as well as many of our peers, have invested in human capital to leverage that technology to get some of those details right. So we're hoping to scrape a couple of margin points out of it across different businesses over time. And that money will be invested in our business as -- or brought back to the bottom line. We'll make those decisions depending on the category, the size, the magnitude.
